The Echo Show 5 has always been a reliable smart display, but this latest version truly steps up the game, especially in terms of sound quality.**Sound Quality:**One of the standout features of this Echo Show is its upgraded sound system. With 2x the bass and clearer sound than its predecessors, the audio quality is surprisingly robust for such a compact device. Whether I'm listening to music, catching up on the news, or watching videos, the sound is rich and immersive. It's perfect for smaller rooms, like the kitchen or bedroom, where you want good audio without the need for a larger speaker.**Display and Design:**The 5.5-inch screen is sharp and vibrant, making it great for watching short clips, checking the weather, or making video calls. The compact design fits easily on any shelf or counter, and the Charcoal color gives it a sleek, modern look that blends well with any decor. The screen's adaptive brightness is a nice touch, adjusting automatically based on the room's lighting.**Smart Features and Alexa Integration:**As expected from an Echo device, the Alexa integration is seamless. Voice commands are picked up easily, even from across the room, and the responses are quick and accurate. I use it to control my smart home devices, set reminders, and even follow along with recipes. The new smart display features also make it easier to see and control multiple smart home devices at once, which is a huge plus for someone like me who has a lot of them.**Privacy and Security:**Amazon has included a physical shutter for the camera, which provides peace of mind for those who are concerned about privacy. There's also a mic/camera off button, which is easy to use and effectively disables both the microphone and camera.**Overall Performance:**The Echo Show 5 (3rd Gen) is a fantastic addition to any smart home setup. It offers a great balance of audio quality, smart features, and privacy controls. Whether you're new to smart displays or looking to upgrade, this device is definitely worth considering. It's small but mighty, and I find myself using it more than I expected for everything from checking my calendar to watching cooking videos.

product_name: All-new Ring Battery Doorbell, Head-to-Toe Video, Live View with Two-Way Talk, and Motion Detection & Alerts (2024 release), Satin Nickel
description: We've had the Ring Doorbell camera for just over a month now. Some things I've learned:Do not expect this to pick up license plates - you can't even read the front plates of our cars parked 10 feet away. There are other home camera packages sold on Amazon that I plan on getting for better home surveillance.This is not a 24 hour recording device. It only starts recording once it picks something up or if you go into live view, and there's a slight lag to it, meaning the deliver guy might be walking away by the time it started recording.You may have to be creative in mounting it. I have siding, so it wouldn't be on a completely flat surface. I cut a piece of pvc board to get full contact.If you don't want to mess with recharging it, wire it into your existing bell wires. The terminal screws are right on the back. I did not realize they were the terminals screws at first, because of how they looked. You don't need to remove any covers to get to them. It will charge very slowly (as designed), but eventually it will get to 100%.You get a 30 day free subscription when you buy this. Ours just ran out, and it was very telling of how this product is designed for you to need the subscription. It is not just that you lose the recording of videos. I could live with that. All day I've been getting tons of motion alerts. It seems to be picking up cars driving down the street that are 30 feet out from the front door. When you are on the free subscription, it has person identification, meaning it isn't alerting you for cars driving by. When you are off the subscription, it alerts you for everything and just says motion alert for it all. I kept adjusting the sensitivity down trying to get it to not pick up cars and it seems like that was doing nothing. So, we caved, and paid for a subscription. As of right now it's $49.99 if you pay for the whole year, for one device. It's almost $10 more if you want to go month to month.It is nice having a camera at the front door, and it's nice to be at work and be able to see the front yard. I know the moment a package is delivered - sometimes you don't know even when you are home. I set up an automated message which starts talking after a few seconds of someone pushing the doorbell. It tells them we aren't home and that they can leave a message. This has worked well for solicitors, as they seem to leave as soon as they hear the message. We no longer have to peak out the window to see who's at the door. It just bothers me that they strip away all the features if you don't get on a subscription plan.

product_name: All-new Ring Battery Doorbell, Head-to-Toe Video, Live View with Two-Way Talk, and Motion Detection & Alerts (2024 release), Satin Nickel
description: I like my ring cameras.  I have six cameras.  My issue with these cameras is that they don’t automatically reconnect to the internet after an outage.  You have to reset each camera.  For stickup cameras it requires taking them apart to hit the reset button.  Of course if your stickup cameras are used indoors and aren’t located in a high position, it’s easy.  But if you have intentions of hanging them in a high location please check how to reset them.  If you use the tilt and pan that also requires dismantling the camera in order to get access to the reset button.  I’m keeping my current cameras but once they don’t work well I’m replacing with another brand.

product_name: All-new Ring Battery Doorbell, Head-to-Toe Video, Live View with Two-Way Talk, and Motion Detection & Alerts (2024 release), Satin Nickel
description: This is more a critique of the SELLER than the product itself. Since I wont be able to utilize the doorbell camera I purchased -- and will return -- it might be good to INFORM any prospective consumers what the WiFi requirements are to operate this product: The WiFi router needs 2.4 Ghz to make this work the way its designed. Most single family homes probably have this capability, but rental properties that have the internet supplied by the landlord may not, as is my case.  Once again, the camera is probably a fine product, but I won't know, at least in the immediate future.

product_name: All-new Ring Battery Doorbell, Head-to-Toe Video, Live View with Two-Way Talk, and Motion Detection & Alerts (2024 release), Satin Nickel
description: Compared to the Ring video doorbell I bought before, this product has a larger wide-angle camera. The packaging box uses a new tear strip opening. The lens protective film has also been replaced with a more environmentally friendly paper material instead of the previous plastic material. The screw bag provided with the product also uses a new semi-transparent plastic fiber material instead of the previous transparent plastic bag. All these are great.However, it's very strange that one of the screws has no thread. It seems that a defective product has been mixed in. Fortunately, I have a replaceable screw in my toolbox, so it doesn't affect my installation. Overall, this is a good product.

product_name: All-new Ring Battery Doorbell, Head-to-Toe Video, Live View with Two-Way Talk, and Motion Detection & Alerts (2024 release), Satin Nickel
description: Good Video But Poor Battery Life.  If you want to only use its internal battery power, be ready to charge this about every four days.

product_name: All-new Ring Battery Doorbell, Head-to-Toe Video, Live View with Two-Way Talk, and Motion Detection & Alerts (2024 release), Satin Nickel
description: I am disappointed that the lack of a replaceable battery was not clearly note in item description. It was minutes to change out the battery on my old doorbell cam. Now the doorbell will be down for a few hours while charging. My installation is not suitable to run a 5 volt AC power lead from a transformer.

product_name: All-new Ring Battery Doorbell, Head-to-Toe Video, Live View with Two-Way Talk, and Motion Detection & Alerts (2024 release), Satin Nickel
description: It only works about half of the time. Every time I walk past it, it alerts me. If I get a delivery, it only alerts me sporadically.

product_name: All-new Ring Battery Doorbell, Head-to-Toe Video, Live View with Two-Way Talk, and Motion Detection & Alerts (2024 release), Satin Nickel
description: Ring support told me that the night vision would be in color…it’s not.Disappointed, I could’ve saved myself the money.

product_name: All-new Ring Battery Doorbell, Head-to-Toe Video, Live View with Two-Way Talk, and Motion Detection & Alerts (2024 release), Satin Nickel
description: Video quality was a major step backwards as the picture was all washed out in any brighter areas.  I had the video doorbell 2 in the exact same location, and the picture quality was fine.Overall was very disappointed with the quality of image.  The larger aspect ratio was nice as it could see the full doorstep, but being completely washed out made this a returned item.  Also that it doesn't come with a corner kit is really cheap and annoying.Con (listed first as it is the major functionality of the camera):- Picture quality (completely washed out even when not in direct sunlight)- Lack of corner mounting kit- Not very secure as you could use a simple flat head screwdriver to unlatch it and take the entire unit in less than a few seconds.Pro:- Image aspect ratio- Look and feel were nice on the bronze model- Like the slimmer profile from other units- Easy install

product_name: All-new Ring Battery Doorbell, Head-to-Toe Video, Live View with Two-Way Talk, and Motion Detection & Alerts (2024 release), Satin Nickel
description: I fully charged this last night and set it on our table.  Then I installed it late this afternoon and tonight it's already down to 80% battery on the low impact settings.  What a pain because you have to take it off and bring it inside to charge it every time so now I don't have a doorbell when I need to (frequently) charge it.  Garbage.  Also you have to buy a separate chime so it's not really a "doorbell", it's a camera.  Finally the Chime "PRO" is a waste.  It's supposed to 'boost' my wi-fi signal to my devices but my chime is about ten feet from my router and my door bell is about 20 feet from my chime but both are continuously saying "poor wi-fi signal".  I should have went with one of the other brands.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: I hope Roku doesn’t get too excited that I bought this and go out and celebrate with champagne. I actually have a ten year old Roku 3 stuffed somewhere deep in a closet or something and it would have worked just fine.  I already have 99.9% of what this does built into my high-end projection TV. The only reason I bought it is that the makers of my TV won’t pay the Netflix licensing fee so I can’t watch the very few things I want from that service on their projector. So the one and only thing this will ever be used for is that purpose. I know most people are here wanting to read reviews with specs and opinions about the picture quality and things like that but if I made just one person’s life better by letting them know for thirty bucks (twenty if HD is good enough for you) you can make your TV or projector think it is compatible with that streaming service.  And it does work.  And maybe I’ll pick up some additional content too, it looks like Roku is going big into the content creation business.PICTURE QUALITYIf you got this far, don’t have high expectations from any review of the picture quality, there is no answer. It is what it is, 4k is 4k, how it looks on your TV will depend mostly on your TV, and to some degree your internet provider, but in any case the Roku box isn’t going to have a very direct influence on what you see.QUIRKSOddly, Roku still uses line-of-sight infrared for their remote control while most remotes I am used to these days are RF. That means the receiver has to be located where the remote can “see” it. With today’s ultra-thin TV’s that can be a challenge because the sensor is located on the side not the face of the receiver, so for it to be “seen” would mean to try to stick the adhesive strip on an edge of a TV that can be less than a quarter of an inch, or even rounded.  As if that’s not bad enough in my case I am using it with a projection TV and my projector is located behind our seating area. The only thing I could do is to choose the best location I could which still means I have to turn around and point the remote backwards at the projection TV. This is 2024, why hasn’t Roku kept up with the real world?Also in the same category is that the four direct access buttons can’t be re-programmed. I know over the years they have changes those buttons as different TV sources come and go in popularity but what if one of the services (I’m thinking Disney) is something we would never use? That wastes 25% of the available buttons. Yet something we watch every day (I’m thinking YouTube) is not possible to assign to that unused button. Again Roku, this is 2024, even ten years ago I could assign my own favorites to a A and a B button, why aren’t you thinking of such things?DEALBREAKERSWhile I used the word dealbreaker I’ll temper that by saying I am keeping this product, not because I want to but because if I want to watch Netflix on my projector I have to. But if that were not the case it would go right back to them right now. It took me three hours to set it up and I am highly technical, I set most things in in minutes usually without reading instructions. If you have a desire to bring back technology for the 1980’s this is the device for you. The setup is maddening. Whether or not you want to use their power button and volume control with your TV, that’s not your choice, they force that decision on you and there is absolutely no way to get past that first setup screen after it hooks up with your wifi. They give you a list of TV brands. If yours isn’t on the list, sorry, there is no way of saying so or skipping that option. Your only option is something they call Advanced (it’s not) which makes the assumption that your TV’s remote is infrared (mine is RF). Roku never heard of RF so you are dead in the water at that point. There is a CEC option but that is way technical and I don’t have to discuss it here. So I went online and not surprisingly they don’t say a word about it. I went to the user forums and other people have the same frustration but there was a lot of “I don’t know or useless suggestions with no way to give feedback that they were useless.  I finally did come up with a way to confuse the device and move on but not after a good part of my afternoon was gone.YES NO MAYBEMy answer is that the HD unit at ten bucks less is so much the same that most people will never be able to tell the difference on 95% of what they watch. But if you are a perfectionist and ten bucks more isn’t a dealbreaker than you might as well splurge.  What about all the other models?  My opinion is your return on investment is very little with them, you get some nice but not necessary features but the price premium is far too much. Overall I would say this model gives you the best bang for your buck but that doesn’t mean I can endorse poor engineering and product design. They are resting on their laurels and shouldn’t be congratulated for that and anything more than an average rating is too high.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: To begin with, the Roku format does provide a little more organizational usefulness than what you'd get from your smart TV remote (I am using it with a Sony Bravia). That being said, there is room for improvement of the Roku device from both an ergonomic and functional perspective.1) The mute and volume buttons are inexplicably located on the side of the remote...right where your middle finger rests when you are applying pressure with your index finger to operate the main control buttons. Consequently, as you grip the remote to operate the buttons you find yourself frequently muting the sound (or occasionally lowering or raising volume) with that middle finger. Mute and volume should be moved to top surface of remote IMHO.2) If you have ever had regular cable or Direct TV you are used to having a number define the channels. The Roku format does not use numbers to define channels, in fact it uses no numbers of any kind. You can sort and customize features of various streaming platforms into smaller groups to make them easier to find. Or you can go into voice command search and destroy mode looking for what you want. But be aware...the days of turning on the TV, punching a memorized three digit number into the remote and going directly to the exact place you want to be are over.3) The basic remote is almost useless in the dark. You would think by now most companies making remotes would incorporate backlighting as a given, but no. Roku seems to push the non-backlit model hard having their retailers place it in the equivalent of "eyesight level, center shelf" in all advertising. It's AFTER you buy it and find out how extraordinarily difficult it is to use in a dark room, you see the obvious need for it to be backlit. Only then do you discover YES, there IS a backlit model they developed. For double the cost of the original, of course.Call me a luddite, but I think a system more akin to regular cable 'channels' could have been developed and incorporated into each streaming platform format by Roku to ease the transition of the over 40 crowd from linear TV to streaming. And, as a significant portion of television watching is done in a dark room, I can't understand why every single remote associated with television viewing isn't backlit. However if you want to make your navigation through the world of streaming a bit more managable, Roku will make your life easier. I just suggest you go for the backlit model right up front. And make sure you get the backlit model for the Roku STICK or dongle. Most of them out there, particularly the cheaper models, are for the Roku TV and will NOT work with the HDMI plug in Roku devices.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: The setup went fine but 3x I've had an issue where your can't see any video one the show plays.  You can hear not the screen is black.  Random channels, random shows.  Have to turn everything off,  unplug the TV,  reset the wireless,  reset the Roku. Even called support. Would've returned it if I felt like logging out of everything and resetting it,  but I was sick.  Worst thing is trouble shooting tech when you're sick and just want to watch a show.Everything new has problems.Remote control is fine.  The Roku itself is small,  like my old one that wasn't Peacock compatible.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: I switched from the fire stick to the Roku. I liked it so much I bought a second one for my bedroom. I love the live tv options and love that the home page isn’t busy like fire stick. However, I noticed my internet usage has gone way up, even during hours when I am not home or asleep. I unplugged roku and the data usage went back to normal. Weird that it uses data when the tv is off and Roku is not in use. If you have unlimited data on your internet, fine, but if you don’t, keep that in mind.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: My old Roku started showing everything pixelated so figured easiest thing was just to buy the newer version.  The new one was super easy to set up and I thought cool when I could link up to the new remote to adjust my tv volume too.  Channeling Pretty Woman, big mistake, Huge!  Got it work for maybe a few presses of the volume and then it just didn't work.  But then because it had synced to the volume, it had kicked off my tv remote so I couldn't even go back to use that.  Messed around with the new remote for 45 min or so and finally gave up.  Couldn't find my old tv booklet either, so had to mess around with the tv remote  to try to get it to sync back to the volume.  FINALLY got both of them back working as just the Roku remote and the tv remote, like my previous set up.But now its only been about a month and a half since purchase, and the 'pause' button on the new Roku remote is acting wonky.  If I push the pause quick like I used to, it pauses for a second and then tv show keeps going.  So have to hold the pause for a few extra seconds for it to 'catch.'  But when you push pause to continue the show, its the opposite - show starts for a few seconds and then goes back on pause by itself.  Next step will be throwing it out the window and digging out one of my old universal remotes because I know they work.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: This Roku seems to work fine but does not shut down when my TV is turned off. The power light on 24/7.I have read that this is intentional to allow it to get updates whenever. It says that it is "low draw" but I want it to turn off when my TV is off.This is still a waste of electricity ("Vampire") and unless I want to manually turn it off each time it is used, it will have to stay on, which is not good.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: I bought this to replace an old Android TV box that I use for RV camping trips with downloaded Netflix and Max tv shows.  Wifi is usually too slow to stream at campsites. The info on Roku stated it supports downloads but when I set it up and went to the Netflix app download was not available so I am returning it.  I understand it's a Netflix app policy to not allow this but Roku should at least provide accurate information on what works.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: Love the way it works EXCEPT the remote has stopped working. Change batteries and they only last a day or so. Keep getting message to pair the remote but it doesnt ever complete the pairing. Just gets into a loop. I have to use my tv remote to power on the tv. Then I use the remote on the ROKU app on my phone to change channels. Bought one for another tv and it does the same thing.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: We've tried several streaming devices & Roku is definitely our favorite. We've been through 3 Fire Sticks & a couple other brands meanwhile our original Roku 3 is still going strong after 10+ yrs. So when the last Fire Stick we decided to go back to Roku. Set up was easy & it worked great....for about an hr. After that we couldn't get it to stay on for more than 7 min. Tried basic trouble shooting & after looking for people who had similar issues on the Roku website found a few people who had the same issue all had to exchange out for a different one. Amazon didn't give us an option to exchange so we returned it, went with the Roku Ultra & had no problems. Actually like it better anyway, it has a find my remote option which with a full house helps.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: Bought this 1 for my room and think god i had a real old remote ( one with no volume control on it ) because this one brand new out of the box today will not work 😑

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: This is our second Roku purchase but our very first brand new one as our first one was given to us used from a friend. We were afraid that buying a new one to have for our other tv would be too expensive but were pleasantly surprised to find this one on Amazon at such a good price! Easy to set up and use with unlimited streaming capability! Did not disappoint!

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: I bought this as my LG TV firmware was incompatible with YouTubeTV and had issues connecting to my wifi.The Roku Express 4K+ has been a game-changer for my home entertainment setup. The 4K and HDR quality make a noticeable difference in streaming, delivering crystal-clear picture quality with vibrant colors. It's perfect for watching movies and shows in stunning detail.Setting it up was quick and simple, and the Roku interface is super user-friendly. I love the voice remote – it makes finding content so much easier, especially with access to free and live TV options. Roku's platform offers a wide range of streaming services, so I can access everything I need in one place, including live TV channels, without needing a cable subscription.The device itself is compact and discreet, and it has been reliable with fast load times and no lag during streaming. Overall, the Roku Express 4K+ is an excellent value for anyone looking to upgrade their TV viewing experience with minimal hassle. Highly recommend!

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: Rokus are arguably the most affordable and easy to use streaming devices on the market. If you don’t have a Roku TV or any kind of smart TV, or want to use this with a projector or something else, this is a no brainer investment.I’ve purchased many of the older Express 1080p units and this 4K+ unit is basically the same with some added perks. The remote included with this unit is a voice remote and allows power control of the TV/display device all within the same remote. The old basic 1080p units did not come with this so it’s a great upgrade. If you use an external audio amplifier that integrates to your home theater via HDMI, CEC control can be used to allow the volume control to control that as well.All necessary cables and batteries for the remote were included. Also includes VHB tape (command strip) to adhere the Roku to your TV if you choose to do so.My application for this was a very early gen smart TV from 2013. Although it’s only 1080p it has a higher refresh rate than most TVs at that time, the picture quality is amazing, and it still works great so I saw no sense in replacing it.My only complaints are with the Roku design and platform, not this unit in particular:- Specific to the remote, there are a number of channel based services that would benefit from a number pad for direct dialing channel numbers. Roku does not support this, so OEM and aftermarket remotes will never be able to utilize this.- I’m a huge fan of the purple arrow buttons. Unfortunately they are rubber, not plastic. Easier on the fingers however they get gooey and degrade over time. I’ve had to replace a handful of Roku remotes over the years because of this- Dedicated streaming service buttons should be programmable. If I don’t subscribe to a service, I don’t want it as a remote hotkey. Interestingly enough, different remotes from different vendors all provide different variations of streaming buttons. There’s no consistency. At that rate, just get rid of them.Despite the small issues that bother me I still would not steer away from Roku as a platform. It has a lot to offer and an excellent price.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: Quick and easy set up. Looks and works great. Even came with 2 different types of connecting wires.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: Purchased in June 2024.The Express 4K+ player is good- fast and responsive and the YouTube Roku app works well. The main reason I purchased this Express 4K+ player was to replace a 10 year old Roku 3 which had trouble with its YouTube app, and a few other apps that apparently were becoming Roku 3 incompatible. The Express 4K+ voice control remote has locked up a few times, however. (Just take out the batteries, and reinsert.) One thing that I had hoped was that the Roku 3's radio gaming remote would allow me to plug in headphones for use with the Express 4K+. But that DOES NOT work. The basic functions of the Roku 3 remote DO WORK on the Express 4K+ player, but the headphone feature DOES NOT. I believe the Express 4K+ player and Voice Control remote are IR optical only. Oddly, there is no obvious window on the front of the remote for the IR light to exit.One last thing- try to use the USB power adapter that comes with the 4K+ Express. I assumed that any old sugar cube type USB power supply would do, and some did not not. Apparently, the Express 4K+ needs quite a bit of power (it does run pretty warm), and the cheapo low current USB cubes may not be able to supply the player with enough power.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: This revived my declining smart TV. Easy to setup, easy to use, and had a great connection. I haven't found any problems yet. Great value for your money.My only complaint is that there is no option to turn off the led indicator light on the unit.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: Some backstory for why I bought it:My son’s tv is an older flat screen and isn’t a smart tv so he has used my old vcr and vhs tapes to watch while he falls asleep because it helps him not be so scared at night, but when we had to move into our new house, the vcr was somehow damaged and won’t work. He was miserable ever since, especially in a new house.I had heard about Roku awhile back, so I looked into it and saw that it can be used on tvs that aren’t smart ones, so I decided to order this for him for Christmas last year and he LOVES it!It’s got access to all the apps he uses, but it also has its own channels, like a Roku kids channel complete with a variety of different kids shows, even streams from their fav streamers. It was extremely easy to setup, and you can even set it to be able to control the tv power so you don’t have to use multiple remotes. It has an auto shutoff so it’s not on all night, can be controlled with the app as well as the physical remote which has come in handy when he’s lost it and couldn’t find it before bedtime, and the box that gets hooked up to the tv is little and compact, and it comes with sticky pads to stick it wherever you need it without worrying about it shifting around or if you can’t find a flat surface and want to stick it to the tv.It has really helped us out over here in a big way and I def recommend it especially to anyone in a similar situation!

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: After using the Roku Express 4K+ for a few weeks, I can confidently say I’m really happy with my decision. I was looking for a way to upgrade my streaming setup and get 4K quality without spending too much, and this device has delivered in all the areas that matter most to me.Pros:Amazing Picture Quality:The 4K HDR support on this Roku is impressive. Watching movies and shows in 4K has been a noticeable upgrade in picture quality. Colors are vibrant, and details are crisp. Even older content looks better, and I’ve really enjoyed seeing my favorite shows in a new light with such clear, sharp visuals.Simple Setup and Easy to Use:Setting up the Roku Express 4K+ was so easy. I had it up and running in just a few minutes, thanks to the clear instructions on the screen. The interface is straightforward, and navigating through different apps and channels is super simple. Everything I need is right there, and I don’t have to spend time hunting for what I want.Roku Voice Remote is a Game-Changer:The Roku Voice Remote is one of my favorite features. I love how easy it is to search for shows or movies just by speaking into the remote. It works really well, and I don’t have to scroll through endless menus anymore. Plus, it controls both the Roku and my TV’s volume and power, so I only need one remote.Great Free and Live TV Options:I’ve been really enjoying the free channels and live TV access. The Roku Channel offers a solid variety of free movies and shows, and there are a lot of live news, sports, and entertainment channels available, which means I don’t need an extra subscription to watch live content.Tons of Streaming Options:Having access to all the major streaming services like Netflix, Hulu, Disney+, and Prime Video is perfect for me. I’m able to find whatever I’m in the mood for, and the device handles everything smoothly. The app interface is clean and easy to navigate, which makes switching between different streaming services hassle-free.Cons:Not for Gaming:While this device is great for streaming, it’s not built for gaming. If I wanted to play any serious games, this wouldn’t be the right choice, but that’s not something I’m using it for, so it doesn’t bother me.Audio isn’t Top-Tier:The sound quality is decent but not exceptional. The built-in audio is fine for everyday use, but it doesn’t blow me away, especially with the 4K visuals. I’m considering adding a soundbar to get better sound to match the picture quality, but for now, I’m still happy with how it performs overall.No Ethernet Port:The lack of an Ethernet port is a bit of a downside for me since I prefer wired connections for more stable streaming. I’m using Wi-Fi, which works just fine, but I do notice occasional fluctuations in speed. Not a deal-breaker for me, but it's something I’ve noticed.Final Thoughts:The Roku Express 4K+ has been an excellent addition to my setup. The picture quality is fantastic, the voice remote is incredibly convenient, and the setup was quick and easy. The free and live TV options are a nice bonus, and I’ve found myself exploring a lot of new content because of it. While the sound quality and lack of an Ethernet port are small inconveniences, they haven’t detracted from my overall enjoyment of the device.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: Roku has been in the streaming business since the very beginning.  In fact, when Netflix began its transition from DVD rentals to streaming services, the only way to watch Netflix was either on your computer or with a Roku device.  I have a smart TV, but it has a billion apps that clutter up the screen and which I never use.  Also, since its interface is android based, it need to have apps closed and the cache cleared on a regular basis or it will either slow down or some apps may stop working altogether.  So I bought this little streamer from Roku to skip all that bloat and extra work.  For the money, it can't be beat.  The only reason I took off one star is that the light on the front doesn't go off, despite the fact that I chose the option in settings to allow the device to go into standby mode when there is no activity after 20 minutes.  I called Roku customer service twice about this.  The first person I talked to didn't seem sure, but finally said it should stay on, although no rationale given.  The second person was certain it should go off like with my earlier model Roku's.  However, when I asked why mine didn't go off, I got no answer.  They need to get their story straight; further, how can you tell the unit is in standby mode if the "on" light stays lit?  I still recommend this unit and have bought several others for Christmas presents.

product_name: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
description: Our old TV just got a reprieve.  After doing some research, we bought this Roku Express 4K+ streaming player and found it works quite well.  We have hooked it up to an old Samsung 22" TV (model code LT22B350ND/ZA) which was made in 2013.  Received it within a few days of ordering it and it took about 20 minutes to get it working.Ease of use: Follow the included instructions.  I plugged it into our power strip rather than the TV USB port since I heard that there were issues related to that (one report of fire, some issues with inadequate power, etc.).  Remote takes a little time getting used to - I haven't figured out what all the buttons do and I still haven't figured out how to slave the remote to adjust TV sound.  I can imagine that will make my life easier because I won't need to use the TV remote for anything else except for changing the input source and doing some TV fine tuning.  Volume adjust/mute buttons are on the side of the remote which was an issue for a few people, but I'm OK with it.  From past reviews, sounds like the remote is not very durable but that remains to be seen.Speed: quite responsive - no complaintsAppearance: The wireless receiver is quite unobtrusive.  This Roku comes with a mounting strip so you can stick it where you want it.  I just parked it on the TV base without the strip.Battery life and the rest:  remains to be seen but for a gadget that cost less than $40, we're satisfied.  So much so that we will get another for our living room TV - it's a few years younger but we expect the Netflix and Prime Video software for it to eventually outdate.  One thing that bothers me is that you have to sign up for a Roku account which means giving out your credit card info.  I still have misgivings about doing that being the closet Luddite that I am.

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: I've had an iPad Mini 4, 5 and now 6. I use them in the cockpit of a small plane, which is one thing Apple is now marketing the Mini 6 for. But I also use it for general tablet stuff; web browsing, watching YouTube, listening to music. I upgraded from the 5 to the 6 specifically for Pencil 2 support. The Mini 5 supports the first-gen Pencil, and while that was great as a first step towards going paperless in the cockpit for me, the way the Pencil 1 charges is just really an inconvenience for my use. I'd constantly get in the plane only to realize my Pencil is dead, and I'd have to just go back to paper anyway. I ended up just always carrying paper and a pen on me anyway, which kind of defeats the purpose of having the Pencil. So being able to have the Pencil 2 constantly stuck to the iPad and charging magnetically was enough in itself to get me to upgrade.You'd normally expect that any upgraded tech device would have all the stuff you liked about the prior model, but just with more power, features and/or a more elegant design. In the case of the Mini 6, though, I feel like it may be one step forward, two steps back. I'm really happy with the Pencil 2 support but not really with anything else. I may actually be returning it; I'll update this review if I do.First, jelly scroll is real. I'm always skeptical of complaints like this. They often start with one person who's either overly nitpicky or who just got a defective unit, and then they snowball as others with the same defect or a severe case of OCD write internet comments in agreement. But I was honestly shocked when I turned on my Mini 6, went to a random web page in Chrome, scrolled and saw the effect. It was much worse than I expected, and easily noticeable. It is difficult to believe this got past Apple's quality control.In reading some other articles about this, it seems clear that Apple's not really lying when they say this is "normal LCD behavior", but the problem is that they've mounted the screen controller in the Mini 6 sideways. If you look at the Mini 5, and pretty much any other tablet, you do see some jelly scrolling in landscape orientation, but not in portrait orientation. The Mini 6 is the opposite; it jelly scrolls in portrait but not in landscape. So it is, oddly, a landscape tablet. The weird thing about it, though, is that the controls are not really set up for that orientation, and I sure don't normally use it that way. It's not an efficient way to read web pages; the only thing it's good for is watching videos, where jelly scrolling isn't an issue regardless of how the screen controller's mounted.The screen is also slightly taller (or you could say "wider" if you consider it a landscape tablet), and that doesn't work well in portrait mode either. My Mini 5 shows 6 icons across and they are nicely spaced. The Mini 6, using the same settings (smaller icons), shows 5 icons across and they are weirdly bunched up in the middle. This could be fixed with an OS update but I'd never buy any product based on the promise of a future update. Also, it again is just a weird design decision from a company that's supposed to be all about design.I compared the screen brightness of the two tablets as well and while they're close, the Mini 5 is very slightly brighter. Again, I made sure they had the same settings - max brightness, Night Shift off, and True Tone both on and off. The Mini 5 screen always wins by a hair.Add to all that the removal of the headphone jack and I'd say that if you don't need Pencil 2 support, keep your Mini 5 or buy a refurbished one if you're in the market for your first Mini. Save yourself some money too. This was just not a very good update to the Mini line.Personally, I just need to decide if the Pencil 2 support is enough to overcome all of the Mini 6's downsides. My only viable alternative if I do want the Pencil 2 is the iPad Air, which is $100 more expensive and bigger/heavier... not necessarily an asset in a small plane carrying two people. The iPad Pro also supports the Pencil 2 but it is larger still and even more expensive. It's a tough call for me, but I'd definitely say that most people should get either a Mini 5 (if you don't need the Pencil 2) or an Air (if you want the Pencil 2 and have the space for a larger tablet).

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: Stays charge only 2 hours. And an 80$ one I had, I can’t tell no difference. I was expecting so much more. I ordered a new one .. but I think this is second hand. I’m caucasian, but everything on here was of the Black person. Even the emoji was black. I deleted and change things around. I hate complaining like this .. but I thought you needed to know😡 just had to charge again 😢😢😢

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: I was looking for a small tablet as replacement for a Samsung S2 8in which has a great screen but, after 8 years, the wifi and processor became too slow for most news & book apps, youtube and web-browsingand, with Android, became annoyed with the increasing ads and excessive data collecting by google. The IPAD mini has a  high-resolution screen and can be used with one hand as the S2, but it has speedy wifi and a fast chip in a small and light tab, not available in Android anymore.IOS seemed to have stood still (since 2015 I last used an Apple SE) and has not kept up with the hardware.It is functional, though some oddities:-  The screen-layout shows some large, esthetically ugly,  icon-voided areas on the right and left. The 4x6 cannot be changes to, e.g. 6x7, 6x8, or whatever a user may find pleasing. It seems to be designed for cell phones with high aspect ratio.- The folders show unreadable images for the apps  (unlike Android).- Inconsistent 'back page button' within apps. E.g. in some apps, a tiny arrow appears on the upper left, in others, it is in the lower area of the screen, etc.- Disappointing to me: By now, as many and as intrusive ads like Android.Summary: I will keep it because there is no alternative. Apple seems to be the only player left not following the mantra  "Bigger is better" (unless coupled with inferior hardware).

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: I believe my battery died but I am not sure how. I take good care of my tablet; nothing has ever happened to it before. I believe I need a new or reset battery. What can I do?

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: These are a really great product but they cannot handle kids doing their thing with them. My daughter has had a history of sitting in front of her tablet for way too long. I hesitated getting her another one. She and her sisters are so precious to me. I know rainy days seem gloomy if your not stimulated and I teeter between listening to her laugh and play with others on a tablet to feel like I am not engaging and teaching her real world life experiences. Well 2 months in she had a black line on her screen, a few days later her screen went black. I thought I purchased extra protection (Apple +) but I didnt. going through apple warranty support is pretty dismal. You need to new aside a day and time (Appointment) to bring it to a Best Buy store 40 miles away and it only says cracked front screen only in the repair note. Tried to bring up another repair....only available for it is cracked screen. With no other option I would say that it is a good product but it is not supported well. I have no clue if she got water inside of it or it was defective. But somehow we are outside of the support and service loop. I will not be buying her another apple product but I will engage her more and I think we will both be much more happy in life. Buyer beware of the lure of twinkly lights and the sadness it brings.

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: It’s nice to have a lightweight, easier to carry tablet.  The tips of my fairly small fingers fumble at the keyboard trying not to err. Not to mention the keyboard changes! This won’t change because I’m still using my larger iPad.  Also, the smaller print (adjustable but time-consuming) is challenging to my aging eyes. Both the old & the new time out fast, partly because I forget to ditch websites.  But really—How do people read books on these things? Guess I should use my Kindle.

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: very fun

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: I have an iPad Pro 12.9", mostly for reading music at the piano, and a new iPhone 15 Pro. I purchased the iPad Mini on a whim because I thought my 60-year-old eyes might appreciate something larger than the phone without the bulk of the iPad Pro.The iPad Mini in Starlight is an elegant little tablet, but after trying it out for several days, I found myself reaching for my iPhone. Here's why.While I gained some screen real estate over the phone, the Mini's text generally wasn't any larger without zooming in, and many apps I use didn't scale to its screen size. I missed Face ID, even though the Touch button performed admirably, and I quickly started longing for my iPhone's smooth-as-silk Pro Motion scrolling.Yesterday, I picked up the iPad Mini for one last time and sighed as it became clear that I never should have left my iPhone. I spent too much money on a shiny new thing that offered me nothing I didn't already have. I erased it, carefully repackaged it, and set up a return authorization.You might be pleased with the iPad Mini if you haven't spent years looking at Apple’s flagship tablets and phones, But if Pro is all you know, I suspect your experience will resemble mine. The Mini and I just weren't meant to be together.

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: Easy to use speed and functionality

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: Great product and a good buy. I'm giving this purchase1 star because the return process was so time consuming and stressful. I bought two of these iPads - one for me and one for my grandson. When they arrived, I realized it did not have enough memory for my needs so I went online immediately to return it. I didn't even take the wrapping off. I kept the one for my grandson. And he really loves it! After I initiated the return process, I was not given a return label. Instead I was directed to wait all day for the UPS person to pick it up so I could sign for it.  It did not specify which day I was supposed to stay home. I didn't have an entire day to stay home so every day for 3 days the UPS worker came to pick it up, but I wasn't there. Amazon Customer Service kept telling me that UPS would leave a Return Label, but that didn't happen. Finally a supervisor sent me a Return Label, I paid for the return and UPS tracking showed it was returned. It took many more calls to ensure I got my money back. So the product is great, but the return is extremely difficult if you don't have all day to wait for the UPS person. Amazon Customer service personnel were polite, hardworking, and persistent regarding this problem - thank goodness!! Customers need to know if you buy this product and want to return it, you must be willing to devote a whole day staying home so it can be returned. Otherwise, it is a great product.

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: Once upon a time, a little girl was playing on her 2016 iPad that still had a button on the bottom of the screen. This girl would play Roblox all the time and she would not do any house chores or go outside anymore; she would be on that iPad for hours. Till one day her father broke it because she did nothing to help- out in the house. Years later… Yes, I was that little girl. I worked in landscaping trying to make money to buy a new iPad for school. I saw that all the iPads were too big, or they were too expensive. Nothing was to my liking, I wanted something small that could fit in any bag I carried or if I wanted to carry it would not look so big on my arm. That is when I gladly found the iPad mini. It was small and cute, but even with it being small. It was perfect for everyday use. It has Touch ID but there was no button on the bottom of the screen, it was on top of the iPad where the on and off button is. Making is easy access to use your iPad and do not worry it also has your basic 4 or 6 passwords just in case anyone wants to counterfeit your fingerprint. Now, let us talk about the battery on this iPad. It lasts up to the end of the day which is good if you take online notes in class. It comes in any style of service, as a college student I have Wi-Fi only on this iPad which is good enough for me. Let me get started on how you can decorate your home screen in your style, you can use photo widgets to create a pretty style, making it any design you would want. Like if you love the ocean your iPad mini can be based on the ocean by putting cute photo widgets of the ocean. My design contains a forest and my favorite color with a simple that is in the color dark green. Not only can you decorate your iPad mini you could also add other widgets to have fast access to any app if you do not want to look for it or you can put the widget on your Home Screen or even your Lock Screen. Speaking about the Home Screen the good thing about it is that you can split your screen, and I love that feature because it makes it easier to read a passage of a book and then the other screen has the questions and that makes my life so much easier, I tell you. Making it faster to do homework. You can now have another app open while doing your homework, with the multi-task feature that allows you to watch your favorite show while doing your homework!Not only is the Home Screen and Lock Screen the best thing out there, but your iPhone or Apple Watch connects to the iPad, which also lets you send a sneaky text message in class if teachers do not allow phones. Not only are text messages connected to the iPad but also if someone calls it shows on your screen as well. So, there is no excuse for why you do not answer your mom’s messages. If you love taking pictures of anything, the iPad mini camera has such excellent quality, or if you love to make videos and you need somewhere to edit, you can do that on the iPad mini too. Let's say you are an artist, and you love to draw on the iPad, the new mini canvas feature can get that idea on your screen before you forget. Overall, what I love about the iPad mini is that even with it being small, the price for it is not even expensive. It is in a fair price range perfect for my 10-year-old self to afford with the birthday money I would have had, if only my parents did not take it away. It is a perfect starter iPad if you are a college student or high school student. Or even if you want one like I said something small and light weight the iPad mini is your perfect fit.!

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: First let me tell you I was hesitant about buying an iPad Mini. I even considered buying an iPad Pro: I have had two 9.7" iPads (series 4 and series 6) so I thought I would miss a larger screen. Turns out, I didn't. I will give you a few hints on what to expect with this device:Pros:* Higher resolution: One of the main factors that led me to buy this tiny beast was the screen resolution (319 ppi),  which is higher than any other iPad's resolution. I highlight this feature because I use my iPad primarily to read and watch IT videos.* Portability (it's really lightweight! You will be astounded when you pick one of these)* Size (You can hold the whole device with one hand while writing with the other, something unthinkable in larger iPads).* Battery life (Discharge rate: about 5% / hour when playing videos; Charge rate: about 10% / 14 min)* TouchID (Very convenient, and it recognizes the fingerprint very quickly)* Stereo speakers (they sound really good!)* Apple Pencil support (When paired with an Apple pencil, it's a breeze. I'm using a note-taking application that allows me to use my iPad as a small notebook. It made me wish I had done this while I was still studying).* Three months of Apple TV+, Apple Arcade and Apple Music (Apple gives you three months of Apple TV+, Apple Arcade and Apple Music by only purchasing the device. So I'm enjoying a series in Apple TV+ "For all mankind" and it really looks great in this screen. I'm planning to watch other productions during these three months).Cons:* No silent mode switch (I use teh control center to lower the volume when needed)* No FaceID (I use the TouchID and it's very convenient and fast)* No raise to wake (I gently double tap the screen to wake it up).* No Promotion (There is no workaround to this. The device has a standard 60hz screen, so you will have to decide if you accept it or not)* Some users report sort of a "jelly effect" in the screen when you fast scroll the screen. I haven't noticed anything similar to this behavior in any direction (up, down in vertical nor portrait mode).A word of advice about storage:* If you're thinking about this device, go for the 256 GB one. That was my selection, and I'm glad I did it, because after only one week of usage, I have already used 35 GB of storage. Had I selected the 64 GB version, I would be worried about the storage already.Conclusion:The iPad mini lacks some features its bigger brothers have, but despite this fact, this is totally a great device. If you can sacrifice those features in favor of portability (or you find a way to sort them, as I did), you won't regret. Hopefully we will be able to see an "iPad Pro Mini" in the future (I hope Apple folks read this review someday), but for now, I'm very happy with this purchase. I'm declaring myself an iPad mini fan from now on.

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: The Apple iPad Mini (6th Generation) is fantastic! The A15 Bionic chip makes everything smooth and fast, from browsing to running apps. The 8.3-inch Liquid Retina display is stunning—perfect for watching videos, reading, or gaming. The compact size makes it incredibly portable without sacrificing performance. 64GB is ample storage for my needs, and it handles multitasking seamlessly. Whether for work or entertainment, this iPad Mini is the perfect balance of power and portability. Highly recommend!

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: I spent 7 hours researching a good ipad. I wanted something to use in my hand, not to big or small. I am coming from the iPad mini 5th generation and WOW is this a huge step up. So many great things about it. Not one bad thing at all. I have 9 apple products and love them all. I'm well pleased. Apple does it again. I am glad that I got a good price for this. Apple and eBay sells this for $100 more so I bought it from Amazon. I am so glad that I did. It is super fast. Great feel, quality and awesome camera. The picture quality is unreal. It is very portable even with a case on it. The storage is great. I have 30GB free even after the new iOS install. This is a larger screen than the iPad 5th generation. No more home button, yay. I love the round square edges. I love the pencil 2 charging option. The new A15 bionic chip is awesome. So fast. The battery last 10 hours. Everything loads faster and better. My web pages load so much faster. The video content is awesome. I am very impressed. The 8.3" screen is larger than the 7.9" screens and you can tell the difference. I love the edge to edge viewing. The colors are so very real and vibrant. I highly recommend this. Must buy. I buy a new ipad Everytime they come out with the mini.

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: I bought this on a whim over prime day. I had been looking for something to take quick notes at work, edit PDFs for simple stuff at work and home, and I had really been getting sick of reading on my phone.We have a lot of apple products in my household and to be honest, we've ALL been impressed with the power this things packs and the ease of getting it set up! I can edit spreadsheets easily if I need to and use it for work way more than I thought I would be. We have an iPad Pro 10 inch and the new 10th generation air and none of them seem to perform any better than mine does, but the big thing about it that is a HUGE for me is that it is SO small and light, super easy to tote around, doesn't really add any weight to my bag (which is great, I do a LOT of computer work and sometimes carry around more than one laptop.) I used this to replace my regular notebook and was just including a size reference. I cannot believe how much smaller it is, and it never runs out!I really thought I was going to have a little bit of buyers regret about this but I have absolutely ZERO. If you're thinking about it and you have a little to spare for a fun purchase, you'll love it.

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: The iPad is my favorite accessibility tool.  My 12.9" iPad Pros (one for work, one for home) are my go-to tools all day long.  Being visually-impaired, they're a godsend.  But, they're also heavy, and a bit clumsy in some cases.  As a magnifier, for example.For years I've been using an old 2017 10.5" iPad Pro as a magnifier and general-use tool on my workbench. However, it was getting slow and cranky, plus the battery was losing charge pretty quickly.  I decided to replace it with this iPad mini, since compared to most dedicated accessibility tools, it's rather inexpensive.It turned out to be a good choice.  The camera is sharp, and the form factor makes it easy to get into cramped spaces.  Not to mention it's light: at half the weight of my iPad Pro, I almost tossed it in the air the first time I used it.What came as a surprise is how much I turn to it for other needs.  It's nice to use sitting on the couch and having VoiceOver read news stories to me, or to have text conversations with friends, etc.  Because it has a decent A15 SoC, it doesn't lag when doing VoiceOver.  Plus, the battery life is amazing.It's a decent tool, and I expect I'll be using it for many years.

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: This is my third iPad. My first was an iPad Pro from 2017, second was my iPad Air 5th generation, and then this little guy. My boyfriend received my 2017 iPad from me (it still works well), and I love my iPad Air, but it’s a hassle to take it anywhere unless I have an enormous purse, or my work backpack.Hence, I bought this iPad mini during prime day (awesome deal!)I got the starlight color and 256 gb Wi-Fi only model. I decided to pay the extra $$$ to get the larger memory so that I can have the freedom to download movies and tv shows for when I don’t have Wi-Fi. Also, 64 gb is hardly enough storage nowadays, at least in my opinion.I use my iPad for reading, streaming movies/tv shows, as a planner, as a coloring book and sketchbook, and surfing the internet. I also purchased an Apple Pencil, second generation, and I purchased a Paperlike screen protector— it helps me write easier and smoother on it.I love this thing!!! It’s perfect to take literally anywhere and fits in most of my purses. I will say, battery life is subpar, especially when compared with my older iPad Pro. The 2021 iPad mini and 2022 iPad Air that I own don’t have the best battery life, but at least they charge up quickly with the included usb-c charger. I guess the newer models don’t hold a charge as long, but when I travel I bring an Anker portable battery with me, just in case.Yes… jelly scrolling is real, but not a deal breaker for me. You see it, but I don’t find it distracting at all. It only happens in portrait mode when you’re scrolling quickly, and because it’s an issue I expected, I’m not going to fuss over or complain about it.I’m planning on purchasing apple care. If you get an Apple device, there’s no reason not to get it, in my opinion. Apple will replace the iPad under warranty if something is wrong with it (not including accidents) for up to a year after original purchase, but if you don’t have Apple care and something happens after that, you’re stuck with a hefty bill. So… spend the extra coin and get apple care.This isn’t as heavy as my iPad Air, I can easily hold it in one hand, which makes it perfect for reading and watching shows. I believe it weighs about .5 lbs less than the Air or something like that.I don’t notice much of a difference between this iPad mini and my iPad Air with the M1 chip in it as far as processing power goes. It’s still fast and powerful, and can tackle anything I throw at it with ease.Delivery was okay. Amazon sent me a code to give to the Amazon driver on the day of delivery (the day after I ordered it). The driver dropped the iPad case I’d ordered on my doorstep, then left. I had to chase him down to give him the code and get my package. So a bit aggravating, but it ended up working out fine.I would definitely recommend this iPad mini to anyone who is looking for something larger than a phone, but smaller than an original sized iPad or laptop. It’s super portable. Sure, a little small for setting up two windows side by side, but I don’t do that often. Wait for a sale and purchase it! It’ll be well worth it.

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: Updated my old mini.  Pluses: Very fast cpu & video; great screen form factor; quad speakers for vertical or horizontal use; plenty of memory for my needs, USB-C is convenient.  Minuses: I miss the home button - they try to do too much with the remaining buttons; touch id is slow & somewhat clumsy - you have to master a suite of gestures in order to switch apps, etc.  No audio out either, only bluetooth devices.  iPadOS inexplicably moves things around from iOS; most maddening is the on-screen keyboard, which also works poorly.  The camera is just okay but not nearly the quality of newer iPhones.  Despite all this the iPad Mini is my favorite browsing and viewing device for use all day long.

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: Great mini iPad. Love the size for streaming shows while I’m cooking. It’s bigger than my cell phone and way smaller than my laptop. It’s a perfect size for my needs. The price was phenomenal on prime day, at $349 when Apple had this for $499 still. I love the pink color, I love the vibrancy of the screen and how fast the processor seems to be. I absolutely recommend it if you need a small portable iPad!This was NOT free from Vine, I purchased with my own money.

product_name: Apple iPad Mini (A15 Bionic): 8.3-inch Liquid Retina Display, 64GB, Wi-Fi 6, 12MP front/12MP Back Camera, Touch ID, All-Day Battery Life – Space Gray
description: I took it out of the box, turned it on, and it said if I wanna set up to my old iPad, just have them next to each other. I put them next to each other and completed all the steps on the screen and is perfect.I just received a few hours ago and I love it so far

Battery may be a little on the weaker side but it charges quickly and I do get a lot of use out of it.Would buy again for a backup.

Being rechargeable, it eliminates the need for disposable cans, making it eco-friendly and cost-effective in the long run. Its portability and robust performance make it a must-have for keeping electronics and even car interiors dust-free especially with young children. Highly recommended for those seeking a sustainable and efficient cleaning solution!

product_name: Anker Power Bank (PowerCore 10K), Compact Travel-Ready 10,000mAh Battery Pack with PowerIQ Charging Technology, 5V/3A High-Speed Charging, USB-C (In and Out) for iPhone, iPad, Samsung, Pixel, and More
description: Anker batteries used to hold about 10% more than their claimed amount.  However this battery fell short at 9.1Ah, just under 10% of the claimed 10Ah.This was tested by fully charging the battery out of the box.  Then fully draining the battery.  Then finally fully charging the battery again this time with a meter.Case is made of plastic.  The face has a crosshatch like pattern, the rest of the case is a smooth normal plastic.  The ports feel tight and should last. The battery has a nice feel in the hands.Is this just a one off dud or has Anker's commitment to quality tapered off as they have diversified their product line?

product_name: Anker Power Bank (PowerCore 10K), Compact Travel-Ready 10,000mAh Battery Pack with PowerIQ Charging Technology, 5V/3A High-Speed Charging, USB-C (In and Out) for iPhone, iPad, Samsung, Pixel, and More
description: It is entirely possible that I got a bad unit... it happens.  Unfortunately, after all of the positive things being said about this power bank I am left just scratching my head.First of all, it is inexpensive... I get that.  But still... Anker has a solid reputation, and this fails them miserably.Time to charge -- entirely too long.  I left it plugged in for about 24 hours; according to the very difficult to understand lighting system, it should have been fully charged and good for at least 1.5 recharges of my iPhone 12.Time to recharge iPhone (12) -- entirely too long.  I left my iPhone, which was at about 30%, plugged into this overnight (about 9 hours) and it was only at 82% charged.  My better half also needed to charge her phone (which was at 11%) and after 4 hours it was only at 19% and the power bank appeared to be dead as there were no lights on, and regardless of how you pushed the button nothing happened.I needed this as a very last second purchase prior to hurricane Milton in Florida... fortunately, I was able to connect to alternate power sources to recharge my phone because if I were totally dependent on this thing I would have been completely out of touch.At a minimum, any future power blocks I may purchase with have a display to show how much power is left because trying to figure out the lights on this thing... well, I never really did.And this unit does not come with an instruction manual but rather a QR code to download one; except, it did not seem to download the *correct* instruction manual for me... subtle differences in descriptions lead me to believe the instruction manual is for a newer/different unit.Since I've used it, and tossed the packaging, I guess I'm stuck with it... to be added to a drawer full of junk electronics that I never use...

product_name: Anker Power Bank (PowerCore 10K), Compact Travel-Ready 10,000mAh Battery Pack with PowerIQ Charging Technology, 5V/3A High-Speed Charging, USB-C (In and Out) for iPhone, iPad, Samsung, Pixel, and More
description: I love how compact it is and light. I don't carry around a bulky purse it's small enough to fit in my belt bag. It would last me almost a whole week.My only problem is that I can NEVER get it to turn off so by the time I need to use it half or more of the battery is gone. Yes this could totally be a user error but I promise I looked at the paper it came with and gooogle it. I still can't figure it out. I finally had to give in and just buy another power bank with clear instructions on how to turn it off.

product_name: Anker Power Bank (PowerCore 10K), Compact Travel-Ready 10,000mAh Battery Pack with PowerIQ Charging Technology, 5V/3A High-Speed Charging, USB-C (In and Out) for iPhone, iPad, Samsung, Pixel, and More
description: Only used this product maybe 20 times in 2.5 years. Worked great until now. I can’t get the battery pack to charge anymore. I tried multiple cords to make sure that wasn’t the issue but it wont charge at all anymore I

product_name: Anker Power Bank (PowerCore 10K), Compact Travel-Ready 10,000mAh Battery Pack with PowerIQ Charging Technology, 5V/3A High-Speed Charging, USB-C (In and Out) for iPhone, iPad, Samsung, Pixel, and More
description: I update my review to provide the following information: After writing the original review of the product, Anker noticed I wasn’t satisfied and proactively reached out to me to offer a full refund. When I accepted, they said they would be happy to provide a refund but would prefer to provide me a different Anker portable battery that was more powerful. They wanted me to give their brand another chance because they stand behind their products. I accepted this offer, and they sent me an upgraded product in the mail, free of charge. They explained that the PowerCore Slim 10000 can only offer 6000-7000 mAh battery capacity to your phone. Even after I received the new product, Anker reached out to me to ask if the new product worked for me. This reaction shows that Anker truly cares about their customers.Original review:--------------------------------------------------After doing some research, I purchased the Anker PowerCore Slim 10000, but I am not happy with my purchase. The reason for the purchase was a backpacking trip I was going to take. From what I read, hikers suggested buying a name brand, like Anker, if buying a portable charger. When backpacking, you want to minimize the weight you carry so I liked the slim and light weight feature of this product.This was my first purchase of a power bank. I had received a free one that has a company logo on it that is the size of a flash drive. It is able to charge my phone 50%. When buying a power bank that is much larger and weighs over half a pound, I expected to be able to charge my phone several times. However, that isn’t the case with this Anker product.The main problem I have is that it only charged my phone 1.1 times (110%). I expected to be able to charge a minimum of 250% and hoped for 400%. The first night, I charged my phone from 15% to 75%, and the 2nd night, I charged my phone from 35% to 85%. That is all the Anker provided me so I was only able to increase my phone battery 60% after day one and 50% after day two, a total of 110%. Hoping it was a one-time thing and maybe the product would improve after the first use, I tested it again after the trip and got the same results. It wouldn’t even charge my phone much more than once.One appeal to me was the light weight indicated in the Amazon listing. The Product Information section indicates that the Item Weight is 7.5 ounces. The “Compare with similar items” on Amazon indicates the product is 145 grams, which translates to about 5.1 ounces. When I received the product in the mail, the User Manual indicates the product is 206.5 grams, which is about 7.3 ounces. However, all of these are incorrect; the charger itself actually weighs 8.4 ounces, the charging cable weighs .4 ounces, and the carrying bag weighs .3 ounces. Most people probably don’t care that the advertised weight is understated, but if you are considering purchasing this product for a through-hike, it would be nice to know how heavy the product actually is.Prior to purchasing, I had read a bad review where a buyer suspected receiving a refurbished product. Although my product was delivered in a stickered box and contained paperwork, such as the User Manual, I do wonder if I received a refurbished product too, since the product was only able to charge my phone 1.1 times.I think the product looks nice. I like how there is some indicator of how much charge is left; there are four lights on the power button that light up to show whether the charge is near 25%, 50%, 75%, or 100%.Since another reviewer indicated the product didn’t even work, I can say that I am thankful that I received some charge on my phone. It would have been very difficult for me to not be able to recharge my phone at all while on the trip. This is the reason I don’t give only one star.

product_name: Anker Power Bank (PowerCore 10K), Compact Travel-Ready 10,000mAh Battery Pack with PowerIQ Charging Technology, 5V/3A High-Speed Charging, USB-C (In and Out) for iPhone, iPad, Samsung, Pixel, and More
description: I have owned a Anker charger for many years and love it. It amazing how long it keeps a charge. If not or barely used my old one will keep a charge months. I would rate it 4.9 with 5 being the highest. The only complaint is the weight.  The new one I purchased is for my husband. As with my old it is heavy. With the new one I have difficulty attaching the cord into the port.  It should not take that much force. I started to return them, but I really needed them.

product_name: Anker Power Bank (PowerCore 10K), Compact Travel-Ready 10,000mAh Battery Pack with PowerIQ Charging Technology, 5V/3A High-Speed Charging, USB-C (In and Out) for iPhone, iPad, Samsung, Pixel, and More
description: I bought this for recharging my phone and GPS while backpacking, a situation where equipment dependability can save your life.  I read a lot of reviews on backpacking sites and this brand was much preferred over other brands.  I had been using a battery bank with replaceable batteries which seemed like a good idea, but the batteries would get jostled away from the contacts, charging was slow, and capacity was limited.  This bank charges my iPhone and other devices quicker, and has a very good capacity to weight ratio.  It has been very dependable so far.  The size and shape is easy to carry.

product_name: Anker Power Bank (PowerCore 10K), Compact Travel-Ready 10,000mAh Battery Pack with PowerIQ Charging Technology, 5V/3A High-Speed Charging, USB-C (In and Out) for iPhone, iPad, Samsung, Pixel, and More
description: Got this a for a long trip. Worked fantastically, just now it’s a full night to charge this to full. That’s to be expected as it’s equal to 4 1/2 battery charges for a iPhone 12. It has no MagSafe charging so a good flexible cable is recommended.

product_name: Anker Power Bank (PowerCore 10K), Compact Travel-Ready 10,000mAh Battery Pack with PowerIQ Charging Technology, 5V/3A High-Speed Charging, USB-C (In and Out) for iPhone, iPad, Samsung, Pixel, and More
description: Have you ever experienced the panic of seeing your phone battery drain to 1% while you're in the middle of a road trip or a day-long adventure? I certainly have! But fear no more, my fellow adventurers, for I have discovered the ultimate solution: the Anker Portable Charger, 313 Power Bank (PowerCore Slim 10K)!Let me share my personal experience and why this remarkable power bank has earned its spot as my trusty sidekick. As a tech enthusiast who loves exploring the great outdoors, I depend heavily on my smartphone for navigation, capturing memories, and staying connected. But as we all know, battery life can be a real buzzkill. That's where the Anker Portable Charger comes to the rescue!First and foremost, this power bank boasts a whopping 10,000mAh battery capacity, providing me with enough juice to revive my phone multiple times. It's like having a superhero's power at my fingertips! With this portable charger in my backpack, I can bid farewell to the anxiety of running out of battery power at the most inconvenient moments.What sets the Anker PowerCore Slim 10K apart from the rest is its sleek design. It's incredibly slim, compact, and lightweight, making it the perfect travel companion. Gone are the days of bulky power banks weighing down my pockets or bags. The Anker PowerCore Slim 10K slides effortlessly into any pocket, leaving me feeling light and free.Now, let's talk about charging speed. The PowerIQ Charging Technology integrated into this power bank is a game-changer. It automatically detects the device connected and delivers the fastest possible charge, ensuring that I spend less time waiting and more time enjoying my adventures. Whether I'm charging my iPhone or my Samsung Galaxy, the Anker Portable Charger handles it all with lightning speed.I must highlight the USB-C input, which provides an incredibly convenient way to recharge the power bank itself.
