Its heart rate, sleep, and activity tracking capabilities are impressive, providing detailed insights and accuracy that can help you stay on top of your health. The water resistance adds a layer of versatility, making it suitable for various activities, including swimming. The materials used in the watch feel premium, and the software experience is seamless and intuitive. Additionally, the price point offers good value for the features and performance you receive. Overall, the Series 9 is a top choice for anyone serious about fitness and health tracking.

product_name: Apple Watch Series 9 [GPS 45mm] Smartwatch with Midnight Aluminum Case with Midnight Sport Band M/L. Fitness Tracker, ECG Apps, Always-On Retina Display, Water Resistant
description: This updated version has a far superior battery and useable face area. The rose is a cute metal color and it has a very clear screen and easy-to-read icons. Mine came with the soft velcro-style strap, that is fully adjustable, so very comfortable. There are also lots of options for alternative straps available so you can dress it up, or change them out to coordinate with an outfit.Pairing this watch with my iPhone, and removing my old Apple watch was easy and seamless.

product_name: Apple Watch Series 9 [GPS 45mm] Smartwatch with Midnight Aluminum Case with Midnight Sport Band M/L. Fitness Tracker, ECG Apps, Always-On Retina Display, Water Resistant
description: I bought it to replace my Fitbit watch. Very easy to set up, charge, and program. The blood oxygen feature is not included by Apple in USA but can be used with other blood oxygen app available from third party, although I have not verified that for fact. The only change from Fitbit to Apple series 9 is that battery needs to be charged daily. Display is very sharp and sound is clear for phone conversations. I haven’t played music.

product_name: Apple Watch Series 9 [GPS 45mm] Smartwatch with Midnight Aluminum Case with Midnight Sport Band M/L. Fitness Tracker, ECG Apps, Always-On Retina Display, Water Resistant
Apple Watch Series 9 [GPS 45mm] Smartwatch with Midnight Aluminum Case with Midnight Sport Band M/L. Fitness Tracker, ECG Apps, Always-On Retina Display, Water Resistant
description: It’s sleek, stylish, and offers a range of features that are perfect for both fitness enthusiasts and everyday users. It’s bright and clear, making it easy to check the time or notifications without having to raise my wrist. The Starlight color of the case is modern and versatile, matching well with a variety of outfits and settings.Fitness tracking is accurate and comprehensive. The watch tracks workouts, heart rate, and even ECG with impressive precision. It’s been helpful for monitoring my health and keeping up with fitness goals. The water resistance is also a plus, allowing me to wear it while swimming or in the shower without worry.One minor downside is that the battery life, while decent, requires daily charging to keep up with all the features. It’s not a dealbreaker, but it’s something to be aware of if you prefer longer battery life between charges.

product_name: Apple Watch Series 9 [GPS 45mm] Smartwatch with Midnight Aluminum Case with Midnight Sport Band M/L. Fitness Tracker, ECG Apps, Always-On Retina Display, Water Resistant
description: I was like “what’s the hubbub” about these watches, Until I got one.I am one that really needs in your face reminders, and this thing reminds me by giving me a vibration so I never miss my reminders. I really like that.And I like that there’s so many different faces that you can buy you don’t have to stick to one.And I like that it’s constantly monitoring my Heart rate and exercise, how far I walk and it even remind me to stand up and stretch. I need that, it tells me how long I’ve washed my hands And gives me a vibration when I can stop. Crazy isn’t it? I don’t know I like it because I really have a hard time, remembering things.I like the fact that I can change bands whenever I want too.I guess the only thing I really don’t like about it is that I have to plug it in all the time to charge it up lol I’m used to never having to charge a watch. lolAnyway, really nice watch and definitely worth the price.

product_name: Apple Watch Series 9 [GPS 45mm] Smartwatch with Midnight Aluminum Case with Midnight Sport Band M/L. Fitness Tracker, ECG Apps, Always-On Retina Display, Water Resistant
description: I love Apple products.  This watch has a much longer battery life than my old Apple Watch gen. 4 and has a slightly larger screen.  Plus it has the always-on functionality.Great price for the Apple Watch gen. 9!

product_name: Apple Watch Series 9 [GPS 45mm] Smartwatch with Midnight Aluminum Case with Midnight Sport Band M/L. Fitness Tracker, ECG Apps, Always-On Retina Display, Water Resistant
description: Bought this series 9 to replace my series 2 that I had for three years. I needed to get a bigger face size as my tired eyes need all the help they can get while running without my reading glasses. The watch works as expected. I have an iPhone 12Pro and obviously have no issues with pairing or configuring the watch with the watch app. Battery is ok, but you definitely will not get days of battery life especially if you are exercising with the watch. There are other watches out there that may have better individual features and/or battery life, however, it is difficult for those other watches to beat the Apple watch in overall features and performance. It is for that reason that I give the Apple watch series 9 the five stars.

product_name: Apple Watch Series 9 [GPS 45mm] Smartwatch with Midnight Aluminum Case with Midnight Sport Band M/L. Fitness Tracker, ECG Apps, Always-On Retina Display, Water Resistant
description: I had to upgrade my Apple Watch from a series 3 to a series 9. So far the series 9 GPS is so much better than my series 3. It is quicker and the battery life lasts for 3 days and I wear it all day everyday. My series 3 color was black and decided to get a different color, the pink one and I love it! I have had my series 9 for a month and it is working great so far. My screen is also bigger than my series 3 and I’ve enjoyed that lot.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: I’ve only had them a couple days, bought as an economic fill in until my Bose EarPods get replaced. Set up was easy, the fit is light and comfortable. Call quality is great and tap functions are plentiful and work well. I also like that you can use left or right individually.Now the “bad”: the app doesn’t function most of the time (so far) and didn’t find the headphones when I open the app. Sound quality is ok with music, I tried a couple genres. The lows fall flat but otherwise it’s a nice sound. On a scale of 1-10 (10 being my Bose QC ultra and gen 1 AirPods being about a 4) these are about a 6.5. Additionally they do not charge wirelessly,  which I feel is an industry standard these days.I got mine for $50 (on sale?) and they’re definitely great at that price, not sure I’d feel the same at full price.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: I got these on a really good deal and figured I wasn't out much if they didn't work well.Pros:These seem to sound better to other people than my previous (more expensive) ear buds when I'm using them to answer a phonecall.The sound on playback seems to do a good job.The case is pretty compact.Cons:They are a bit hard to get out of the case. They get pulled in by a magnet so they don't shake out, but breaking the bond takes a bit and if you've got big fingers, or long fingernails, it will take a bit of work.I'm struggling with the fit in my ears.  There's a weird pressure point which seems odd since they're pretty low profile.  Must be the shape of my ears!The tips aren't very easy to exchange.  After going for a sealing version and not liking it, I put the original tips back on. Pro tip, there's a front and a back side on that set!All in all, they get the job done.  Not sure I am going to be able to wear them comfortably all day, but I'm not sad about the investment in them either.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: I bought these headphones to replace another set of JBL headphones that has been put through the wash. Those headphones were the kind that "plug" into your ear, and they were exceptional. Great noise cancelation, great call quality and battery life. I loved the JBL app and i loved th headphones themselves. So when it was time to replace them, I went on amazon, typed in JBL headphones and quickly ordered this pair that were a bit more expensive, but I felt confident in the choice (the JBL brand has already won me over so I felt comfortable going with a higher priced one without much research, thinking that the cost would be representative of the level of quality, and the quality would be the same/better as the previous headphones, a pair i bought from kohls for about $30 btw)Unfortunalty In my haste, I didn't notice that these are fundamentaly different headphones than what i had before. These are the kind that "sit" in your ear rather than "plug" into them. I noticed this right away once they arrived and was disappointed....my fault for not making sure, but still. Here i was. I found myself in a predicament. I needed to keep headphones since I was about to board a plane for a vacation, but these weren't the ones I wanted! And they are kinda pricey. Ugh. I decided to keep them and give them a shot. I tried all the different size fittings and found some that worked-ish. Now it's about 3 weeks later and I'm here writing a review.Ultimately the headphones have a good quality feel, good battery life, etc. And im sure they compete with the other major brands and outperform them for the price. But to me, these and just not good headphones. And I postulate that this design is just plain inferior to the "plug" in kind in every regard.These never really feel like they are secure in the ear, they don't seal in the ear to create rich deep bass and smooth mids. When there is even the slightest breeze the wind catches them and sends a blast of whistling noise in through the edge of the earbud. And most dissapointing to me,the active noise cancelation doesn't seem to do diddly squat. On my other pair. The difference of turning ANC on/off was night and day. They really blocked out the sound!. On these, there's hardly a difference. Certainly not enough to justify wasting battery life on the feature.Ultimately these may be fine for you if you know for a fact you like this style, but my opinion is these are, and always will be an inferior style of headphone. And I regret not returning these. Be sure to check that this is the style you want and In my case, they may "accidentily" make their way in the washing machine sooner than later.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: Bought to replace my previously owned model the JBL Tune 230NC that I think jumped out of my pocket at a gas station one evening. I hope someone found them and got some use out of them but probably just got run over and thrown away. In my estimation this JBL Tune Flex model is inferior to those earlier ones in every way except for lightness and battery life. On their own merits they are decent non-apple airpods. Get them for an upgrade from stock hardware you may have. If you don't have anything to compare them to they're an ok all around performer. Compared to all the other JBL earbuds I've had over the last 10+ years these have the worst audio, surprisingly so. Really missing that good bass I've become accustomed to. Microphone pickup is ok for calls but aggressively cuts off quieter sounds. They feel fussy and prone to accidental touch input. Even the case is fussy and oddly sharp. At time of writing these are half the price of the earlier model and I can see why. Take some time to make sure these are properly fitted and use the JBL app to dial in the audio especially if you're getting these for music or video.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: Handy, they hold the charge quite well, and the charging case also holds its charge for a long time. I did have trouble getting them to stay in my ears, though. The fit is not snug, and I've tried all the different sized attachments. It's like they have powder or something that keeps them sliding out. (There is no powder of course, but that's what they feel like to my ears.) There's an app you can use that is supposed to help you figure out the best size for your ears, but I don't have the patience to do that, I just tried all the sizes and kept having trouble with them staying in no matter what, especially the left ear. Never had that problem with ear buds before.UPDATE: I've tried all three sets of earbuds that come with them and none of them are snug in my ear. They are elliptical shaped, not round like most. That is a cool look I suppose, but apparently not designed for fit. They just don't stay in my left ear for whatever reason. I tried other attachments from another set which fit normally, but I can't close the charging case because they stick out. Should have returned them long ago. Again, sound is good, noise cancelling is good, they hold the charge well. They just refuse to stay in my ear

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: These do not have the bass I was expecting. They also are not anywhere near loud enough. The noise cancelling feature is not noticable to me at all. I can still hear a bunch of outside noise whether noise canceling is on it off.Lastly the fit is not good for me at all. They constantly fall out of my ears. They are very touchy. I'm constantly having to adjust them so they stay in my ears and that just triggers the settings each time I have to touch them.Very average earbuds so for JBL's these are disappointing. The price slash of 50% to $50 is still overpriced for these earbuds in my opinion.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: I purchased these to replace my Airpods (2nd gen) which quit working. I generally stay far away from Apple products but I had Airpods because they sound good and they stay in my ears without the suction/ear plug tip. Since I am loathe to buy another Apple product I looked for a similar product.Pros:-Similar shape to Airpods-App to adjust settings/preferences works with Android (unlike Airpods)-Sounds pretty good to me but I'm not an audiophile and mostly listen to audiobooks-Nice options for choosing touch gestures-Good battery life-Uses USB CCons:-Case is the same style as Airpods and it's a bad design, hard to open and get them out with one hand. Also it feels a little chintzy compared to Airpods-They are a little bit bigger than the Airpods, which for me is a con-They are more touch sensitive for gesture controls than Airpods which can be annoying-When you pause with gesture controls there is a excessively long delay before it actually pauses, which is hard to get used to. This was not a problem with my AirpodsAll in all, they are pretty ok, but not great.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: Overall the quality of these headphones are decent especially for the price. The sound is good the bass is amazing, but the charging design for these is just plain bad. The little charging port in the headphones constantly gets clogged, so I have to get gunk out of them all the time but after a while the dirt and stuff in there prohibited me from being able to charge them, and unfortunately the customer service from jbl is terrible. I called them twice to get the warranty activated (which the warranty is actually amazing they said they would completely replace them for free) but they said they’d send me an email after 48 hours and I never got an email on two occasions.Overall save your money and buy a better quality longer lasting product unless you want to change headphones every two months.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: My specific device is probably a lemon. I’ve had it for a few months now, and I’ve had a persistent problem with the left earbud connecting to the case’s battery to charge. It doesn’t sit well within the socket, and bc it doesn’t identify the connection, it stays connected to my phone. I lose my place when listening to music/podcasts, and more importantly the battery does not charge. The left earbud dies quickly, doesn’t connect to the charger, doesn’t disconnect from the phone, and won’t reconnect to the phone when coming out of sleep mode. The worst part is that I haven’t found a customer/technical support for the device, so I haven’t been able to fix what could be a simple problem.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: AS STATED ABOVE.....WHILE THESE ARE GOOD EARBUDS.....THEY WILL NOT PAIR WITH MORE THAN ONE DEVICE.....THAT IS WHY I RETURNED THEM.....THEY WORK GOOD IF YOU ONLY NEED THEM FOR ONE PHONE.....I HAVE TWO PHONES AND IT IS IMPORTANT THAT I CAN USE EITHER PHONE WITH EARBUDS WHEN NEEDED.....THESE CANNOT DO THAT.....YOU CAN ONLY PAIR THEM WITH ONE PHONE.....WHICH MEANS YOU CAN ONLY USE THEM WITH ONE PHONE.....WHEN YOU TAKE THE EARBUDS OUT OF THE CASE.....THEY AUTO CONNECT.....WHICH MEANS.....YOU HAVE TO DELETE THEM FROM ONE PHONE.....THEN RE-PAIR THEM.....BEFORE YOU CAN USE THEM WITH ANOTHER PHONE.....B-T-W.....THE AP IS USELESS.....MOST OF THE TIME IS SAYS THAT IT CANNOT LOCATE THE EARBUDS (WHILE I HAVE THEM IN MY EARS).....

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: I bought these for my dad because I was tired of him always having me on speaker. I was iffy because they were on sale, and the reviews were mixed. I'm not sure what they were talking about because the battery life is crazy long for both case and the buds. The sound quality is clear. The mic works very well although it does pickup background noise. Overall, great value for the price. I can't get him off the phone now that he has them!

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: Update after 5 months of use:A quick update of the ear buds.  The charging of the ear buds is fast.  Going from "low battery" to full takes a short amount of time.  I think a minute or two.  Never timed it.A couple of issues:* Taking calls on it is hit or miss.  Often the headphones will get out of sync and it will do a weird binaural thing where it will alternate between each ear getting cut out for a split second back and forth for about two seconds.  This can happen multiple times in a minute.* Over a bit of time of playback, the earphones will cut out for about 2-3 seconds.  I'm not sure why.  Maybe some sort of sync issue?  More annoying when listening to an audio book than music.Original Review:This review is for:  JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (White), SmallOverall, I like them.  Video mode has no audio lag.  They sound good with boosted base and sealed tips.I really wish there was a way to turn on the headphones without the case.Highs:* When using to go to sleep, the pillow won't accidently activate the touch controls (very nice).* Touch controls are responsive and are easy to activate.  I haven't had them accidently double activate so far.* Video mode has no audio/video lag.  Must be enabled in the app.  By default it is set to Music mode.* Good sound.  They sound very good when using the bass EQ, music mode, and the sealed tips.* Fit is good.  Three sizes for sealed tips.* Can setup each touch control to a different command set.* Important! : If you want volume control, it must be setup in the app.* Has a "find earphones" function (only when still turned on).  Emits a tone and is easy to hear.* Has an optional auto standby which also optionally deactivates ANC.  For example: With some other earphones, ANC will stay on even with auto standby enabled.  If using them to sleep to, ANC being on all the time will cause the battery to be low by morning.* Good Bluetooth range.Lows:* Hard to get out of the case.  This seems to be common with all case based small headphones.  There isn't a good way to grip them and they won't shake out.* When getting out of the case, it's easy to activate the touch controls over and over.  (Skip, play, pause, volume up.)* No way to turn on the earphones without the case.  Not even with the app.  Cannot force standby either.* This means that if you forget the case, you can't put them in your pocket because the touch controls fire randomly.  The app can turn off the earphones.*  Couldn't tell a difference between ANC on or off.  With or without the sealed tips.  But I was not really surprised for small in ear headphones.Other:To put on or take off the tips, use a credit card or spudger to separate the white tips from the body.  The sealed tips are easy to add and remove.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: The JBL Tune Flex earbuds offer excellent sound quality and a comfortable fit, making them a fantastic choice for everyday use. The bass is punchy, the mids are clear, and they handle various genres of music really well. They’re lightweight, and the battery life is impressive, lasting through long listening sessions without needing constant recharging.The noise-canceling feature is decent, but not as strong as I expected, especially in noisier environments. While it does a good job at reducing background noise, it doesn't completely block out distractions like higher-end models.That said, for the price point, these earbuds deliver great value with solid performance and convenience. A bit more refinement in the noise-cancellation department, and they'd easily be a 5-star product!

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: Got these on sale for $50. For that price, they’re worth it; definitely not worth the original price though.Pros:- sound quality: a little hollow sounding, but good enough for casual listening and workouts. Noise cancellation is OK.- set up was seamless- convenient portability- quality of plastics seems good, but they’re no Apple productMisc: the app seems alright so far. It’s nice to have some customizability. Definitely check the audio | video playback option out. When watching videos on audio mode, there’s a noticeable sync issue between the video and the sound. But switching to video mode makes it go away.Overall thoughts: after a few days of usage, I’ll keep them. Hoping they last more than 6 months though like the last pair.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: I got it on Prime Deal Day so it was almost half off the original price - and I’m SO glad I got it. Can’t say for sure yet if it’s worth full price. I lost my Apple AirPods and decided to look for an alternative since AirPods are simply too expensive. These came fully charged straight out of the box so I tested them right away. The sound quality will blow you away, literally. The bass is incredible considering these are earbuds and not over-ear headphones. There’s an app you can download that will allow you to customize the level of noise cancellation, an equalizer, etc, and also has a “Find my Buds” that will ping each earbud individually in case you lose them in a couch cushion or something. Ive seen complaints about the charging case, but I haven’t had them long enough to give my opinion. I’ve only had these for one day and I’m super impressed so far, so we’ll see.Will update this review if anything changes.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: I bought these JBL Tune Flexes as a replacement for a pair of JBL Vibe Flexes I lost.  There are more options on it than the Vibe Flex, which are nice.  The noise cancelling is not that effective with the open ear bud tips in.  They might work better with the isolation tips.  But I generally don't like isolation tips.They stay in my ear pretty well, and they have good sound.The touch controls are a little "touchy," in that they activate when I don't intend to activate them.  I deducted one star for that.  Other than that, they have been a good pair of ear buds.  Certainly a good value when I found them on sale.Battery life is good.  I can listen just about all day at work before charging from the case.  I haven't figured out how long the case battery lasts.  I recharge it maybe once a week.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: Only Con:Getting the ear buds out of the case is sometimes like playing a claw machine; the way they sit in the case + smoothness of the ear buds themselves makes them come out of the slot(s) but then slip out of your fingers and the magnets pull them back into place -- positive note: magnets are STRONG, so no worries about the ear buds falling out of the case.The Pros:It has an app to customize the sound, function(s) of taps and for each ear buds, noise cancellation type, and even locating a missing ear bud when misplaced.The sound quality is fantastic. I chose these for the old-school ear bud design (not the plug) even though it also comes with a tiny case for plugs to switch out (for your liking and ear fitting).Charging and connectivity is fast and the battery life is amazing. One charge lasts me at least a week (about 5 hours of use a day).Highly recommend!

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: The fit took a little getting used to, it's fine until I run or have to move my head as if looking between papers and a screen or something. The sound quality is pretty good for what it is and I really like the battery life that I've gotten so far. There are a few things that I don't care for though.  I'm not sure if there's a setting to change it, but anytime there's wind or air movement the earbuds make a crackling sound. Not sure if they're trying to cancel that noise out or what, but I work in a machine shop so we use air guns quite a bit and it's less than desirable. The other thing is that after five months or so the right earbud stopped charging. I've cleaned the contacts on the earbud itself as well as the contact in the case but still can't get it to charge, so now I just have one functioning earbud. I usually only have one in anyway, but I liked to alternate between the two sides to stretch battery life a little.For the amount of money I spent on these, I definitely don't regret buying them. However, I also would not buy them again unless they were on sale or a revised version came out because of the earbud that doesn't work.

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: I love these earbuds a lot. They're comfortable in my ears and I can keep them in all day until the battery dies. I use them for work mostly and I'm working from 7:45 am to 4:30- 7:30 pm varying and they will last me until 4. The anc is great and I can't hear anything when I turn it on (the battery dies die quicker with and on), the talk through function I find really good for when I'm talking on the phone, and the awareness mode feels like I can hear clearly what someone is telling me. I'm all in all in love with these earbuds and use them all the time

product_name: JBL Tune Flex - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds (Black), Small
description: You don't know you need them until your on an airplane that has you use your,cell to listen to music or watch free Movies and you pull out,your earphones and find there's no place on the phone to plug it in....  It's EAR BUDS TIME ...

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: I recently purchased the Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger, Solar Power Bank, External Battery Pack 5V3.1A QC 3.0 Fast Charger with Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange). Initially, I was excited about the solar charging feature, which seemed perfect for outdoor activities and emergencies. The power bank itself is well-constructed and offers a substantial 42800mAh capacity, which is great for multiple charges of my devices. The fast charging capability and the built-in super bright flashlight are excellent features that add to its versatility and convenience.However, I encountered a significant drawback with the solar charging functionality. Once the power bank is completely drained, it is nearly impossible to recharge it using just solar power. While the solar panel does work, it is extremely slow and ineffective for fully recharging the large battery capacity. This limitation is quite disappointing, especially for a device marketed as a solar charger. Despite this, the power bank is still useful when charged through traditional means and offers ample power for extended use. For the price, it provides good value, but the solar charging aspect falls short of expectations. Therefore, I would rate it 3 stars. It’s a nice backup option for outdoor use, but don’t rely solely on solar power for recharging.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: Solar Power Bank Charger had 3 bars or 50-75 percent charge out of the box.  It was used to charge a phone and tablet to get it down to 2 bars.  Charged a Ipad Pro 10.5 from 40 percent to 100 percent and a Iphone SE3 from 60 percent to 100 percent.  Unit was later set outside for a couple of hours in direct sunlight on a 22 degree afternoon.  Not sure if 3 days worth of direct sun exposure would have increased the charge to a third bar. Maybe best to use the solar feature on a fully charged battery to keep it topped off.  As for solar charging a smartphone, maybe an hour or two would be sufficient  to get a 1 to 3 percent charge.Unit was later fully discharged and then charged with a fast charger.  It was plugged into the fast charger at 7:00pm and left to fully charge throughout the night.  By 5:00am, it was charged.This 42,800mAh device has some heft to it.  Solar Power Bank Charger was set between a 21,000mAh  Jump Starter and a Jackery 10,400mAh USB charger to compare its size to the others.  That is an old Iphone 8 sitting next to the Solar Power Bank Charger in the picture.The flash light feature is adequate.  I bought my mom the same device after trying mine out.1-21-24My Power-Bank-Solar-Charger suffered a 2 ft drop by accident onto a hard surface.  Everything is still functioning but it now has something rattling inside of it.  I question the shockproof and rigidness of this unit.5-02-24Some people are questioning the battery capacity of this Power-Bank-Solar-Charger.  TOPDON or equivalent Battery Booster Jump Starter Pack might be a better choice.  Some of them like the one in the picture come with a 12V Cigarette Lighter Socket Adapter.  You can buy one for the TOPDON on Amazon.  If you have cordless power tools, a USB charger that mates to your power tool battery would give you more battery capacitance options.  Some of the multi-functional power adapters have a 12V 3 amp output and others have the option to connect a 12V Cigarette Lighter Socket Adapter to them.5-11-24Connected a KYY 15.6 inch portable monitor and a Roku Streaming Stick 4K to the Power-Bank-Solar-Charger to show off the portable monitor to my mom.  She needs a portable monitor to travel with for her business.  I only had the devices connected to the power bank for maybe 15 minutes.  It managed to keep both devices powered.  I am not sure for how long though.10-18-2024I recommend a ELECOM NESTOUT Portable Solar Panel to pair with this.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: So this works fairly well, however, it takes an excessively long time to charge to full. It basically needs about 20-25 hours of direct sunlight (so at minimum 2-3 days) to charge to full from 0 battery.I wasn’t able to give it the full direct sun test, averaging about 6-7 hours of direct sunlight over 3 days and it took about 30-32 hours. So I’m guessing if you check on it constantly and keep it out of shade for a solid 2 days you may be able to charge it to full.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: So far as a battery pack with solar charging functionality, this products work well. However, I would caution that even though the product look like it’s fairly rugged and possibly water resistant this is not the case. I did not purposely try to test this however I accidentally left it out during a very late event for about half an hour without remembering it. When I went to go retrieve it, however water had worked in all around the solar panel and the product internally was full of water again I do not believe in the details it state is water resistant or waterproof or anything however, looking at it you might think that it is. So I would just like to caution that it is not. I do not test it and do not expect it other than that as a charger with solar charging functionality has been a great product , I’m not sure if this will work after being left out in the rain and this is not a negative reflection although the appearance might lead some believe it might have some tiny bit of water resistance so I just wanted to warn everyone.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: When charged up for 2 days with 120 volt, it kept a string of lights lit for over 5 hours. But, on solar it would not keep the same string of lights lit for an hour after being pointed toward the sun all day. So, good if you can charge it with something other than the sun, which is maybe the whole point?

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: Pros/likes:Charges 2 devices at onceFlashlightFunctions as intendedCons/dislikes:BulkySolar charging is just a gimmickAdvertised as $299 on sale for $29Unable to speak to longevity yet, may update my review later

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: The as was misleading.  It shows two chargers.  We are preparing for a hurricane and we really wanted two for our single daughter with two kids.  When it arrived there was only 1 and I do not have time to get another to her.  Please change the photo!

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: Solar recharging does not work.  Looking at other reviews sounds like this is common problem.  If you buy this - it is only worth about $20.-$30.  It does charge your phone, just the solar doesn't work.  Though once it charges phone to about 80% it turns off.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: It works as described. I think the manufacturers can think of putting built-in cables. It would make it so much more functional. We know we’re buying the solar and not really going to get that much out of it. We know we’re buying it for the amount of power it can hold. That aside, it works. The light is bright.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: I like the idea behind it. It does actually fully charge with the solar panel only, but it is larger than I was expecting. More like the size of a 5x9 picture, not the size of a cell phone. I know the larger size means it can hold more of a charge but it's almost too big and bulky to keep in my bag.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: This charger can charge my iPhone 15 multiple times before having to recharge it. Only drawback is charging it the sun can take two days before it’s fully charged again. Great value. Built with hard sturdy plastic so it can take drops without falling apart. Bulky fit. And weighs more than most.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: The built-in solar panel is a standout feature. While it’s not the fastest way to charge the power bank, it’s incredibly useful in emergencies or when you're off the grid. Under full sunlight, the solar charging is reasonably effective, but it's important to manage expectations—fully charging the battery using solar alone takes a significant amount of time. It works best as a supplementary charging method rather than the primary one.This power bank can charge a typical smartphone up to six times before needing a recharge. It has two USB output ports, which is convenient for charging multiple devices simultaneously. The charging speed is impressive when using a wall outlet, taking about 6-7 hours to fully charge. The USB-C input/output port is a great addition, providing faster charging for compatible devices.The SunCharger Pro comes with a built-in LED flashlight, which has proven handy during camping trips and power outages. There are three modes: steady, SOS, and strobe. Another practical feature is the battery indicator lights that show how much charge is left, so you're never caught off guard with a dead power bank.- Durable, water-resistant, and dustproof design- Solar charging option for emergencies- Dual USB ports for simultaneous charging- Built-in LED flashlight with multiple modes- USB-C input/output for faster charging- Solar charging is slow and should be considered supplementary- Slightly bulky compared to non-solar power banks- Takes considerable time to charge via solar fully Solar Power Bank is an excellent choice for outdoor enthusiasts and those who need a reliable backup power source. Its rugged design, high capacity, and additional features like the solar panel and LED flashlight make it versatile and dependable. While the solar charging is a bit slow, it's a valuable feature for emergencies. For its price point, this power bank offers great value and peace of mind for anyone needing extra power on the go.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: We have another one of these and do love it. It is a great accessory for rafting or camping or other outdoor adventures.We have had it for a while now and it still works perfectly. I like that you can plug in a few for rent things and charge it at the same time. It lasts for a while. We just plug in what we used up that day and everything is fully charged the next morning for the day. However, this new one wasn’t charging in the sun so we are returning. It is a little heavy so not something you’d want if you’re carrying your stuff for long periods of this.Also, I don’t think it is 100% waterproof so we have to be careful with it. But it is good for the price compared to other ones.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: This is great because you can charge two things at once. It’s great especially during power outages. It’s water proof and durable. It is bulky and a little heavier than I thought but worth the money. It holds a charge for a long period of time. It also comes wih a belt clip. The flashlight is very bright. I would recommend this item. Great for camping and any outdoor adventures.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: The bank is able to power two phones simultaneously.  I haven't tried to drain the battery completely yet, but I have had 3 hours of charging and the battery only depleated 25%.  Of note, this is not a fast charger.  It may work for some people, but I was unable to get the product to fast charge my phone.Very sturdy, feels like it can be dropped without it being affected.  I will update the review as more experiences come.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: I originally bought this for hurricane season and I use it for the theme parks. I loved how it was solar powered, a flash light, and has 2 charge ports. The battery life is real lengthy and keeps my phone charged when I need it, and the battery stays charged up from the solar panel. The orange color is a bright safety orange so it’s easy to see, it’s compact and easy to carry with clip it came with, and overall it’s a great quality battery for the money.⭐️10/10 recommend⭐️

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: This is a very well made, well-designed battery bank.  The solar panel charges easily the battery, but one can also charge from the wall.  The unit has a built-in flashlight, which is not super bright, but is very functional.  It has USB-A X2, and USB-C x2, the ports of which can be covered by a rubber insert. This will get a lot of use from me!

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: I bought this mostly based on price, but also because the solar component is promising given that I sometimes am in asture environments.  The first thing I'll say is that this charger is pretty big and very heavy.  It's OK for a base camp, but I don't think I'd want to lug it around.  There are much smaller and lighter battery packs to keep in a pack or pocket.That said, as a means to recharge your phone or one of the smaller battery packs, this device may be a good choice.  After receiving it, I first charged it to full capacity (4 indicator lights).  Water that, I left it near a window and used it exclusively to recharge my Galaxy S21 from 5% or less back up to full strength.  I charged whenever the pho e was at or below 5%, regardless of daylight vs after hours.  I also charged my wristwatch with it.  I got 5 full phone charges and 2 full watch charges before the charger ran dry.  This took close to a week.  Once it was plugged back in, it charged to full in about 3 hours and we did it again.I have not yet evaluated how rapidly it will recharge itself using only solar power, but most are pretty slow.  I imagine that if you use the charger mostly for top offs and the use solar to top off the charger, you'll get the most usefulness out of the charger.  I'll experiment and find out.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: I think this is a great product overall. I keep it in my backpack to charge my phone when I'm out. It lasts quite a while without charging. I also found the flashlight handier than expected. One thing to note, it is quite bulky. an outer pocket of a backpack can hold it but if you want to walk around with it, you'll need big pockets. The main issue I have is how little the solar panel actually charges. I don't think putting it on a windowsill is very effective. But also inside I can just plug it in so it's not a big deal.

product_name: Power-Bank-Solar-Charger - 42800mAh Portable Charger,Solar Power Bank,External Battery Pack 5V3.1A Qc 3.0 Fast Charger Built-in Super Bright Flashlight (Orange)
description: During Hurricane Helene, I was without power for four days. It managed to charge my phone for two of the four days that I used it, although it possibly might have lasted longer if I hadn't used the flash light so frequently at night.The solar power bank's slowness is its main disadvantage. Despite setting it outside in direct sunshine early in the morning, only one LED light had been recharged at the end of the day. The fact that there are four LED light indicators and that I can always recharge to three of them but it seems to take forever to charge to the fourth is another drawback.

product_name: Amazon Kindle Scribe (16 GB) - 10.2” 300 ppi Paperwhite display, a Kindle and a notebook all in one, convert notes to text and share, includes Basic Pen
description: TLDR: The basic reading functionality is very good.  The pen isn't that useful.  Software is still pretty limited if you don't want to use reading glasses.My last kindle device was a kindle DX (yes the giant one that was released more than 10 years ago).  I gave up waiting for Amazon to release something that amazing and went with the scribe. The screen is very paper like, the resolution is crisp enough that letters look very good and readable.  The page turning speed if very nice.  The actual feel of the pen writing on the screen is very much like pencil on paper, this part was very unexpected and pleasant experience.  Finally, it's a good weight for hold and reading for extended periods of time.Here's where all the complaining begins.  This device is pretty expensive for what it is and it's not like this is Amazon's first kindle product so I believe these complaints are justified.1. You can't use the pen to write on most books.  None of the books I would want to write on can be written on.  Since the pen is kind of the marquee feature of the scribe this is very a surprising limitation.  Why would one want to do this and not leave a note:  a.  The notes are represented as little dots to tap on and aren't really read in-line with the book.  b. Some books like cook books are basically meant for you to personalize.  Like cross out which ingredients you already have when making a shopping list.  Notes on taste.  Variants you want to try. c. You have different types of notes you want to make (e.g. TODO vs idea notes) and you won't be able to see this unless you expand the notes.2. It's 2024 and presumably Amazon still has software engineers in its employ so that they can make small changes like...changing the font size of the non-book part of the display.  The most obvious fail in this issue is that the dictionary is still at the default font size regardless of the size chosen for the book.  I don't know about most people that use the feature, but it's a big selling point that I don't need to use reading glasses to read books on the Kindle: I can just make the font size larger.  This limitation is even more perplexing when you are browsing the kindle store on the device where everything is rendered in a tiny font.  It's like they don't want me to be able to discover new books on the device and buy them.  Which brings me to.3.  The kindle store is integrated into the home page, but I often don't care about the categories that are displayed.  I want to go to the store and shop it like the regular amazon site like as if I want to shop and buy something.  In the ancient DX there was a menu item to just do this.  Again this is a perplexing move as if amazon is not interested in acquiring more of my money.4. One side of the device has slightly more bezel than the other side.  This should be side side you use to hold the device.  It's just the right side for my big thumbs.  Great.  Oh wait I just shutoff the device.  They put the power button in the middle of the side where the device is held for reading.  There are three other sides to the device (if you don't count the front and the back) that could be chosen for this functionality. Three sides where this wouldn't matter.  Three of them.

product_name: Amazon Kindle Scribe (16 GB) - 10.2” 300 ppi Paperwhite display, a Kindle and a notebook all in one, convert notes to text and share, includes Basic Pen
description: I was soooooo excited when I was gifted this Scribe. It does have a larger screen, and a wide margin for holding the device whilst reading.I am disappointed though. I looked forward to making notes on the pages of books I have purchased. Not a note that is viewed separately. The underlining and highlighting are the same as in previous Kindles.The notebooks are okay. The pen is good. I appreciate the eraser function. I downloaded several of the notebooks available, such as the Gratitude Journal and puzzle book.My expectations were too high. I have several journaling books on my Kindle, as well as “how to draw” and lettering books. Unfortunately, I had envisioned being able to write and draw directly on their pages. Yes, I can create a notebook, but then I don’t have the book content immediately available unless I use another device. For the price, I’m not impressed.Perhaps I am spoiled because I have an iPad Pro. Unfortunately, the Kindle app doesn’t allow writing on the pages of the books either. I can’t import the Kindle files into my Notebook apps the way I can with pdfs.That might seem picky. I knew it didn’t have the colour screen like the Kobo Libra or the Pocketbook Era. None of the e-readers seem to have the ability to write directly on the pages. I do appreciate the fact that we can import pdf files into the Scribe Notebook section and scribble to my heart’s content.So, I guess my expectations were too high for the e-ink technology and the proprietary format of the Kindle books.Other than that, I LOVE the larger screen. I’m glad they brought the larger screen size back. I wish the power button was on the back, or top edge because I keep inadvertently hitting it.I do have a couple of covers for my Scribe, though I am constantly taking it out because it simply gets too heavy if I’m reading for more than a few minutes.I do like my Scribe. It is an improvement on the Kindle Paperwhite, which was an improvement on the original Kindle. I chose to continue with the Kindle Brand, after purchasing the first Kindle AND early Kobo.My eyes appreciate the e-ink format. As I age and my eyesight worsens, this works much better than the iPad/tablet screens.I just hope Amazon gets innovative and improves the technology.You can listen to audiobooks with Bluetooth headphones, which is a decent option. I haven’t tried listening to an audiobook and using the notebook function.It isn’t waterproof, which should be standard at this point. I’ve never read in the tub or near water, but I am a bit klutzy with my beverages, so the added security would be nice.I did receive the “premium” pen. It does write well and has an eraser function, as well a a button that can be programmed with different options (one at a time). It doesn’t seem pressure sensitive. I suspect that is an issue with the screen technology. I have yet to try converting hand-writing to text.So, it is an upgrade from the Paperwhite, mainly for screen size and limited notebooks with a pen for writing.

product_name: Amazon Kindle Scribe (16 GB) - 10.2” 300 ppi Paperwhite display, a Kindle and a notebook all in one, convert notes to text and share, includes Basic Pen
description: I have been eyeing the Scribe for a while and jumped at the chance to get one with the current sale ($279 - 32 GB plus Pencil Pro). These are my first impressions, and I will update them as I spend more time exploring the features. I also found many reviews outdated, not reflecting the newest software upgrades. *This review is not yet complete, but I wanted to share my initial impressions. Stay tuned for updates.*### My Reasons for Getting a Scribe:1. Reduce eye strain and prevent disruption of sleep from reading other devices at night.2. Consolidate all my books and notes into one lightweight, portable device with dependable battery life.3. Reduce distractions such as notifications, web browsing, memes, etc., which tend to derail my reading or journaling when I use my iPad.### Kindle Tablet vs. Kindle AppI would also like to note the different features exclusive to the Kindle Scribe vs. the features available on the Kindle App on any tablet, like an iPad. This is important for me to determine if I really need the Scribe or if any tablet where I can download the Kindle app would suffice.### Opening the Box, Writing, & First Impressions:#### Look and Feel of the Device:- My thumb hurts from holding the Kindle, as the charging port is right where I tend to hold the device. It’s a very impractical place to put the charging port, and why is it so sharp? (May Update: this has been solved by using a case)- The device isn’t particularly aesthetically pleasing. It’s black, and the side holding piece looks unattractive, although it is a very helpful feature. (May Update: Apparently they sell stickers for these things were you can cover the black part, front and back. I have not tried the stickers yet)- The pencil locks in place on the side, but it falls off easily when I transport the Kindle from one room to another. (I still need to get a case.) (May Updated: Solved with the case)- The eraser feature is awesome! It feels very natural to use the pencil. I love it. (May Update: still love it)- The highlight (or extra feature) button is a good addition, but it’s a bit out of reach and doesn’t feel as ergonomic or easy to switch as the eraser feature. (May Update: getting used to it)- The fountain pen feature makes my writing look pretty amazing, if I say so myself! (May Update: love!)- The big screen is fantastic! It’s just like reading a book. I have the Kindle Paperwhite, which is very portable, but I tend to set the text at a very large size, so I can’t read much on one page with the Paperwhite. The Scribe fits more content.#### Writing Feel:- I LOVE the feel of writing! If you check my past reviews, I have returned notebooks because the paper was scratchy, thin, or deficient in some way for my level of sensitivity. Not with the Kindle Scribe. I love how it feels; the experience is very elegant and motivates me to keep writing. I also have an iPad with a pencil, which I use a lot, but I really dislike the feeling of writing on such a smooth, glass-like surface.### Evaluating Reasons:Evaluating how it meets my reasons for getting a Scribe (vs. my iPad, iPhone, or another device):1. **Eye Strain:** The device DOES reduce eye strain. It is a very different experience than reading on a tablet. I like how you can set up the Scribe to automatically adjust the brightness and warmth depending on the environment.2. **Eliminating Disruption of Sleep:** This has not yet been accomplished, as I find holding the Scribe is not very comfortable, especially with the sharp charging port. It is maybe a tad too big/unwieldy for holding with one hand. So, I am still using a tablet and waiting for the arrival of my Scribe cover to see if this makes it more comfortable to hold while in bed. (May Update: This has been solved with using a case, propping it using the case and using dark mode at night, I love reading at night with this thing, now the problem is trying to NOT get TOO interested in the book :)  )Well, this is it for now. I have BIG gripes about the distractions, notes features, and clunkiness of the software both on the Scribe and Amazon Content and Devices page. I will continue my update in the next few days.### May Update:3. ** Notes: Well this took me a while to figure out.My best advice is to make a list of what are the top must haves for your use.  I looked at so many YouTube videos, read reviews, etc. The Scribe is compared in these reviews to the Supernote or the Remarkable, or Boox, iPad, etc), except for me, the #1 consideration is PRICE.  If I could spend $600 - $1000 for these devices, I would listen to the reviews, maybe go with the latest Boox, but, at the sale price of the Scribe, it is in my range, so I do not expect it t have all the features of a $1,000 device like an iPad.For  my purpose of "2. Consolidate all my books and notes into one lightweight, portable device with dependable battery life." it has served me well enough within a price I could afford. Could it be better, have more features, the software do more, be more user friendly, YES! But it is what it is. I am happy with the features at the sale price point.  I would not spend $350 for the Scribe though.Now for the notes:- You have Kindle books and PDFs in your Library and your Kindle Notebooks, well in the Notebooks section.Here is how they differ:- Kindle books - with "sticky note" technology. You can place a sticky note and write on the sticky note and then email the notes to yourself.  You cannot annotate directly on the book.- Kindle books - with NO "sticky note" technology. Besides the usual Kindle features you would find in another Kindle, the Scribe wont do anything special in these books.- PDFs - You can directly write on the PDFs! Yay! You can then email these notes to yourself. It seems you cannot sync or maybe even view these notes in other kindle devices, but I have not tried that feature.On the Notebook section:- Here you have your Kindle Notebooks. Just choose a template and write. You can do basic writing and there is templates for lined, dot, grid, monthly, weekly, daily schedules, blank, etc. You can only have ONE template per notebook. So you cannot have a cover page that is blank, and the second page be lined, etc.Again, the features are basic, if you have used iPad or Notability, Goodnotes, etc, the Scribe does not have all the bells and whistles. I think the latest update the fanciest it gets is a "lasso" to copy and paste your text and the ability to add folders. You can email these notebooks for yourself. You cannot edit them in other Kindle devices.OK, so this is current to the current software update. I hope Amazon adds more features, especially the ability to straighten the highlighting!  I am still new to this device.### Conclusion:For now, for my purposes, my budget, the ease on my eyes, ability to use while I sleep, hold all my books (Kindle and PDFs), to read the books with ease on a large screen and the basic writing abilities are enough to be content with this device.  If you have a larger budget or are looking for different features, this may feel to limited of a device.

product_name: Amazon Kindle Scribe (16 GB) - 10.2” 300 ppi Paperwhite display, a Kindle and a notebook all in one, convert notes to text and share, includes Basic Pen
description: TLDR: snazzy, but it really doesn’t bring anything much new to the table and what it does bring you’ll tear your hair out trying to figure out,i just bought a new scribe and it actually arrived on prime day.  my initial reaction is good, but more and more things keep cropping up that make me seriously consider returning it.pros: as i said, it looks and feels nice right out of the box and i was happy to see i could immediately make a notebook and export it to my ipad books, where i could make screenshots of it and save them to my icloud photos so i can do whatever i want with them. that’s all good (and wasn’t really made clear in the verbiage on the listing.  in their scramble to mask any cons, they forget to push the pros! ) buuuut, i could already do all that without the imposition of the scribe, really, just using the apps pretty native to my ipad in the first place.cons: there are a lot.  yes,  you can make a doodle (see picture) but only in the notebooks, not in books themselves. apparently this includes their supposed sticky notes, you can’t put them in your books! books are where you’d want them, but no, only the same old typed notes just like my other kindle applications made.  wtf?pros:  it’s light and thin and i was looking forward to at last not having to use a case since it seldom, if ever would be leaving my house.cons: buuuut, you kinda hafta anyway? because in the less than 24 hours i’ve had it i’ve lost the pen three times. the magnets that hold it on don’t really, they’re so weak, making the premium pen even more elusive than crochet hooks. and speaking of that premium pen…pros: yes, there are different writing implements, buuuut…cons: you can only access them by getting out of what you were doing and mapping the implement to the button on the pen, which you then have to keep holding in while you’re using it. it’s not that hard to hold it in, unless you want some variation in your writing, of course, but that doesn’t really matter because its not pressure sensitive anyway and, oh yeah, the fountain pen is italic. ONLY italic, and you can’t vary the line thickness on any of the implements, including the italic fountain pen, so whether you like that line you see in my picture or not, that’s what you get,  (hint: amazon, thinner lines would facilitate usefulness of the tiny stickies that we can’t put in books.)pros: i got the scribe, and some headphones to go with it, precisely so i could listen to audiobooks and write or draw (what they call doodling, possibly because drawing sounds too intimidating?) sounded great.cons:  only you can’t do that.  you can draw in a notebook, OR you cam listen to audiobooks, but not both at once.  so there’s absolutely no audiobook advantage to the scribe at all that i can see. i already listen to audiobooks externally while i’m working, and i’ll have to continue to do so, and return the unnecessary headphones…not to mention that it couldn’t find my audible library.  (!)  all ready to have me buy new ones, sure, but the 600+ audiobooks books already in my audible library? were nowhere to be found.  i called amazon customer service and was told, among other things, that you can’t listen to audible books outside of the audible app, which is simply untrue (where do they get these people, mars?). i kept on pushing and they kept trying to transfer me back to the same clueless audible person until finally i screamed so loud they gave me to somebody in the kindle unit (honestly people, was that so hard?) who said it was a known issue, that the library wasn’t working and that to get to my library i would have to go to the website and send it to the scribe, only it’s  not called the scribe there but something like “my 347th kindle”.  which, of course, takes the scribe out of the loop altogether, other than as another dumb terminal. (when i looked a few hours later all my audiobooks were there in my audible library, so why didn’t they just say it would take some time to populate? morons.)why did i buy this?  it doesn’t do anything i haven’t already been doing on my ipad for years, and not nearly half as well.  the only actual advantage i can see is it’s nice for reading and the pen doesn’t slide around on the screen.  so why am i not sending it back immediately?  well…i like it. it does look nice. and i still hope it might tempt me to read more, i can give it a bit more time to see if i even use it much. and i’m a sucker.now let’s see if they publish this.

product_name: Amazon Kindle Scribe (16 GB) - 10.2” 300 ppi Paperwhite display, a Kindle and a notebook all in one, convert notes to text and share, includes Basic Pen
description: + Best hardware for the money+ Warmth and brightness sliders for the back light+ Pen requires no batteries, is light, and writes with minimal latency+ Great battery life (dropped just 2% overnight)+ Easy export of annotated documents to email- Writable pdfs necessitate minutes-long process of uploading them to Amazon's cloud on another device, then downloading them on the Scribe- Writing Toolbar always on screen while writing on a pdf- No landscape orientation optionThe Kindle Scribe has a lot of potential. The hardware is amazing. None of its competitors seem to be able to match the hardware--a 10.3" screen; a backlight with not only adjustable brightness, but adjustable warmth; a writable surface, long battery life and a responsive stylus that does not require batteries--for the price. In fact, it's difficult to find another eReader that checks all of these boxes at all. It's thin, relatively light, and more comfortable to hold than a hardcover book of the same height and width, though re-learning how to hold it has been a bit of an adjustment coming from a Kindle Paperwhite and Kindle Fire 8. For me, the larger display more than makes up for the slight hit to ergonomics. My only quibble with the hardware is that erasing with the premium pen takes a surprising amount of force. Applying sufficient pressure to to depress the eraser button and dragging the pen feels to me like I'm going to scratch the screen. I haven't yet, but using the shortcut button to erase with the nib is much more pleasant and requires much less pressure. Other than that, it's difficult to think of a way to improve the hardware. Particularly, reading at night with the back light's warmth adjusted to filter out blue light is pleasant and unlike any other device I've used. It's excellent.The software, though, is where it becomes evident that this is a first-gen product on its first firmware revision. The big one for me: Although the promotions and ads are correct that you can write on pdfs on the Scribe, **you can only write on pdfs that you send to your device through the Amazon portal in a web browser on another device.** If you simply drag and drop a pdf onto the device over USB, then that pdf is going to be read-only. This reliance on Amazon's cloud service was not mentioned in the product description or advertising anywhere (**EDIT: Amazon has revised their product page to address this omission), is annoying, and raises some serious concerns about privacy. If you're sending an ebook in pdf form (typically 5-6mb), then the process of opening your browser, dragging and dropping it into the Amazon portal, waiting for it to upload, then opening your kindle, waiting for it to sync, finding the new item, clicking on it, waiting for it to download, and opening it is cumbersome but tolerable. If you're hoping to write on an even larger file like a scan of a book, though, get comfortable: the 50mb scan I uploaded took twelve minutes! Over a 500mb/s fiberoptic connection! Having to use proprietary web software to get usable pdfs to a separate device feels like a holdover from 2005. Having it take several minutes feels like a holdover from 1998.Aside from being unwieldy, dependence on a third-party cloud for writable pdfs presents a privacy problem. One thing I was hoping to do with the Scribe was grade student papers. I was picturing simply dumping a folder full of them onto the Scribe via USB or even WiFi over my own network. The first isn't possible and the second now seems like a distant dream. I can't in good conscience send my students' work to Amazon's servers. So I won't. **EDIT**: Amazon has since updated their product description attesting to the security of their servers. I believe them! But I still wouldn't feel comfortable managing students' work on the Scribe unless/until I'm able to transfer them back and forth over USB.The other issue with writable pdfs is that the Writing Toolbar must be on the screen if you want to mark up a pdf using the pen. This means looking at a dime-sized icon of a pen on every single page of whatever you're reading. Sure, there's an option to hide the icon, but doing so reduces the function of the pen to mere pointing and scrolling. If you want to write, then you're going to have to tolerate the icon. Why not offer an option to hide it while remembering its previously set function? Why not at least make it smaller and have it expand upon tapping it? Maybe it won't bother you, but I find it incredibly distracting.Lastly, there's no option to read in landscape mode, meaning there's no way to hold the Kindle on its side to view two pages at once as you might on an iPad. You're locked into portrait mode. Being able to hold the tablet sideways would've been welcome while reading lying down, which is a little tricky with the screen as tall as it is. It's also too tall for the shelf of the treadmill I like to use while reading sometimes, but a portrait mode option would've been fine. Hopefully this is an option that will become available as the Scribe firmware matures.If none of these three software shortcomings bothers you, then I don't think you'll find a better deal for comparable hardware. For me, though, they may be deal-breakers, which is too bad since the device itself is by far the best I've ever used to read ebooks.

product_name: Amazon Kindle Scribe (16 GB) - 10.2” 300 ppi Paperwhite display, a Kindle and a notebook all in one, convert notes to text and share, includes Basic Pen
description: Anyone who has used a Kindle knows how pitifully crude and rudimentary its document management is and continues to exist in unacceptable fashion.  Organizing books, identifying duplicates and even simple appearance is akin to beta software circa 25 years ago. It's about time Amazon actually made a modicum of effort, especially since I came extremely close to buying an Android ereader but for a rare major sale and acceptance that this is an ereader and not the tablet it purports to be. I'll explain why.1. Inability to connect a bluetooth keyboard. This is completely unacceptable. Very few will bring along a 10" device and not have the ability to have a keyboard for note taking, which was standard at least 5-10 years ago.2. Inability to easily organize notes, with books and collections having the same issues. We need some nested folders for organization and basic file management tools that have existed for decades. If you can't provide them, Android readers are worth every penny of the extra $100 they charge now and dropping.3. No basic apps other than Kindle reading and note taking. As above, if you're portable with a 10" e-reader, I can't imagine anyone not also using it for basic email management and communication. This requires you to take a second tablet or laptop because it cannot satisfy basic demands expected a decade ago.4. No audio capability other than Audiobooks. Wake up Amazon. You're not keeping us in your ecosystem but making the device incapable of playing audio files and without any MP3 player or audio app. I have books that use MP3 files and not useful if on such platforms - such as language and other instructional books. In addition, sometimes I like to listen to music while reading, soft classical in the background. I'm far from alone.5. Note taking feature is poorly implemented and gets in the way of reading. To give you an example of how lazy the development has been, there is a big circle that stays on the screen for note taking options while reading. It cannot be moved. It gets in the way of documents that I have open that go closer to edge to edge reading, which I enjoy far more than big white margins. Hard to believe anyone would design it like this and features are barren. Other reviews cover that part.6. Amazon's own platforms are unacceptably deficient. If you try to use Amazon's web platform to organize books, even that doesn't have an identification of all books that are not tagged or labeled for organization like there is on the actual devices. This type of oversight is completely unacceptable as it requires you to scroll and individually look at every book to see if it has a category/folder/collection, wasting huge amounts of time. The Android app is also barren of many features and looks like it hasn't been touched in a long time.7. Very limited e-reader options other than Amazon's format, e.g. PDF. There is no way to zoom in text and lock the screen for PDFs. This common feature allows you to maximize the visibility of viewable PDF text on the screen and push the white borders out of view. Right now, you still need to crop the borders out and reprint every book (if you can) because the Kindle software cannot do this for PDFs. If you're getting a 10" tablet to view docs, especially PDFs, this omission is another baffling bit of laziness that will cost you huge amounts of time if you read books that have illustrations, charts, etc. and benefit from the slightly larger screen space of zooming in docs and removing needless white borders.Bottom line is this. When other ereaders and basic software is light years ahead of this device - whose hardware is excellent - you know it's time to consider abandonment and move onto something far more useful with value for the money. Unless Amazon invests a modicum of effort, I'm very confident you'll find the better, high end Android readers a much better value. And if you value your time, basic book management features will save you huge amounts of time that make any premium price worthwhile without even thinking about it.The hardware itself is great. But others will rip apart the pathetic, dated software that Amazon treats as a cash cow with its brand name until you recognize the limitations and the pen being mostly a gimmick.Come on Amazon - up the game here! No other leading tech company would allow its products to languish and look this poor in comparison to the competition. You're close to the tipping point of people flipping to alternative products and the basics are not expensive to add. Just do it!

product_name: Amazon Kindle Scribe (16 GB) - 10.2” 300 ppi Paperwhite display, a Kindle and a notebook all in one, convert notes to text and share, includes Basic Pen
description: Generally I love a Kindle but this so far is a failure. For the amount this device costs, I really regret purchasing a Kindle.I do like that you have the option of setting a lock screen and that it is not mandatory.I am extremely frustrated that for the amount this Kindle costs and its so-called accessibility features (which are not), do not address those of us who love to read and have visual disabilities. They should have consulted with someone who has visual disabilities before calling it accessible. It's like the place that says it is wheelchair accessible but the wheelchair won't fit through the doorway. Lot of promise ahead if you can just get through the door.I have changed the settings to LARGE for the print but the large is equal to the regular default print on a computer screen.. not very large 10-12 pt?  (I enlarge my screens using CTL - scroll wheel on the mouse.) In a book you can enlarge it but, real catch, your clock and page status stays extremely small so what good are they when you need large print? Might as well leave that option off. I do like to have it on so I can see how far I have read and since I read at night I like to see how late it is...  Need to resort to my clock instead.I have had to resort to using a magnifying screen/glass to read what is on this device. This makes it impossible to hold and read so I have to use a cover that I can use as a stand to use this device for reading.I would love to see some color to add contrast. The light grays are hard to make out against a white background and don't show up when you invert the pages to dark background. The warm background is not as warm as I would like (I have sepia on my Tablet). There is no way to adjust the contrast to enhance the grays.I also got this because of the ability to write in documents and notebooks. Just like the Samsung Note phone. I am disappointed in the features of this Kindle. Many of these features are "still coming"... I was able to load some Word documents I had written but not that someone else had written. Quirk? My son is a songwriter and we were sending documents back and forth. I thought this would be nice so I could edit or make notations on his documents. We are still working on the perms so that we can exchange PDF and word docs to make notes on. Not as straight forward as one would hope. He is not using a Kindle to create his documents.Also in the notebooks there is dead spaces in the upper right and lower right corners that can't be used. These are areas that are used to turn pages I think ... can't really write on them and have trouble trying to erase what marks get put there when trying to write there.The Kindle is easy to hold with the left side giving plenty of space to hold without putting your fingers on the screen. The premium pen is handy for noting things and writing in notebooks and taking notes in documents (that let you). I haven't noticed a change in the brush when I click to change it though. It is light and easy to hold. Just be careful not to click the button while writing. I have spasms in my fingers and have learned that I need to turn the pen so my finger does not rest on the button.It does have Google Search which is by far a lot better than Silk.The battery seems to last.  This is good since I use my Kindles a lot.This isn't a long review. I'm not going to get into the tech stuff. That is all covered in the description and by tech buffs.  It is a Kindle. It does the Kindle stuff but unfortunately this Kindle is not geared towards the visually challenged. Yes, I am visually challenged/disabled, but have had absolutely NO issues with my Kindle Fire Tablets.  This has the e-ink and other features that I was sure I would love. I might -- if I could enlarge them to read the screens and not be so frustrated.Think twice if you are thinking of getting this as a gift for someone who is a senior or has vision issues. Get a Fire Tablet instead... at least you can adjust the print size and the colors help to make out what is on the screen.About the touchscreen. Mine seems to be finicky. Sometimes when I tap it responds, other times it ignores me (which seems to be the standard response). Usually I need to resort to the pen to tap on the screen to get it to react.Storage -- does it hold a lot? Yes. I have a lot of documents loaded and still plenty of space.  Just wish I could enlarge the print and read them.For the above problems with the print size, I have gone through all the available Amazon help pages to find an answer. They don't have one except for a couple that say submit feedback, which I have done. There is no available work around or fix at this point. Sadly this is a first generation and knowing Amazon I will have to purchase a whole new Scribe to be able to access the fixes to the print. I think I will just stick to the Fire Tablet.
