I won't hold this against it because it's so new.BASS 90/100MIDS 85/100HIGHS 80/100DETAIL 85/100SOUNDSTAGE 85/100BATTERY 100/100QUALITY 95/100---VALUE 65/100OVERALL 80/100RECOMMENDED? NOT AT MSRP.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: The Bose SoundLink Max is a stout little speaker that produces impressively big sound considering its compact size. It has a simple design, both aesthetically and in its features, and could appeal to most anyone looking for a portable bluetooth speaker if budget was not a factor.Rated IP67, the Max is water and dust proof with a powder coated silicone exterior that annoyingly attracts debris and fingerprints which are very visible on the black finish. Along with handles in different colors, shoulder straps can be purchased separately though it would have been nice to see a shoulder strap included at this price point.At low to moderate volumes the sound quality is quite good. Going louder, the bass begins to drop out and music loses its luster, which is expected to a certain extent but I didn't expect such a noticable sacrifice of depth for decibels. Connected to our satellite receiver, however, it played the role of a soundbar beautifully.After owning and using the SoundLink Max for two weeks, I can tell you there are plenty of bluetooth speakers with quality sound that are a better value. Many are significantly more affordable and/ or offer more features (one might expect a microphone and wifi capability in this price range but the Max has neither).Due to the exorbitant cost, friends and family said they'd be unable or unwilling to buy this speaker. I'm not sure who I'd recommend it to but my imagination tells me the Bose SoundLink Max might be purchased by 35+ crowd who have disposable income and/ or those who are Bose loyalists.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: The sound quality is great and volume too I can hear it well at my job. Although I only get 3 hours of charge? That's while I have it plugged in too, maybe something's wrong? I don't knowm

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: When I first unpacked this product and listened to it, I was completely won over.  What an amazing first impression.  Excellent soundstage.  Wide, detailed, clear, everything you could want.Unfortunately, once you take the volume to even close to 50%, which you'd want to do in many situations and certainly outside, and it all falls apart.  Hero to zero in the blink of an eye.The bass has a fart-like quality to it which ruins everything.  The only way to make this sound acceptable is to use the EQ to take the bass pretty much to nothing or even a negative setting.  In which case, you could buy almost any other Bluetooth speaker for less than half the price that is going to sound just as good.Many of the reviews talk about bass and presence, but that's only true at really low levels.  At least assuming the unit I was sent is working to factory spec.And don't get me wrong, I'm not listening to music at window rattling levels designed to annoy the neighbors.  I'm not even listening to tracks that I think are especially bass heavy.As an example I listened to Clocks by Coldplay.  Hardly a hardcore bass fest.  The opening bars sounded amazing.  But as soon as the gentle bass chords joined the music, the speaker lost itself.I tried the product on a hard wooden stool.  A hard wooden deck.  A patio table.  A different patio table.  A few feet away.  A few meters away.  It really didn't matter.  I played with numerous EQ settings.  But the bottom line is that it just can't put out bass in any real capacity unless you are willing to lower the sound to a background volume.  In which case, it's amazing.  To me, the bass being available in such a quiet and tiny sweet spot, makes it kind of worthless to include it at all.  I have a pair of B&O Explore speakers, that sound amazing and can be set as a stereo pair.  If you buy them well you can have two of them for $100 less than this Bose.  What they lack in bass, they more than make up for in incredible sound stage, stereo separation and can go toe to toe in terms of detail.  The thing is, they also KNOW they can't do much bass, so they don't even try.  Bose, is trying too hard to make bass happen that apparently isn't possible in this system.Just like I don't drive my car at 100 mph ever, I want it to be capable of that.  I want it to accelerate from zero to sixty in under seven seconds, even though it's not how I drive.  And when it comes to speakers, I want to know that if I want to turn up the volume a little, it isn't going to sound like a box of farts.I tried to give it every opportunity to impress, but it failed at everything except very quiet listening levels.  I was mainly streaming from Apple Music, and I even looked for songs offered at their highest bitrate or including spacial audio technology.  For the price they are charging, there is no way I keep this item.  It is already in the box ready to go to UPS.Maybe it would be different if you have a different sound source, are using a different streaming service, are using AUX or Android.  My tests were iOS based, and bluetooth streaming.  Tracks that I have previously tested on my Marshall Woburn II speaker as an example, with the same source equipment.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: *Disappointing and Flawed: Bose SoundLink MAX Review*I am amazed that over 75% of the people who have written a review of this product do not mention that it does not link to another speaker. That just goes to show you that they have no intentions of buying another speaker because this probably cost so much, they can’t afford to buy another one.I'm writing this review with a heavy heart, as a lifelong Bose enthusiast who's been let down by their latest flagship product, the SoundLink MAX. This premium speaker's glaring omission – the inability to link with other identical models – is a staggering misstep.As a loyal customer with decades of Bose electronics and speakers, I expected excellence from the SoundLink MAX. Its name suggests a continuation of Bose's legendary linking capability, allowing seamless stereo pairing with other compatible models. Instead, this pricey speaker stands alone, stubbornly refusing to connect with its own kind.The customer service department's baffling response – "they had no idea why" – only compounds my disappointment. Did Bose abandon their signature linking feature to cut costs or cater to a new market? Whatever the reason, it's a catastrophic decision.The SoundLink MAX's performance, while decent, can't justify its premium price tag. It lacks the depth and richness I've come to expect from Bose. Compared to its predecessors, this speaker feels like a step backward.*Key Issues:*1. No linking capability with other SoundLink MAX models2. Overpriced considering its limited features3. Disappointing sound quality compared to previous Bose models4. Lack of innovation and progress in design*Verdict:*Avoid the Bose SoundLink MAX. Its flawed design and missing feature make it a poor investment. As a loyal customer, I'm saddened by Bose's apparent self-destructive trajectory, prioritizing profit over innovation and customer satisfaction.*Rating:* 1.5/5 stars*Recommendation:*Explore alternative options from brands that still prioritize quality, innovation, and customer needs. Consider the following:- Sonos Move- JBL Boombox- UE MegablastBose, take heed: loyal customers expect better. Revisit your design philosophy and reclaim your reputation as a leader in audio excellence.*UPDATE:* I hope Bose will address this critical issue and release a firmware update or new model that restores the linking capability. Until then, I cannot recommend the SoundLink MAX.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: Just setting without using Battery won’t hold a charge over a day. Other then that is a great speaker

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: The Soundlink Max is a good speaker by itself, The finish and build are really great, The base and EQ work phenomenall, If you only want one portable speaker this is it. However, and unfortunately, it is sold as a sound link, which usually means you can pair it with another Bose and run it in stereo mode. This is not the case with the Max. I purchased this to pair up with my Bose flex But that's never going to happen. Bose missed the target once again. I can live with the fact that it does not have a microphone for phone conversations but it's hard to get stereo with 2 speakers, 4 inches apart. You can get 2 flex speakers with microphones and pair up in stereo and separate them by thirty feet and have an amazing sound and only spend three hundred instead of four hundred. Returning it today. BTW, I own many Bose sound systems Including sound bars SL3, SL2, mini's, And even the S1 pro with subwoofer that I use for small weddings, Very familiar with the software and using them.Thanks for listening.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: This speaker connects seamlessly to any Bluetooth capable device. The sound is there, it’s definitely decent. What you would expect from a speaker this size. I run into a wall with the price, this is not worth the price at all. If this were about 50% less, it would be worth it. The sound quality is good, but not as good as the price. Definitely better than other speakers on the market, but you have to weigh the pros and cons with how much you’re willing to shell out! The speaker itself is large, but easy to handle (it literally has a handle). Easy to move from space to space or travel with. One good full charge seems to last a long while. We have used it 2 nights in a row at our bonfires with no need to charge again. It feels good quality. Nice sleek, black look… but I must say, again, the price—scary!

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: Sound is great...it's expensive..with the sounding name I assumed it would "link" with the other sound link products but it doesn't.  Kind of underhanded way to false advertise. I think I'll switch to Sony or Sonos. Still...the bose sounding flex is as good as it gets

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: I’m a Bose guy. My surround sound my headphones my mini speakers…impressive sound with all of those but not so much with this one. I was disappointed. If you’re trying for a loud speaker for a larger gathering this is not the speaker for you. If you want a louder speaker than the mini speaker then you’ll be happy with this one. If you turn up the volume it gets distorted like most cheap speakers out there. Sad for Bose.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: First off the presentation is fantastic. The brushed rubber shell does collect fingerprints/stains but it just as easily sheds them with a swipe. This allows for a better grip. The front grill screams premium quality that you come to expect with the BOSE name. The included handle feels sturdy and makes you eager to try out the long shoulder strap that will truly make you portable and be able to carry hands free sound. The entire unit, about the size of a football, feels incredibly well made. It is heavy, dense, and very substantial. You would not be brushing it over, or knocking it off the table easily. Minor splashes in the kitchen setting while im preparing food have easily been cleaned off and leave no residual mark. The bluetooth connection is seemless and easily connects across multiple devices. The app allows for quick preset configurations such as treble boost that makes conversations in movies clear as day, while bass boost literally shakes your body with glorious vibrations. However, the reason to choose this product over the competitors is how loud it can get with the addition of BOSE famous clarity of sound. The loudness is similar to expensive alternatives that are much bigger in size. However the clarity and richness of BOSE is undeniable and incomparable. I filled my 3400 sq ft home with full sound and didn't even turn it up to the highest level for fear of disturbing my neighbor's peace. There was no rattle or crackle at that level which is the best mark of quality materials. My favorite setting to use is when I'm in the yard gardening and watering the plants. Once my shoulder strap arrives. I'm sure Ill just be able to carry it around as i work without having to reposition it at all. All in all, this is a premium device that you are paying for high quality materials and even higher quality sound. Bose did not disappoint! It can be the perfect small footprint travel companion to offer premium home theater sound while streaming or big party speaker sound to a whole room or outdoor patio/deck with power to spare.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: Experience exceptional sound quality with the Bose SoundLink Max, a compact and portable Bluetooth speaker. The SoundLink Max is a small speaker that produces rich, full-bodied sound, making it stand out from other Bluetooth speakers. One of the most impressive aspects of the SoundLink Max is its deep, punchy bass response. The speaker's proprietary transducer technology delivers low frequencies with clarity, precision, and no distortion or muddiness.The SoundLink Max delivers a satisfying bass experience that belies its size, whether listening to hip-hop, electronic dance music, or rock. The midrange and treble frequencies are equally impressive, with a level of detail and clarity that is rare in portable Bluetooth speakers. Vocals sound natural and lifelike, while instruments are well-separated and easily distinguishable. The SoundLink Max is a musical time machine that transports you to the concert hall, putting you in the front row with the performers. Another standout feature of the SoundLink Max is its build quality.The speaker is constructed with high-quality materials, including a durable aluminum grille and a rubberized base that keeps it stable on any surface. It's ideal for use outdoors or in humid environments. It’s also water-resistant, perfect for summer pool parties or even on your boat. I love using it on my boat, as it is almost as loud as my built-in stereo. The long battery life ensures the music lasts all day, and because it is so small, my kids can carry it around and use it.The SoundLink Max is also incredibly easy to use, with simple controls and a user-friendly app that allows you to customize your listening experience. The speaker has a range of up to 30 feet, allowing you to move freely around your space without losing connection. Enjoy your music all day with up to 12 hours of battery life. While there are certainly Bluetooth speakers on the market that can play louder than the SoundLink Max, none of them can match its combination of sound quality, portability, and design. Get great sound wherever you are with the SoundLink Max, the perfect speaker for those who want quality sound in a compact package.In conclusion, the Bose SoundLink Max is a top-of-the-line Bluetooth speaker with exceptional sound quality, durability, and ease of use. This speaker is a game-changer, able to produce deep, powerful bass and detailed, lifelike midrange and treble frequencies that set it apart from the rest.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: Simply put... this Bose speaker is absolutely Fantastic! Crystal clear highs, mids, and lows. The bass that comes out of this speaker is incredible! I had a dumbfounded look on my face when I heard this for the first time because I was like..  "There's no way that this little size speaker puts out sound like that with incredible bass." But, YEP, it does! And to top it off, the bass doesn't fall off at higher volumes like other speakers do.It was easy to setup, the play/pause/volume controls are straightforward. It does take a few hours to charge when the battery is fully depleted. I have no complaints about that. Besides, you get like 20 hours of play time on a full charge.It is a little heavy for its size. But that just goes to show the quality of this speaker. It feels very durable. The pricetag is HEFTY. But let me tell you this... it is absolutely worth every penny.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: As a long-time owner of the first-generation Bose SoundLink Mini, I had high expectations for the Bose SoundLink Max, and it did not disappoint. This review covers various aspects of the speaker, including sound quality, durability, ease of use, compatibility, setup, and design. The SoundLink Max lives up to the Bose name. After testing it with a myriad of musical genres, I was blown away by the fullness of the sound. The bass is so powerful that you can feel it, yet it does not drown out the mid and treble frequencies. It is worth noting that the initial EQ settings are flat, which might be why some users have complained about the lack of fullness. This could be addressed by repurposing the shortcut button for quick EQ adjustment. The SoundLink Max meets the IP67 standards, making it rugged, dustproof, and waterproof. Weighing nearly five pounds, it is heavy, but this is an acceptable trade-off for the durability it offers. In a pinch, you could even use it as a brick or a weapon for defending yourself from zombies! Using the SoundLink Max is straightforward. Press the power button, then play to start enjoying your music. When it’s time to change settings, the buttons are clearly labeled. The Max charges via a supplied USB-C cord and power block and can also serve as a portable power device. This is my main point of contention and it is not specifically with the Max, but with Bose as a whole. They have partnered with Qualcomm/Snapdragon for their HD Audio, which is currently confined to the Android ecosystem. As an iPhone user, I felt a little left out in the cold. Straight out-of-the-box, the Max was nearly ready to go. It took two seconds to pair and less than that to start charging, thanks to the included USB-C cable and power brick. The Bose app was easy to find and quick to install. I was able to set up an account and start using the app right away. While the setup was easy, more emphasis should be placed on the necessity of using the app to achieve the best sound, as the default EQ settings are a bit flat. The SoundLink Max boasts a sleek and simple design. There are no unnecessary lights or reminiscent designs to distract you—just a rugged exterior that protects the speakers while delivering excellent sound quality. The rope handle is a nice feature that accentuates the rugged yet simple design. They are easily changeable for other colored handles and shoulder straps, which are available at a steep premium on the Bose website. The Bose SoundLink Max is a phenomenal portable speaker that lives up to the high standards we expect from Bose. After several days of testing in various locations and with different music genres, I have not been disappointed. While there have been some reports of less-than-fantastic sound quality, this issue is easily resolved by adjusting the EQ settings in the Bose app. The final question is, is the SoundLink Max worth the $400 price tag? The simple answer is yes, it is worth every penny.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: The Bose Soundlink Max was a little smaller than I expected but boy does it pack a punch! The build quality of the speaker is top notch as you'd expect from Bose.We used it at my daughters party last weekend and it completely filled our backyard with clear mids and some serious bass, it can get VERY loud if you want it to without compromising on quality. Battery life will last all day and it's charging time is very reasonable. I love that it's IP67 certified as we use it resting on our hot tub and we plan on taking it to the lake next week without any worries. The buttons are sealed under rubber, but they still have a nice "click" to them so you know you are pressing them, the handle is swappable so you're able to customize it's color a little and it doesn't weigh too much, so we can carry it quite comfortably in a backpack or bag. Overall I feel like it's just a tad overpriced, but I would recommend it to everyone who needs a quality audio experience on the go!

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: Purchasing the Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker was a game-changer. From the moment I unboxed it, I felt a sense of excitement and anticipation. The sleek design and robust build promised an unparalleled audio experience, and it did not disappoint. Setting it up was a breeze, and within minutes, my home was filled with rich, crystal-clear sound.One of the unexpected benefits of the Bose SoundLink Max was the positive impact it had on my marriage. My spouse and I often struggled with communication and finding common ground for quality time. This speaker changed everything. We began having evening listening sessions, sharing our favorite music, and even discovering new artists together. The immersive sound quality created a shared experience that brought us closer. We laughed, reminisced, and connected in ways we hadn't in years. The Bose SoundLink Max became a cornerstone of our daily routine, rekindling the spark in our relationship.Music has always been a refuge for me, a way to escape the stresses of daily life. The Bose SoundLink Max took this to another level. The clarity and depth of sound allowed me to lose myself in the music, providing a therapeutic escape. Whether I was working from home, relaxing after a long day, or simply needing a moment of calm, the Bose SoundLink Max was there, delivering an audio experience that soothed my mind and lifted my spirits.What truly sets the Bose SoundLink Max apart is its portability. I could take it anywhere—whether I was moving from the living room to the kitchen, spending time in the backyard, or even taking it on trips. Its battery life is impressive, ensuring hours of uninterrupted playtime. The Bluetooth connectivity is seamless, allowing me to control my music from my phone effortlessly.The Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker is more than just a speaker; it's a life enhancer. It saved my marriage by providing a new way for my spouse and I to connect and brought immeasurable benefits to my mental health with its impeccable sound quality. If you're looking for a product that delivers exceptional audio and has the potential to transform your life, the Bose SoundLink Max is the answer. It's a purchase I will never regret, and I cannot recommend it highly enough.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: I just got the Bose SoundLink Max Speaker, and it's awesome! From the moment I opened the box, I knew it was going to be great. Sound: The sound quality is amazing. Whether I'm jamming to some chill acoustic tunes or blasting dance music, it sounds perfect. The bass is strong but doesn't drown out the other sounds, which stay clear and crisp. Look: It's got a sleek and modern look that fits nicely in any room. It's also pretty solid and easy to move around, so no worries about it getting damaged. Battery: The battery life is fantastic. It easily lasts over 12 hours on one charge, even when I play it loud. Perfect for parties, BBQs, or just a music-filled day. Connection: Connecting via Bluetooth is super easy and the connection is stable. I can move around my house without losing signal. Plus, the built-in mic is handy for clear calls. Extras: It's water-resistant (IPX4), which is great for outdoor use. I also love the voice prompts that tell me the battery level and pairing status. Overall: The Bose SoundLink Max Speaker rocks! It's a bit pricey, but totally worth it. If you're looking for a top-notch portable speaker, you should definitely get this one.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: A minor accident with defective work equipment destroyed my Bose SoundLink Revolve+ Series II.After viewing "JBL Xtreme 4 Vs Bose Soundlink Max" by GYMCADDY on YouTube, I decided to replace my broken Bose with this newer model.After receiving the Max and listening for a few minutes, I was immediately disappointed. Where is the clarity and sound purity I worship from the Bose Revolve+ Series II? Even with a flat equalizer, the bass on this SoundLink Max sounds muddy compared to my prior Bose. But this "muddy" effect is common in portable speakers with bass, regardless of brand.After adjusting the equalizer on the Bose app, and listening to this Max for a few days, I have grown to enjoy its extra bass on pop and rock tracks that the Bose SoundLink Revolve+ Series II lacks. Now, if I had to switch from this SoundLink Max to my prior Bose, I would gripe, whine, moan, and complain:"Where is my bass? Where is the expanded soundstage coming from the side radiators on the Max? Where is the higher volume I can get out of the Max?"It has to do with acclimating to what we are used to. Now, if I had to choose only one of those two, it would likely be the Max. But I will always miss the sound purity out of the Revolve+ Series II.The Revolve+ Series II is as loud or louder than I usually desired. But if I were a young guy with no one telling me to "Turn that noise pollution down!", I would appreciate the extra volume and extra bass on this Bose SoundLink Max.GYMCADDY on YouTube said he likes the sound from the JBL Xtreme 4 better than from Bose SoundLink Max.The reason I chose this Bose SoundLink Max, is because the Xtreme 4 is a bit bigger, and the Max is already bigger than the Bose I replaced. And I need to balance a relatively compact mid size speaker, with sound quality and volume. The Extreme 4 is a bit bigger than what I am willing to schlepp around, manage, and find spots to nest it in during use and transport.If size were not an issue, I would have gotten the Extreme 4......except for ONE unfortunate factor:GYMCADDY said that - as of his review about a week ago - Extreme 4 needed a software update, as he experienced lip synch lag on it while watching videos on his phone, which he did not experience with the Max.The Max comes with a small rope handle, but you can purchase a long shoulder rope strap for it from Bose.Com for $45 + $5 shipping + sales tax. It is clever how you can use just one hand to turn each lug to remove the handle or shoulder strap, and easily replace with the other option. Each end of the rope and handles are permanently attached to its own lug loop, unless you use scissors or a knife to permanently detach them.Two benefits the Revolve+ Series II has that Bose SoundLink Max does not:1. You can use it for phone calls. 2. It is a circular speaker, you can set it in the middle of a room, and the sound comes out 360°: the sound is the same all the way around it. With the Max, you have to be in front of the speaker for its best sound.If you value clarity and simply amazing sound purity in a portable, get the Bose SoundLink Revolve+ Series II. It still has a modest amount of bass. If you want more pronounced bass, but need a relatively compact medium size portable, get this Max. If you desire even more volume, and don't mind carrying around and storing more weight and size, consider getting one of the bigger JBLs. But pause on the Xtreme 4, until they update their software for that video lip synch lag.JBL has an even bigger portable than Xtreme 4 that I use (an older version of) with my TV, on Bluetooth, and I experience no lip synch lag on it.P.S.: I am "underwhelmed" that Ama*on refused to sell me the third party brand protective carrying case with shoulder strap they label as their recommended choice, UNLESS I signed up for P*IME. I had never seen this before, though I do see other forms of manipulation on Ama*on.Such as frequently hiding the 'Most RECENT Review' option, so one has to go looking for the most recent review with some products, rather than seeing just the (usually) glowing 'Most Helpful Reviews' they place right in front of you. As a way to seduce you to click 'Buy It Now', rather than research what recent purchasers' experiences are with products.The reason they are called "Managers", is because "Manipulators" strips them na*ed in public. And public n*dity is ill eagle. Mmhm--that's how that works. Run and tell THAT.So I skipped the protective carrying case. I am glad I did, because except for the speaker grills, most of the rest of the speaker is rubberized, to minimize cosmetic damage. And a carrying case would also defeat my smaller, more portable speaker goal. And besides, if you use it as a "portable", carrying it to and fro, you reasonably expect it will get banged up to some degree.Educational Post Post Script: A box or container that delivers sound is called a "speaker". Each of the round things inside it that produce sound waves are called "drivers" or "speaker drivers". Better quality speakers have multiple drivers, such as for bass, midrange, and a tweeter for treble.

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: INITIAL REVIEW...So my review is solely on the comparison of the sound between the Bose Soundlink Max vs. JBL Extreme 4.  Both are about the same prices.BASS:  Bose WINS.  Deeper and more prominent bass. (I realized it sounded bloated and muddy)TREBLE: JBL WINS.  More detailed and brighter.SPECTRUM OF SOUND:  Bose WINS.  Bose seems to have a wider spectrum of sound.SEPARATION OF INSTRUMENTS:  JBL WINS.SOUNDSTAGE:  JBL WINS.  JBL sounds more open while the Bose sounds more direct and focused.VOLUME:  Bose WINS.  Bose seems to get about 25% louder than the JBL. (But the JBL gets plenty loud -- the Bose get's ridiculously loud for its size)OVERALL SOUND ENJOYMENT:  This is tough but I belive the Bose WINS.  The Bose just sounded overall, better to me?  It definitely was warmer and less "tinny" sounding.  The brightness was apparent when you compare the two speakers.  I enjoy a V-shape sound.  I applied the EQ on both the Bose and JBL apps to reflect my preference.  Now don't get me wrong, if you only bought one and only listened to one speaker, you would probably think either one sounds phenomenal.CONSTRUCTION/MAKE:  Tie. This comes down to preference.VALUE:  This one is tough.  Just because you can buy a larger speaker, such as the Sony ULT 7 for the same price (on sale) as the JBL or Bose, doesnt mean the value is not there.  Because if you want a portable smaller speaker to bring, say, to the beach and  don't want to lug around a 15 lbs speaker, then you have to compare the smaller speakers and see which one provides the best sound and features for the smaller size.  Overall, I believe the JBL and Bose should be more realistically priced at $300 regular price - not $400.  But for the smaller size footprint, these two speakers are pretty amazing.UPDATED ON 09.23.24:After keeping the Bose for a few days, I purchased the JBL Extreme 4 to listen to it again.  I also adjusted the EQ in the app again.  In the end, I decided to keep the JBL.  I couldn't get over the seemingly bloated (not very clean) bass and almost muffled sound of the Bose.  The JBL just much sounded cleaner, open, and more refined.  Very impressive.  Plus, I also got the JBL for $329 on sale, and I own the JBL Boombox 3, which allowed me to link them together.  But evaluating just sound, on "instant replay" I decided the JBL was the superior sounding speaker!

product_name: NEW Bose SoundLink Max Portable Speaker, Large Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker, Up to 20 Hours of Battery Life, USB-C, Built-in 3.5mm AUX Input, Black
description: I wanted a new speaker that was small and yet had an awesome sound. Did a bunch of research and came up with two speakers. Extreme 4 and Bose SoundLink Max. Bought the extreme 4, got it home and listened to it for 2 days. While the sound was very surprising for such a small speaker and had a lot of bass the upper end was just too harsh for me. So I boxed it up to go back and ordered the  Bose SoundLink Max. While the base was just about the same with both speakers the mid and upper range to my ear was so much more mellow on the Bose. As One reviewer put it, the extreme 4 is an outdoor party speaker in the Bose some link Max is an indoor speaker. Both are excellent products. But the max just sounded smoother to my ear at the high end of frequencies. Keeping the Bose for sure.

product_name: PAWCUB Smart Board 55 Inch Interactive Whiteboard 4K UHD Touch Screen Digital Electronic Interactive Whiteboard Built in Dual System for Office Business Conference Education (Wall Mount Included)
description: Our company's training room is used. I am very satisfied with this purchase. It is easy to install and set up. Dual operating systems are a great feature and it's easy to switch back and forth between operating systems. This interactive whiteboard has excellent performance! The writing speed is fast and the response is sensitive, leaving a deep impression on everyone who has used it. The display quality is high-definition, and you can easily customize annotations. Wireless screen mirroring is seamless, without lag or lag. Overall, it provides a smooth and efficient experience for teaching and presentation.

product_name: PAWCUB Smart Board 55 Inch Interactive Whiteboard 4K UHD Touch Screen Digital Electronic Interactive Whiteboard Built in Dual System for Office Business Conference Education (Wall Mount Included)
description: The demonstration function on this smart board is top-notch. I can seamlessly switch between slides, dynamically annotate, and save notes for later use. I am very satisfied with this interactive whiteboard because it significantly improves my work and learning experience. I will not hesitate to recommend it to other users with similar needs.The touch screen of this screen is responsive and different from some other smart boards on the market, it will not lag too much. Built in dual system Android system, also available in Windows. Overall, the product is quite good.

product_name: PAWCUB Smart Board 55 Inch Interactive Whiteboard 4K UHD Touch Screen Digital Electronic Interactive Whiteboard Built in Dual System for Office Business Conference Education (Wall Mount Included)
description: This interactive whiteboard can be switched to an educational whiteboard or a drawing board, which is very convenient for my work!. In addition, its real-time sharing and team collaboration features are very helpful for our discussions and project collaboration.

product_name: PAWCUB Smart Board 55 Inch Interactive Whiteboard 4K UHD Touch Screen Digital Electronic Interactive Whiteboard Built in Dual System for Office Business Conference Education (Wall Mount Included)
description: This smart board greatly improves our meeting efficiency and interactivity, with 20 touch and real-time save capabilities enhancing team collaboration, allowing for easy sharing of notes after each meeting. Built in high-definition camera and microphone, excellent audio and video quality make remote meetings smoother.

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)
description: The picture is fine, connected to things fine. Internet, Netflix, Amazon prime. Home screen sucks. My old tv connected to the security cameras as soon as it turned on, then I could go to the home screen if I wanted. Which I never wanted to on the old tv, and wish I would never see on this one even more. Connected to my new headphones fine, but disconnect while moving through the apps. So far, it has only happened once.My biggest problem is I can't put the Spectrum TV app on this. So, it is a boat anchor as far as I'm concerned, though it would probably float, to me it is unbelievablely light. I would send back, but it was my own fault for not checking first and buying because it was cheap. I will be buying another tv to take its place, after some research, and this will be only for the security cameras and left on until it burns out considering it only has 2 HDMI connections anyways. If it would go to the thing connected to it first, I might have replaced the monitor for my laptop with it.Update: I was able to find a setting that makes it go to the last imput when turning on, as long as I check the cameras before I shut it off, it seems to work fine. The headphones disconnecting is happening more often, like when I go to an app I have to reconnect, but not positive yet if that is what is causing it. Once on Netflix it stays connected, though I have to go into the settings to connect manually. The speakers sound bad, low volume, but I haven't changed any of the settings since I bought it exclusively to be heard through headphones. Someone mentioned the app removal doesn't work, mine does, yet it's on that messy home screen I try to avoid. I only use three apos, Netflix, Amazon Prime, and Spectrum TV.

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)
description: I purchased this tv with high hopes, my daughter had previously bought one and I had helped her set it up when she bought hers and so from what I saw I was initially impressed. The colors were bright, the remote was simple, the apps seemed like they were all up to date and all fairly easy to sign in- okay so that’s not what’s most important. What’s most important is that it doesn’t lose wifi connection in the middle of trying to watch your show every few times per day. I would say you get what you pay for but I have purchased 2 Rokus and a few Samsungs and this HAS NEVER HAPPENED. I wouldn’t recommend this tv. I didn’t return it cause I threw the box out. I would also like to add that when I brought this up to my daughter, she said she was experiencing the same thing, but less often. Like I said it shouldn’t happen at all.

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)
description: This Tv is ok, the picture is great. I am very disappointed the remote does not have a microphone, I like searching with the voice feature., which this Tv does not have. Also my old Tv, had pause, rewind and fast forward with a zip drive plugged into the back. The remote takes time to learn. The box said it works with Alexa, my daughter linked them together, but she doesn’ t know how to do any commands. I’m just very frustrated right now. Switching from attenna to the apps is weird too, nothing like my old Tv. I’m still learning, I should be familiar by now. Disappointed

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)
description: I bought a tv not a casting device.  First I had to install an app on my phone to proceed in the set up.  Then I cannot get anywhere on my tv using my remote? With Help from Vizio it was found I had to create/log into the website and add the tv there if I want to use the remote control.  The app is a separate piece, that wasn't very clear

I would not buy again.

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)
description: I didn't like that the speakers were not loud enough because the overall sound quality of the speakers are not very good. I purchased a external Vizio speaker for it only to realize that it did not have enough HDMI ports to support  it, so I had to unplug my DVD player to accommodate the speaker. I have other TVs that have 4-5 ports.

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)
description: Was easy to set up, but doesn't work with my Amazon firestick nor my Bluetooth ear buds. Will never buy a Vizio tv again. Very disappointed it doesn't work as well as my old Sharp tv that finally died.

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)
description: Great price and very good value for the price paidWorks well and actually better than expectedHave to setup the TV for use, but not hard just a few taps if you follow the directions as instructed on the TV

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)

Also,I have the highest wifi and it does freeze on the free channels. Not netflix and all. Iam happy over all because I wanted an inexpensive tv that's good.

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)
description: It's great so far, picture is clear, and the sound is wonderful,  I don't know why some say it's bad, I'm not having any issues with it. Overall it's a great tv. Smart features were great and this is my first experience using them. I watch a lot OTA and enjoy the old black and white shows.

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)

The picture is fine and all that, but there is a noticeable (enough to be distracting and annoying) lag between picture and audio when using Bluetooth.  I'm not going to bother returning it but the Bluetooth is disappointing.  How could they let something go out the door that bad??

product_name: VIZIO 40-inch Full HD 1080p Smart TV with DTS Virtual: X, Alexa Compatibility, Google Cast Built-in, Bluetooth Headphone Capable, (VFD40M-08 New)
description: Set up was trick with the phone app, but it’s done. Looks a lot like Roku home page.  I’ve had several Vizio tv’s and have never been disappointed.

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: The OEM Roku remotes supplied with TV's manufactured by TCL, Hisense & others as well as the Roku apps utilize radio frequency communications. To do so, the remotes regularly exchange data with the TV regardless of whether one presses buttons. That ensures they are fast & the TV is responsive but results in shorter battery life.These remotes utilize infrared communications that is slower so the TV isn't as responsive but the battery life is longer because the remote isn't constantly communicating with the TV. As infrared remote & TV pairings go, these remotes aren't very good. Most good infrared remotes from decades past with fresh batteries could be pointed at a white ceiling or mirror & the bounced signal would get the job done. These remotes must be aimed directly at the point on the TV where the infrared receiver is located (usually bottom center). Any deviation in the aiming or object in the path will prevent keypresses from being received & acted upon.People used to pointing RF remotes in any direction & from behind most objects will have to get used to pointing this IR remote at the TV with an unobstructed path. This probably accounts for the high number of returned remotes & one star reviews.

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)

Thank you

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: One remote quit working today. We changed the batteries and still would not work. Luckily we had the extra one and it's  working fine for now. Bought these in July and one is already dead. Lasted till just after return by date.

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: Buttons falling off would be the name of this review but I went with NOT THRILLED instead.I bought these twice in the span of 6 months and I'll tell you why.  The first time I bought them, all was fine and dandy.  My TCL TV is stellar and the remote that looks just like these that came with it, was also stellar.  But after 5 years of abuse by my family including tiny baby boys, it finally gave up.  The buttons were chewed on...it had been cleaned many times and it was hard to read the buttons anymore.So it did a great job.I went on here and sniffed around for a replacement.  I was initially happy and they worked well for the most part - I gave one to my in-laws and kept one for myself.  Then after a few weeks I noticed the buttons were sort of...not on the remote.  They were gone.  Under the couch or just on the floor, they were just falling out of their little sockets.  Of course when my four year old is watching TV, he sort of stares blankly at the TV while unconsciously picking at the buttons.  He just loves that rubbery feel, I guess.So it's partly my fault for having a destructive trait in my DNA, partly just whatever, and partly the remote's fault.  So after reprimanding my son, I ordered two more (They're SO cheap).  Anyway, sure enough, without fail, my floor was littered with the tiny little rubber buttons after a day or so.Other that this issue, they work fine, just as they are supposed to.  I can put the buttons back in, but it's kinda stupid to keep doing that.As you were

description: I got these to replace a different Roku remote and they work great with my other TV, but not for my TCL that I intended them for.

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: I recently bought the (Pack of 2) Replacement Remotes, and they work perfectly with my devices! Syncing them was a breeze, and both remotes responded immediately. The design is similar to the original, and the buttons are easy to press with great functionality. Having two remotes is convenient for multiple rooms or as a backup. They feel sturdy and well-made, providing excellent value for the price. If you're looking for reliable replacement remotes, I highly recommend this pack! It’s saved me a lot of hassle!

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: These remotes worked instantly. We have two Roku TCL flat screen TVs. These remotes work for both TVs. Regardless of which remote you are using. No downloading or set up is required. It is as simple as putting the batteries in the remote. It works on either Roku TCL TV instantly. The price for a two pack was amazing. We are constantly losing remotes. Never knew it was so easy to replace a remote.

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: Controllers work fine for the TV we bought them for (TCL brand). Nearly docked a point because they unfortunately also turn on a second TV (Vizio) that is in the same room every time we adjust the volume on the TCL, but that would be a unfair. Overall, happy with the purchase.

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: Came next day and replaced a remote that stopped working. Two to a package so have a spare.

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: I thought I would have to go through some pairing process like remotes of old.  All I had to do was put in batteries and point it at the TV.  Worked instantly, no pairing process at all.  Buttons are very fast and responsive.  Excellent replacement.  The design is basically a direct replacement of the OEM.

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: Works well enough and is very affordable. My only complaint is it was not assembled very well from the factory so one of the buttons on the remote was stuck so as soon as you would put batteries into it it would try to change apps on the tv. I disassembled it and realigned everything and it worked okay.

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: ROKU TV easy battery install and connect. Perfect...

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: Love it! Super affordable for a two pack and so far seems great quality. I didn’t know how it connected to my Roku but I just put batteries and it immediately connected! Works perfectly.

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: Who knew finding the perfect replacement remote would feel like winning the lottery? This little gem is not only super affordable, but it’s also ridiculously easy to use – even for someone like me who’s tech-challenged!But the real magic? It has somehow survived the terror that is my household: two kids who treat remotes like footballs and a dog with an appetite for, well, everything. I’ve lost count of how many times our old remotes have been chewed to bits or mysteriously disappeared into the black hole under the couch. But this one? Still going strong (fingers crossed).If you need a remote that can withstand the chaos of children, pets, and life in general, this one’s for you. Plus, at this price, I don’t even mind when it inevitably takes a dive into the dog’s mouth.Highly recommend – just wish I had found it sooner!

product_name: (Pack of 2) Replacement Remote Control Only for Roku TV, Compatible for TCL Roku/Hisense Roku/Onn Roku/Philips Roku Smart TVs(Not for Stick and Box)
description: Our doggo loves to find our remotes and destroy them 🙂‍↕️. These replacement remotes are very easy to use and connected to the TV right away. They are fairly durable, I wouldn’t say tough but not going to fall apart if you drop it off the couch. The buttons function well and I love the colored buttons on the front for Netflix, Hulu, YouTube, and Disney.  We are very happy with these, and plan to order more if we lose them to our furry baby, lol.

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: Pros:• Excellent Sound - Given they're open-ear headphones, they have excellent sound quality. They didn't sound like open-ear headphones at all.• Light - I barely felt them on my ears, I tested them for 5+ hours and they didn't bother my ears like others (Airpods/Pro's) do.•Cons:• Price - Not worth $300. With connection issues and lacking features such as auto pause/play when putting them on and taking them off, clunky volume adjustments.• Connectivity - Each time I put them on, it took a few tries for them to recognize they should be synced and playing music together. Most of the time I had one playing music, then the other wouldn't ever catch up. So I had to put them back in their case and start over.• Battery Life Indicator - You'll NEVER know the actual battery life of the case. You can look in the manual to see what the colored lights mean, but those are just an approximation. Unless they do some an update, there was no way to tell the case battery life. I believe they speak the battery % when you first put the headphones on, I'm not 100% sure about that.I REALLY wanted to love these, and I did, but I couldn't justify the cost for what I was getting. First off, the sound quality was excellent. These were my first Bose headphones, and I expected the sound quality to be subpar, (I've used other open-ear headphones, 3 versions of SHOKZ) being they're open-ear, but the sound was the BEST thing about these. I tested the "spatial/immersive audio," it was trippy at first - cool use of technology, but I don't think I'd ever need/want that. I continued playing around in the app for a bit to learn the features and the button presses, which aren't inherent, so you'll have to look them up to find out what they are. More times than not, I would have connection issues. I'd put them on and they wouldn't sync together and play music, only one would be playing. I had to fully remove both of them, drop them in the case, and start over to get them to work again, or open the app, disconnect them, and reconnect them. It was a hassle and shouldn't be happening with a $300 product, especially from Bose. Also, the audio would intermittently pop or disconnect for a second on one or both of the earbuds. I don't feel like a $300 product should be doing this.That said, if these earbuds were in the $200 range, I would've considered keeping them. I think they're an excellent proof-of-concept product, but they still need more refinements to be charging $300 for them.

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: I chose these after really really disliking the update to the Jaybird Vistas (the newest version did not hold up to the originals), and I've got to say they are a work of genius. Somebody at Bose has a brain that's too big for their skull, because these are a truly incredible concept... That almost work.It was very obvious from the time that I played the first song that something wasn't quite right with the sound quality. Going in, I thought the bass was going to be an issue because that was a topic that came up in a lot of the reviews I read. The bass was pretty good, but the range a snare sits in (not a audio tech) was really really bad. The sound is just overall lacking a wholeness and life that in the ear headphones just don't have an issue with. I don't know if this is an issue with the headphones though, as it might just be an inhering flaw with with this style. I would say it feels like Bose really knocked it out of the park with the engineer and design here, but the ceiling for sound quality here is too low for them to be excellent.I think I didn't pay enough attention to the reviews that essitially said "for $300, no," because that's pretty much the conclusion I came to after less than an hour.It's tough, because the incredible engineering and design behind them make me want to like it, but ultimately I don't think I could ever enjoy my music with these.A side note: people can hear what you're listening to while you have these in, which I don't think I saw anyone talk about. If you're thinking of also using these in like a quite office setting, do not get this. Unless you don't like your coworkers... Then these might be a good investment. These basically turn you into a very soft a quite speaker, which is really cool, but also kind of annoying.

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: The Bose Ultra Open Earbuds offer an innovative take on wireless audio with their open-ear design, delivering exceptional sound quality while allowing users to remain aware of their surroundings. This design is perfect for those who want to stay connected to the world without sacrificing their listening experience. The sound quality is clear and balanced, providing a premium audio experience, especially in quieter settings. Additionally, the open-ear format avoids the discomfort of traditional earbuds, making them a great option for those who find in-ear buds to be intrusive.However, there are a few areas for improvement. The "one size fits all" design doesn’t work well for everyone, particularly for those with larger ears. Many users report difficulty in achieving a comfortable fit, often experiencing pinching and discomfort, especially during extended use. Bose has acknowledged this issue, but it remains a concern for potential buyers. Furthermore, while the sound quality is excellent in quiet environments, the audio volume can feel insufficient in outdoor or noisy settings, making it hard to fully enjoy your music. Another drawback is that the battery drain is inconsistent between the two earbuds, with one often depleting faster than the other when both are used simultaneously.Overall, the Bose Ultra Open Earbuds excel in delivering high-quality sound with an innovative design, but they may not be the best fit for those with larger ears or for use in louder environments.

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: I do a lot of biking/running outside, and also don't do well with objects lodged in my ear canal. These headphones were a godsend for me, despite the inflated price. I use them for anything that doesn't require sound isolation (i.e. Airplane) and they're super comfortable.The pros....- Super comfortable- Sound quality is pretty good- Battery life is pretty good, although not best in class- Physical buttons are reliable- Aesthetics..... I think they look awesomeThe cons...- Case feels pretty cheap/loose, especially for the price- Mics aren't great. They seem to go in and out on calls. May be due to my defective unit- Could be louder, but honestly not a requirement- Durability/quality control/warranty (read below)I'm knocking them down 3 stars because after a few months of use, I started to run into issues charging them, and audio in the right bud will simply stop working for hours at a time. No combination of factory reset/repairing helps. After talking to support they agreed to send me a warranty replacement, but they don't do advanced replacements, so i need to send these in first. They also told me that due to warranty centers moving (or maintenance?), it may take up to 8-10 weeks after they receive the buds before I receive the replacements.I'll likely give the Soundcore C30i's a shot since i'll be without this style of headphones for a while and can't afford to drop another 299 for another pair. If i could go back, i would probably have simply got the Soundcore's. I knew 299 was steep, but assumed there would be a good warranty process in place. Only myself to blame. Very unhappy with this turn of events.I love this style of bud, and hope we see more in the future at reasonable prices. ANC would also be an awesome addition, but i know most rely pretty heavily on physical sound isolation, so I wouldn't expect much there.

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: first off, these are open earbuds and the point is to be able to hear things going on around you. i'm sure they're good for jogging, biking and all the stuff they advertise. personally, i got them for work where a lot of things are frequently happening around me and i have to be aware of my surroundings and communicate with coworkers. they work great for this in general even if you have to turn them down a bit or simply click one of the buttons once to pause and hear someone (love the button controls over touch controls 5/5 on that) . for this i give them a 5/5 they live up to what i was expecting.comfort? they don't move once i put them on. i feel them but they don't bug me at all (unlike ones that have the thing that wraps around behind your ear). 5/5extra features like wireless charging and "Immersive" audio and all that? i don't care so i won't rate those. i only used the app to bass boost these (and i would suggest bass boosting these because they kinda need it).sound? don't expect much for bass. it's there. especially at lower volumes in quieter situations but it's never really strong. but for not being inserted into your ears, these do deliver an overall solid and enjoyable sound. at volumes below 50%, i hear a good amount of dynamics and just enough low end (with bass boost). over 50% it's pretty much mids and treble but enjoyable mids and treble. considering the design of these, i feel like these deserve about a 3/5 and i find them fun to listen to because it's different than what i hear with silicone eartip earbuds or over-ear headphones. it's also the first time i've ever purchased a Bose product and although this might not be the ideal showcasing, i do enjoy the sound signature.looks? i think they look coolprice? although i like these and don't mind them costing a bit more, i think these should probably be around like $150 instead of $300 as they are at this time. i like the fit of these and how they just clip on your earlobe. and if you don't mind paying a bit more, these are pretty good. if you wanna get the bang for your buck, i'm not the expert on open earbuds but i've seen that many other great options are out there for around $150 but they wrap around the back of your ear unfortunately. i'm giving the pricing a 2/5overall, i'm happy with them but i feel they are overpriced. 3/5

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: Loved that these rested in the ear cuff. The concept is great! Very comfortable! The problem is that everyone can hear whatever it is you’re listening to, which means they can hear your phone calls as well.The video that Bose uses to give you an idea of sound leakage is not accurate. If you are about 50%, in volume, others can hear. 30% will give leakage, just not as bad but it would be enough to irritate those around you. If you tend to listen to music or whatever at the 30 to 50% level, this is not for you. Depending on the movie you may be watching, you may have to turn up the volume for that movie, which will give sound leakage.These cannot be used in a library but a louder setting, like if you were in a dining hall or where there is outside noise that the sound leakage would be fine, walking to the train!I will say this, if you are not concerned with sound leakage or other’s listening to your calls, these are for you. The sound is incredible! But, I will say that the over the ear canal may be better. I am checking out the Lenovo erazer.I do see others that are similar to these, where they rest over the ear canal. I think if they offered a partial in ear, that would be a huge seller. Returned these for the Bose QuietComfort Ultra Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds, Bluetooth Noise Cancelling Earbuds with Spatial Audio and World-Class Noise Cancellation, Moonstone Blue - Limited Edition Color. We will see later on today!

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: Music:You can use the left and right independently, a huge plus. You have to adjust the speaker in your ear as close as you can to your ear canal to get good sound. They are as advertised open so you can hear the music and surrounds. Not to much to say besides don't expect super great quality as you would from in ear earbuds but or sounds good enough.Call quality:Iet me put it this way you can get better call quality from earbuds that released 8 years ago. They're that bad! Bose always seems to come up short in the call quality in the microphone for some reason in earbuds. You sound like you are talking in a tunnel, idk I am going to wait for the gen 2 or until Bose decides to stop buying microphones from the dollar store.Battery:Not much to say besides it depends on if you use both ears and you will get 8 hrs if you use one ear at a time then you can extend the battery even longer.Comfort:These are comfortable for the most part but there is a snug feeling to them that you have to get a custom to. They take a while to get the feel of them.  At first I caught myself wearing them maybe 2 to 3 hrs before my outside of my ears got sore from the snug fit. But I feel if I would of been more patient at the same time I could of got longer duration.Overall:I had to return them, I wanted more the complete bundle when I get earbuds.. The call quality was so bad all they are used for is listening to music. For that much you might as well spend another 150 and get the bose Ultra Headphones and get the complete package just my opinion. I am going to wait for the gen 2 to see if bose actually fixes the mic in call quality.

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: Let’s start with the bad:When talking to someone, the volume fades in and out. People your talking to can’t hear you, or they say you sound far away and your going in and out. The music quality is good, however the bass don’t hit like other Bose products. The bass just isn’t there. The connection is like any other Bluetooth , however, when Bose disconnects from my phone, I have to forget the device and pair it over and over.The good:The range of the Bose earbuds are great. The battery life is spot on. I had them on all day listening to music land trying to talk on them. Durability is fantastic. They have a very comfortable fit, barely feel them on your ear. The design is great, I’m overly tired of the buds on my ear all day, so this would have been perfect for me.OverallNot Worth the money. I love Bose and have invested into a lot of their accessories, but they dropped the ball on this one.I received these as a birthday gift on 8/17 and now I’m returning on 8/20.Need to do better

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: did not expect these to sound as good as they did. once you put them on you don't feel that they are there and they don't slip off or come loose. obviously they are not meant to block out noise but they do go pretty loud. i listen to music while working everyday and so far they are great and really like. i had the first gen Samsung buds and they were amazing.using these for talking on the phone are a downgrade compared to the buds, the other person on the line said i sounded like i was in a tunnel every time i was using them.if you care about sound quality for music then these will disappoint, but for it being open ear they are not bad.these have a weird affect on me like when i switch to the fold. i never wanna use any other phone.i tried going back to my buds but i always ended up missing these and always switch backthese are absolutely not worth the price in my opinion. case is not wireless charging, you have to pay an extra $50 to get that on there website. I've never used wireless charging to charge the case but any other earbuds close to this price point has that including noise canceling which these aren'ti used amazon points to get these, so if you happen to find these at a good discount highly recommend but not for $300.Update: these stopped working for phone calls, no one can hear or sound extremely far away. Had someone else try them and they did sound terrible or didn't work at all.

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: I purchased exclusively for running. When running, they “bounce” up and down and give the sensation of tugging on the ear. It’s not painful and they wont fall out, but it’s very annoying and distracting. I think to fix this the headphones either need to weigh less or have some sort of adjustability on the piece that wraps behind the ear (to allow for a more secure “clamp” on the ear). These are very much “one size fits all” earbuds - so I think the experience will vary from person to person.  For all the reviews saying “you’ll forget you have them on”, I found the exact opposite to be true. I think these have so much potential - I love the idea of open earbuds, I give Bose credit for the innovative design, but as of now these are, in my opinion, objectively bad for running.

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: Usually I say they are good for what it’s worth.  In this case, for what I paid for them, they are not worth it.Pro’s:  the ear clip/cuff design is different and good, the fit is pretty secure and won’t fall off, comfortable, immersive sound is a plus, turning off the immersive sound and they last  longer between charges.  When running I hardly noticed I had them on my ears.  The sound was good when I was running.  I noticed as I was running that the music got louder.  I think it was because they settled onto my ear lobes and also I turned the automatic volume control.Cons: too expensive, can’t adjust to being closer to ear canal, left me wanting and expecting more from the ear cuff buds.  They seem limited when turning them up to 7 or 8 on the flat setting.  Should be priced around the sound core and shokz open fit buds price, maybe even pricing them lower like $125-$150 on the high end.  For $300 they should have wireless charging, multi point connectivity.  Most of all a larger and louder volume level.  I’m returning them.  My aftershockz aeropex bone conduction headphones do a better job and lasts my whole 10 hour workday without needing to be charged.Maybe another software update with automatic multipoint switching, adjust the eq curve to have more low end and not cap the bass when playing at a higher volume, and drop the price and they would an awesome product.Update 3/12/2024So I returned my first pair of ultra earbuds, and got a set of Shokz open fit earbuds.  I tried those on for some time and really like how they performed overall.  But somehow I started to miss the bose earbuds, and wanted to compare how they went up against the Shokz offering.  The price is still steep, but I had an amazon gift card balance of $157 so I went ahead and bought the Bose to do the comparison.The fit was excellent as before, the sound is excellent, I registered them to get the two year nose warranty as I can see these being replaced sometime in September the future.  The Shokz are really good and probably rank them as one of the best hook buds in the market.  For me and my ears, the Bose and the Shokz are an excellent buy.  They both are light and fitment is excellent, the sound is superb, the call quality I give to Shokz, the update happened to both and somehow the call quality on the bose really improved.  I still prefer the physical button over the touch sensitive approach that Shokz went with.  I still like the Bose ear cuff design vs the earhook.  So which do I prefer.  Running and exercising-Bose without a doubt, mountain biking and any sport with a lot of wind noise-Shokz hands down.3/19/2024I started noticing the Bose ultra open buds starting to lose connection when putting them on.  The right ear would get the connected prompts, but the left would not connect and when it does connect, it loses drops connection a couple of time more than connects and syncs up with the right ear.  I’m going to request for a replacement pair.  Overall, these are excellent buys if you have a gift card balance to buy down these buds.  The Shokz were on sale so I returned my black pair and got the white pair.  I had some Amazon credits and used those credits to buy the Shokz at much lower price.3/29/2024Bose pushed an update to the open ultras (version 1.10.4).  The audio sounded clearer, the connection issue seems to have been resolved, I noticed while doing yard work that my Bose lasted approximately 5 hours on the immersion setting.  No multipoint connectivity like the Shokz open fits have.  Also,  I saw that Bose released a wireless charging case on their website for $50.  I decided to not get the wireless charging case because I was already used to the usb-c plug approach.

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: Let's get the fashion piece out of the way, first. I am *not* one for fashion. Black T-shirt and olive shorts is my daily "uniform". It is interesting, and surprising, that many people thought that these ear buds were a fashion statement. Not me.Now on to the actual good stuff. Compared to the Shokz OpenRun Pro, these Bose ear buds are expensive. Oh, yeah, no denying that. However, at the same time the fit, comfort, and sound quality are also much better, at least for me.I wear glasses, the OpenRun Pro will fit, but there is always the constant adjustment because both the OpenRun Pro and the glasses want to rest on the same place. The Bose Ultra Open does not interfere, at all. The Bose Ultra Open earbuds are more comfortable and convenient.In terms of sound quality, there is no comparison. When I first got the OpenRun Pro, it was a vast improvement over the much older Shokz. The Bose Ultra Open earbuds are something else. One problem that I had with the OpenRun Pro is the placement of the sound emitters. A very slight shift in position caused left-right imbalance. The Ultra Open earbuds do not have this issue, at least on my ears. Also, at higher volumes, the OpenRun Pro had some scratching sounds, probably because the transducers were mechanically rubbing or contacting the casing.In comparison, the *one* thing that the OpenRun Pro is superior is battery life. I can wear it all day, and it does not run out of battery. The Ultra Open earbuds, however, will need a little charging break during the day. However, carrying the case with me makes a quick recharge a breeze.How good is the sound? I am no HiFi aficionado, and definitely not a purist. I can say this: in a quiet office, I now prefer the Ultra Open to a pair of wired IEMs that connect to a dedicated amp. I did not even have to tweak the equalizer in the Bose app.For an open earbud that just hangs on to the ear lobes, the Ultra Open is impressive in terms of sound quality and battery life.

product_name: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds, Immersive Audio Open Ear Earbuds, Clip on Earbuds for Comfort, Running Earbuds with OpenAudio for Awareness, Up to 48 Hours of Battery Life, Black
description: I purchased these because my ears often get sore when wearing earbuds that press into the ear canal or the inner edge of the ear. I wanted to try something that didn’t go in to my ear at all and these looked enticing. I held off for a while because I saw the reviews about them not being loud enough at times and it made me nervous. I also didn’t want them in white or black.  When the blue color came out, I decided to give them a try.Most of the time, I’m very happy with them. They are extremely comfortable and the fit is exactly what I was hoping for. When I’m listening to audio books at home, I have no problems with the volume. The battery life is excellent and they charge quickly.There are 3 things that are keeping me from loving them. For whatever reason, phone volume is completely different from listening volume. I can be listening to a book or music and have the volume at 75% and hear perfectly. Then, someone will call and I will turn the volume up to 100% and still not be able to hear them very well. I have also found that people on the phone have a hard time hearing me too.The third thing that I do not like is that they don’t have ear sensors that tell them when the earbud is in your ear. I have two other sets of earbuds that detect when they’re in the ear and then they connect to the phone. I didn’t realize how much I liked this feature until I didn’t have it. This is annoying when the earbud accidentally gets knocked out of my ear and my book continues to play whereas with my other earbuds, it would stop when it sensed it wasn’t in my ear anymore.
