Once the cartridges are recognized, then the print heads were easy to align.* The HP Smart wizard was very simple and seemed straight forward to me.* Once the printer was on the Wi-Fi, it was very easy for all devices in our household to connect.* Unfortunately, I missed the time limit sign up for HP+ which, their service that includes 3 months of Instant Ink and an extra year warranty. You have to sign up within 7 days of setup.Usage:1. On first activation, the printer takes a few moments to align the printer cartridges. This may seem loud in a very quiet room. After the first time, I expected the setup noise.2. My power cord seems a bit touchy. A slight bump and the printer turns off. I'm going to try a cord replacement since it is a standard type.3. The control panel has a fantastic pivot option. You can adjust it to better and operate the panel. No more neck strain from reading the panel.Overall, I'm enjoying the print speed and quality with the HP OfficeJet Pro 9120e Series. I can't wait to see what else it is capable of once I get comfortable with the machine.

product_name: HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e All-in-One Printer, Color, Printer-for-Small Medium Business, Print, Copy, scan, fax,Touchscreen; Smart Advance Scan, 3 months of Instant Ink included
description: HP did a great job with packaging this printer! Although a compact size for the printing job it performs, it is bigger than other printers I have owned and it was incredibly easy to remove it from its box. The printer was bagged with handles to pull out with when the box is on its side. No having to hassle with the box versus the printer. The printer is beautiful - I love the look of it. It looks modern and sleek. The instructions that came with were very straightforward and easy to follow during set up and ink installation. I typically only use the print feature as I print a lot of labels daily. I do use the scan and copy feature every now and then. It was easy to figure out how to use those features (which on other printers I've used they are not that intuitive). The printer quality on the paper is great! The ink lines are crisp making it easy to read or look at. In my particular case, I have no problems when scanning the labels with tiny lines in the barcodes. It prints very quickly and holds a lot of paper. The only drawbacks of the printer I encountered is that it is a bit noisy while printing, but I have yet to discover a printer that isn't noisy since it's a machine. Also the ink replacement cartridges are a bit pricey compared to what I was using. I was using ink that was refillable and could print thousands of sheets without refilling.

product_name: HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e All-in-One Printer, Color, Printer-for-Small Medium Business, Print, Copy, scan, fax,Touchscreen; Smart Advance Scan, 3 months of Instant Ink included
description: This HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e is a good printer and scanner, but everything about its connectivity is just frustrating. It took 7 tries to get it set up and connected to the internet. The first 5 tries were over WiFi where it became unresponsive after continuing setup in the HP Smart app. I got it almost done with ethernet connectivity but it disconnected after I declined the HP+ limitations. Trying one last time over ethernet I got it to work. After about 45 minutes, I was finally able to print something. This color inkjet does a great job with text and image, coming out perfectly sharp and smudge-free. Because it's an inkjet, it's surprisingly loud compared to the HP Laserjet 2600n that I used before. The print speed is faster than my old HP Laserjet. With the print head moving rapidly back and forth, this printer shakes a lot while printing. While using the ADF, it's the loudest I've heard on an all-in-one printer. The scan was a tinge slow, but the quality was phenomenal. The scans came out perfectly straight and legible. It's painful to set up but once you get it going, it works perfectly for an inkjet and I haven't had any issues after setting it up. Overall, I'd give this a 4-star recommendation, especially considering how this model is priced.

product_name: HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e All-in-One Printer, Color, Printer-for-Small Medium Business, Print, Copy, scan, fax,Touchscreen; Smart Advance Scan, 3 months of Instant Ink included
description: I first printed a recipe, which printed fine. Next, I looked at my pics in the hp app. I clicked on 2 to print. I hit the button, and they instantly shot out. My mouth flew open, and I questioned how? I had just clicked the button! My husband and I were amazed with the quality. Our old printer of another brand never prints anywhere close to that good or nearly as fast. It would have taken much much longer to print them on our old printer. My husband set it up on his phone. Then, he printed our insurance cards and a ticket to a show. They both printed quickly. I was messing around in the hp app, and printed some cards and coloring pages. They all printed in great quality. I've since printed more recipes, some vet records, and other papers. I'm loving the quality and quickness. I'm not sure how the whole paying for ink monthly will work. I'm not sure if it'll be cheaper or not. Our old printer didn't have the option to print on 2 sides. We haven't had one of those in yrs, so I like that we have that option back in the house. I forgot when I was printing recipes that I had that option again. I guess I'll have to print them again if I want them double sided. My daughter will be using it lots to print stuff for school. It was very easy to use the screen then the app to follow setup steps. It prints better than my old printer but the cost is cheaper. I don't know how. I say it's a good value for the money. I haven't had it long enough to see how well it will function over time but for now it is working great. It came with 3 months of free ink and 1 month of free paper. I've already received both in the mail. I canceled the paper, but it says I will be billed for October, even though there is still plenty of time before then. If I get billed for a month I won't be using the paper option I won't be happy. That makes me believe, if you end up canceling the ink, you'll still get billed. I don't think you should be if you cancel it early enough like I did on the paper. If I get billed for paper I won't receive for the following month I will cancel the ink. I will not support that. The weight of the printer isn't too bad. I'm able to pick it up myself and move it.Overall, if you print lots of normal random stuff like I do, I think you'll like this printer. I'm amazed with the pictures, and they weren't even on picture paper! I've got a cricut, so I can't wait to see how well it prints stuff for my cricut when I need stuff printed.

product_name: HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e All-in-One Printer, Color, Printer-for-Small Medium Business, Print, Copy, scan, fax,Touchscreen; Smart Advance Scan, 3 months of Instant Ink included
description: I had a really old printer basically just prints. The quality wasn't there but it did a job until I had kids. I needed a print their school documents, assignments, and birthday party invitations etc. I often had to run to FedEx or any store with printing services, so they were legible. I finally decided to buy a new printer and did my research and picked the HP 9125e printer because it had great reviews. I am not a techy person and was dreading to set up the printer. Surprisingly it was so easy! HP 9125e printer comes with small screen that walks you through steps by steps. It also comes with a QR code that walks you through the set-up processes. It connects to Wi-Fi so I don't have to use or buy a USB drive to print! The size of the printer is just right. Not too bulky and fits right into the corner of our office. I was amazed how fast it prints and the picture quality is also incredible--even in color. I used this printer to make a copy of a document, and the copy was crisper than the original. No more lines between the pictures and it prints so effortlessly.

product_name: HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e All-in-One Printer, Color, Printer-for-Small Medium Business, Print, Copy, scan, fax,Touchscreen; Smart Advance Scan, 3 months of Instant Ink included
description: This printer worked perfectly for my household. Setting it up was easy and took no time at all. Between the smart app and the manual, it was ready to go in mere minutes. After that, sending prints to it was easy and it came out fairly fast. I had no problems using my phone to send prints. Adding the printer to my laptop was easy and it worked as it should.  One great feature is that it can send scans directly to an email, wirelessly to a computer, the HP mobile app. There is a slight pause when doing double sided scanning but it came out okay. The print quality is nice. It color matches very well. If you're doing a lot of color pages it also has a dry setting.

product_name: HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e All-in-One Printer, Color, Printer-for-Small Medium Business, Print, Copy, scan, fax,Touchscreen; Smart Advance Scan, 3 months of Instant Ink included
description: I wasn't expecting a lot from the OfficeJet Pro 9125e. I've had several other home printers in the past, including a laser printer (great because it uses dry toner which doesn't have the issues an inkjet printer typically has, but is only able to print black and white). I've had several inkjet printers, but they all end up having clogged print heads or something that renders them useless after a short amount of time. I thought I'd give this a try, as it could replace my other printers.It's meant for a small office, as it has pretty high duty cycles. I don't print a lot; usually recipes, legal documents, and coupons. I may start printing some newsletters for an organization I'm in, so this may work out well. It can print borderless pages, which would make some nice newsletters!Setting up the printer was fairly straight-forward. The printer was packaged nicely, in a bag with a handle that allows you to pull it from the box easily. The included quick-start guide tells you to plug it in, turn it on, select a language and country, and then go to a URL to set the printer up on your computer or phone wirelessly.The first step is to open the paper tray and load the paper. Adjusting the paper tray for letter-sized paper was a bit confusing, as there are little tabs you have to press to adjust the size of the paper tray. It wouldn't shrink down to the size of the paper, so I just pushed the paper all the way to the back and pushed the tray in. The printer then said it was checking the paper, and said it was successfully loaded.Installing the ink went fine.Then it wants to print an alignment page. Once printed, you put it on the scanner bed, and it scans. That went fine as well.Finally, install HP Smart Printing on the computer and scan for new printers. It didn't find it on the first try, but did on the second. Connecting was quick and easy. It even got the wifi password from the computer. Once connected it automatically updated the firmware. I didn't realize it, so I tried printing something and couldn't. Then the printer chimed and said the firmware was updated.Print quality is fantastic, as is the speed of printing. I enrolled in the HP+ and Instant Ink trial. I got an email saying my new ink cartridges were being shipped, even though I don't need them yet. I'll probably cancel the Instant Ink after the trial, as I don't print a lot, but it may be worthwhile for people/offices that do. Time will tell if the print heads last. Hopefully!

product_name: HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e All-in-One Printer, Color, Printer-for-Small Medium Business, Print, Copy, scan, fax,Touchscreen; Smart Advance Scan, 3 months of Instant Ink included
description: I was delighted to purchase my HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e after my previous reliable HP Officejet Pro 8625 grew too old and tired after many years of dedicated service. After unboxing the printer, the setup was super straightforward and seamless, and the touchscreen interface is very intuitive for all ages. Also, compared to my old HP, the printer is smaller and was able to fit on a shelf which the previous printer was too big for. The biggest selling point for me was everything you get for the price. Copying, scanning, faxing, and of course printing. I frequently have to print and scan documents at my WFH job, and this makes my day to day much simpler with how easy the printer is to use.The first thing I did after plugging in the printer was setup wireless printing. It was a breeze to connect to my home wifi with the 2.7in touchscreen. Navigation of the settings is quick and efficient. After that, I did some test printing of hotel reservations for an upcoming trip. What surprised me was the speed of the printer and how well the pages looked for printing so fast. I am very impressed with the print quality and there are absolutely no complaints with the result. Additionally, setting up the HP Smart app on my phone impressed me. It was able to find my printer in just a few seconds and I was printing only a few minutes after downloading the app. This is something a non-tech person would have no problem in setting up as well. Additionally, the printer has many functions like faxing, scanning, and copying. I scan a lot when I have to use a handwritten signature and there are more options than I would ever imagine in how to scan and where to send the result. I love the flexibility that comes with the entire HP printer solution. The connectivity between the mobile app has changed how I print because my previous printer was getting too old to even connect properly to the internet. I really love this printer, and it is exceptional for the price. I highly recommend it to anyone who needs an easy-to-use printer for everyday home and business needs.Lastly, the 3 months of printing that comes with the printer is a big bonus! No need to ever worry about ink if you subscribe to Instant Ink after the 3 months too.

product_name: HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e All-in-One Printer, Color, Printer-for-Small Medium Business, Print, Copy, scan, fax,Touchscreen; Smart Advance Scan, 3 months of Instant Ink included
description: The HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e stands out as an exceptional choice for high-traffic home offices, seamlessly combining efficiency, advanced features, and affordability. With the ever-increasing demands of remote work and hybrid working setups, a reliable and fast printer is essential. The OfficeJet Pro 9125e fits this role perfectly, offering a balance of robust performance, high-quality output, and a range of modern features designed to meet the needs of a busy home office. ### Speed and Efficiency One of the first aspects that make the HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e a great option for high-traffic environments is its impressive print speed. Capable of printing up to 24 pages per minute (ppm) for black and white documents and 20 ppm for color, this printer can handle large print jobs without significant delays. This speed is crucial for home offices that need to print a high volume of documents on a regular basis, such as reports, presentations, or marketing materials. The fast two-sided printing (automatic duplexing) feature further enhances efficiency, reducing paper use while speeding up large print jobs. The 9125e’s 35-page automatic document feeder (ADF) adds another layer of convenience for multitasking users, enabling quick scanning, copying, or faxing of multipage documents. Coupled with its 250-sheet input tray, this printer minimizes the need for constant refilling, making it well-suited for high-volume tasks. ### Print Quality Despite its speed, the HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e does not compromise on print quality. With a resolution of up to 1200 x 1200 dpi (dots per inch) for black and 4800 x 1200 dpi for color, the printer consistently delivers crisp and vibrant results. Whether you're printing text-heavy documents or detailed graphics, the output maintains professional quality. This makes the 9125e not only ideal for standard office documents but also for marketing materials, presentations, and more visually demanding tasks that require accurate color representation. ### Smart Features and Connectivity What sets the OfficeJet Pro 9125e apart from many other home office printers is its integration with HP’s innovative smart features. The printer is equipped with HP’s Smart App, allowing users to print, scan, and copy directly from their smartphone or tablet, regardless of location. This feature is essential for busy professionals who need to manage print jobs on the go. In summary, the HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e is a fantastic printer.

product_name: HP OfficeJet Pro 9125e All-in-One Printer, Color, Printer-for-Small Medium Business, Print, Copy, scan, fax,Touchscreen; Smart Advance Scan, 3 months of Instant Ink included
description: 5/5 - The printer arrived fast from Amazon and was packaged nicely. No concerns with delivery or packaging. Product box arrived totally undamaged and product was easy to unpack, had minimal packing garbage which I liked. Set: 2/5 - It it very rare these days that setup with a new product goes smoothly. This setup was no exception. At first I was excited there was a QR code to scan to provided step by step instructions and that is about where my excitement for the setup ended. I could barley get past step 1 which was loading the paper (pro tip: don't push the paper all the way into the printer, push the paper towards you so it is flush with the edge of the outer drawer). Step two was equally frustrating where I had to load the ink, I am not sure if what I did was what was needed but after I installed the ink I had to move the cartridge around in order to get past the error in setup. Step 3 again had some snags with the alignment, it wouldn't align so I turned off the printer and turned it back on and it worked. The final step was also met with many issues. During the software setup I had to close and restart the APP multiple times which was frustrating but I made it! Printing: 4.9 - Love the fast printing with options to print from USB or any WifI connected device. Also love that this has the ability to print double-sided pages (an upgrade from my previous OfficeJet). No complaints on the color printing, looks pretty standard. My only complaint is the limited page size compatibility, would love to be able to print on larger pieces of paper. Scanning/Copying: 5/5 - Copying from the unit works as expected, nothing special to note. I LOVE how you can scan from you phone through the APP, that is a great feature I will use often. Longevity: TBD - I haven't had this long enough to say how it will hold up or how long the ink lasts. They do have a program where you can paper per month per page for ink that seems reasonable if you don't want to run out of ink, my printing is too sporatic to justify a monthly plan. APP: 4/5 - Knocking points off for my setup experience. Otherwise I like how it measure ink levels

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: Pros1) El artículo es estéticamente muy lindo, fino y elegante, lo mismo su cobertor y su lápiz.2) Se prende rápido comparado con mi OnyxCons1) La textura de la pantalla no es tan rugosa como podría ser un Wacom, pero mejor que un iPad.2) La batería dura bastante pero se me ha apagado sin aviso previo. O sea, no tiene un indicador que prevenga de conectar.3) El protector es muy delicado, el lápiz queda apegas sujetado del mismo, y se me ha salido apenas con el roce de la  mochila  al guardarlo o sacarlo. También al moverlo fuera de la mochila. Muy poco seguro.4) El borrador no tiene la opción de borrar trazos, sin embargo el software utiliza trazos para guardar los dibujo, por lo que no lo hace no porque no puedan sino porque no quieren. El borrado de trazos es muy práctico en muchas ocasiones y lo tienen casi por defecto todos las app que conozco de dibujo salvo las antiguar app de dibujo por pixeles que ya ni sé si existen.5) No permite elegir la orientación de la pantalla, o sea que cuando se pone horizontal hay una sola forma horizontal. Eso es muy incómodo cuando se trabaja con el lápiz, porque éste queda sujeto en la parte de abajo, y si bien es magnético y se puede "pegar" al costado, dicho  "pegado" es débil y se sale fácil y peligrososamente (ver foto)6) El lápiz, luego de muy poco uso, comenzó a tener comportamiento extraños como ser detectado 1 cm de la pantalla. Lo arreglé sacando el "grafo"y volviéndolo a colocar. Pero fue muy extraño.7) No recuerda la posición original de una patanlla en modo horizontal, de modo que al ir hacia adelanta y luego volver, ¡cambia la posición de la hoja! algo increíblemente molesto e incómodo. A ver ese CEO si se pone las pilas!8) La suscripción al servicio "Connect" solo esta habilitado para algunos países, pero por ejemplo para ninguno de América del Sur, algo inaudito. Igual para lo que cobran y para el servicio que dan, no creo que me hubiera suscrito.9) Cuando se usa el lápiz remarcado y se exporta el documento a Dropbox, la página donde se haya usado el remarcado, sale toda oscura! una cosa increíble! pero cuando se comparte por email, la página sale correctamente.Now in English:Pros1) The item is aesthetically very nice, fine and elegant, as well as its cover and pencil.2) It turns on quickly compared to my OnyxCons1) The screen texture is not as rough as a Wacom could be, but better than an iPad.2) The battery lasts a long time but it turned off without warning. That is, it does not have an indicator that prevents it from connecting.3) The protector is very delicate, the pencil remains attached to it, and it has barely come off with the friction of the backpack when putting it away or taking it out. Also when moving it out of the backpack. Very unsafe.4) The eraser does not have the option to delete strokes, however the software uses strokes to save the drawings. Therefore, the engineers who designed the software did not offer that option not because they did not know how to do it but because they did not want to do it, for some reason that I cannot imagine. What it is is very frustrating. Erasing strokes is very practical on many occasions and almost all the drawing apps I know have it by default except for the old pixel drawing apps that I don't even know if they exist anymore.5) It does not allow you to choose the orientation of the screen, that is, when it is landscape mode there is only one landscape orientation. This is very uncomfortable when working with the pencil, because it remains attached to the bottom, and although it is magnetic and can be "stuck" to the side, the "stuck" is weak and comes off easily and dangerously (see photo )6) The pencil, after very little use, began to have strange behavior such as being detected 1 cm from the screen. I fixed it by taking out the pen tip and putting it back. But it was very strange.7) It doesn't remember the original position of a screen in landscape mode, so when you go forward and then backward, it changes the position of the blade! something incredibly annoying and uncomfortable: call  for the remarkable CEO…8) The subscription to the "Connect" service is only enabled for some countries, but for example for none in South America…9) When the highlighting pen is used and the document is exported to Dropbox, the page where the highlighting was used appears completely dark! an incredible thing! but when shared by email, the page appears correctly.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: First of all this item works very well (when it works)I have had this tablet for 9 months then it just froze while it was asleep.  Tried turning it off.  It wouldn’t turn off. Charged it by my laptop. Nothing…I got in contact with tech support via email and by the way this is the only to get in contact with them.  No phone calls at all.  The support team gave me a list things to do that might remedy the situation.  Nothing fixed it.  They wanted a video of the tablet to see what it is not doing.  PEOPLE IT WASNT DOING A DAMN THING. No video is needed. Be careful.  I will say again it works great until.  I have 1000’s of notes that I have now lost.  Completely threw my work off.  This company needs a phone number to be able to communicate.  So a 3 star is the max.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: I hope I am wrong but it doesn't seem to be worth the $500 price tag. It is simple and does exactly what it says on the tin. You can write on it and it will shows what you are writing. There is no backlight, color, or grayscale images. The pen is not touch sensitive harder or longer presses do not give darker lines so the images that look like drawing in the advertisements are difficult to accomplish.  They did texture the screen to make it feel somewhat like paper, that being said you won't confuse it for paper.The only semi-fancy part of it is the handwriting to text feature (which requires it to be online).It is on the heavy side, close to the weight of a medium sized college text book. I hope that means it is durable and will last a long time.Inputs using your finger are sluggish and may require multiple taps to register. The pen is better but still slow. This makes using the on-screen keyboard is difficult. Taking notes seems pretty responsive though.It works well for left handed people as you can choose if the menu is on the left or right.You can't download your files directly from the device to your computer using a USB cable, and you can only transfer the documents via their services (either online or email). I am afraid it will become useless in a few years when they shut down the servers and you can't get your files, or convert handwriting to text anymore.You can give them your credit card and sign up for their app to sync files between multiple devices. They currently have a 1 year free but it makes you feel as if this is their real product as it took me a while to figure out how not to sign up for the service. Just close the window.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: I got my Remarkable 2 in February and used it daily. I really do love it. The writing is smooth - a pleasure. I prefer to handwrite notes and it was a constant companion at work. My desk was nearly paper-free! I was getting the hang of improving my organization within the R2 with tags and separate notebooks... THEN Recently I got a 0% battery alert while working and plugged it in. It has never come back. I contacted support and tried all the suggestions. Now i have to ship it back for replacement. Since I've been researching, the R2 doesn't do well with fast chargers although I was not using one to charge it (it was plugged into a USB at my desk). Just FYI.Ok, these things happen. But the return process is really poor: I can only use DHL apparently, which is really, really inconvenient based on their locations. I don't feel like paying another carrier to ship this dead tablet to China so I'll be driving out of my way to DHL when any other shipping company would be no ttrouble. Given what I paid, what choice do I have?I now feel more tentative about relying on the replacement R2 for all my notes.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: I really like the remarkable 2 but it only stays in the case with a magnet that disconnects constantly.  I am currently at an airport to fly overseas and the stylus is not in the case.  I looked all over the airport but there are no compatible styluses so I will be at an all week conference with no way to use the pad.  This is far too expensive to have a design that makes losing the expensive stylus far too easy.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: Overall I am impressed by the Remarkable 2. It looks good, writing is a joy, and it is distraction-free. The price is high, but I feel that it is justified by how much better it is than the competition.My issue is that the device does not work well for left-handers. I actually bought this because it is the only current option that has a left-hand mode. But what does that "left-handed mode" actually DO? Some options that are, to me, purely cosmetic, are shifter over. Great.But infruriatingly they kep the little "x" in the top left, which immediately closes out the current document. That 'x' is exactly where I put my hand when starting off a fresh document, and where I frequently brush up against when writing on the top 1/3 or so of a page. No notes are lost, but I have to choose the right notebook again and find my place in the notes. Yes, I could re-learn the fundamentals of how I've written for 40 years, but it is easier to just give this away to a family member.My 2nd minor issue is that the OEM case/cover options need to have a place for the pen. Do NOT rely on the magnent to keep it in place in your bag or elsewhere - it may work for a while, but you will eventually lose it.I would recommend this for folks who write with their right hand, but for others - wait for a software update or competing product.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: The idea is good, but the device is very basic. The operating system is elementary, which makes it complicated to use if you have multiple folders. The level of synchronization is basic and makes it difficult to interact with other platforms. It seems like a good idea, but it lacks development.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: Don't get me wrong I like this thing a lot, it's neat however it has lots of problems.For staters it can be extremely unresponsive to gestures, mostly swiping up to make your page longer. Sometimes I have to swipe at it like 10 times to get it to scroll up. Sometimes I will write something and then a second later some of my writing will vanish.The most baffling thing is all the missing obvious features. Part of my hope with this was replacing my giant pile of graphing composition notebooks because I do a lot of drafting. You can format your pages as graph paper which would be perfect. Unfortunately there are pretty much no basic drawing tools. You can draw a straight line if you draw a line then pause until it straightens the line. It's awkward and only works about half the time.No circle tool, no rectangles, no squares, no polygon, no measuring. A set of basic drafting tools would make this thing worth every penny, if you need that.As it is I'd say about $200 would be realistic. The screen is very good and it does feel like writing on paper, kinda. I really like being able to throw a pdf on it and scribble on it. Also good for long advanced math problems.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: I like the idea of what the Remarkable 2 + its software is optimized to do - which is note taking.  I want something like that to take + organize project notes.  However the device is slow to respond to gestures, for example slow to respond to a one finger swipe up to get more space on a page.  The problem isn't that I'm working with a large document... each is just a few pages of hand-written text.  Overall, the Remarkable 2 mostly does what I need, but I'm disappointed at the sluggishness of the device.  This hardware has been out for years now, maybe the manufacturer should consider release of an updated device.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: The reMarkable 2 has been a game-changer for me, especially since I wasn’t familiar with paper tablets until recently. My journey started with the Kindle Scribe, which I initially bought for reading on a larger screen. Once I discovered the joy of note-taking on an E-Ink tablet, I delved deeper into the market and stumbled across the reMarkable 2, which is often hailed as one of the best in its category. That’s when I decided to give it a try, seeking a more refined, “paper-like” experience compared to the Kindle Scribe.Now, I’m absolutely hooked on the reMarkable 2, carrying it with me everywhere. The device fits seamlessly into my daily routine, but whenever colleagues ask about it, I give them this disclaimer: “I love it, but I’d never recommend it lightly.”The key here is that anyone interested in the reMarkable 2 must first do their homework. It’s essential to understand its specific use case and the design philosophy behind it. Unlike many gadgets that try to do everything fairly well, the reMarkable 2 is a specialized tool that excels at one thing—replicating the paper notebook experience digitally. For that, it’s nearly unparalleled.However, this specialization comes with trade-offs. The reMarkable 2 is highly focused and minimalist. It lacks many features that modern tablet users might take for granted: there’s no email access, no web browser, no third-party apps, and you won’t find social media or even a backlight for nighttime use. For some, this can feel like a “dumbed-down” tablet, especially given that at its price point, you could opt for an iPad or other E Ink tablets with more functionality. If you’re looking for a multi-purpose device, this might seem limiting and even frustrating.That said, the writing experience on the reMarkable 2 is where it shines. The textured E-Ink display combined with the Marker offers a tactile feel that closely mimics writing on paper. With pressure sensitivity and multiple pen options, it’s incredibly responsive, making it perfect for note-taking, sketching, and journaling. However, it may fall short for artists looking for a more versatile tool since the drawing features are limited compared to more advanced tablets.Where the reMarkable 2 does offer some digital conveniences is in its cloud syncing capabilities. With their Connect service (which costs $3/month after a free trial), you can sync your notes across devices, giving you access to your notebooks on your phone or computer. For me, this feature justifies the subscription cost because it adds an extra layer of productivity, allowing me to keep my notes organized and accessible anytime, anywhere.Ultimately, the reMarkable 2 is ideal for people who are looking for a distraction-free, premium notebook replacement that delivers on its promise of a paper-like experience. It’s elegant, well-built, and high quality, but it’s also designed for a very specific use case. If you’re someone who wants more functionality or expects a typical tablet experience, there are better alternatives in both the tablet and E-Ink markets. But if you value simplicity, focus, and a top-tier writing experience, the reMarkable 2 is the way to go.I personally use it daily and even bought one for my wife. But I also recognize that for some, it may not hit the mark. As I always say, do your research before committing to it.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: I wanted to work with this before writing a review. I've been using it for 5 months now and can say, unequivocally, that this is a great product.Writing experienceAs a pen aficionado, I've been surprised at how much I enjoy writing with this. I have the pen that erases. I'm on my second pen tip and use it almost daily, so it has pretty good 'tip life'. The writing experience is really nice. Took no adjustment on my part.The PlatformIt's easy to navigate. Easy to categorize and name documents and organize folders. I don't use the handwriting to text feature bc my writing doesn't translate well, so I can't comment on that. However, where before I was carrying around multiple notebooks for different areas of my life, now I have just one. One! And it contains my work notes, my construction notes, my volunteer work notes, PDFs that I've downloaded. Drawings I've made. It's so efficient. And I've never run out of battery life.SummaryI was concerned that I wouldn't take to this given my pen/paper fondness, but the Remarkable has truly delivered. This is not cheap, but well worth the investment thus far. I recommend it.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: I recently started a new job. The CEO got tired of misplaced or illegible notes, so the Remarkable 2 became a requirement for the Executive Team.I have a short attention span and habitually take notes during meetings/discussions, so I've always loved a good notebook. I was skeptical and a little annoyed when I was told a $500 "notebook" was a requirement for my new role. After a week of use, I'll never take notes on paper again.While it is a digital device, the Remarkable 2 isn't much more complicated than a legal pad. It's every bit as thin as a standard notepad, and the sensation of writing is surprisingly close to pen and paper. It wakes from sleep instantly, and and is surprisingly responsive.The ability to create and organize new notes is incredible, and navigating your library is fast and simple. There are so many templates I haven't had time to use a fraction of them. If you can't find a suitable template, you can create a PDF and upload it. Your notes are synced to your Remarkable account and can be viewed online in near real-time.The Remarkable 2 is expensive, but I find it worth the price. I no longer have to keep up with multiple notebooks, or flip through pages at the start of a meeting.My only complaints are that it charges very slowly and if you use it throughout the day every day like me, the battery life is less than impressive. Otherwise it's an excellent alternative to paper without the complications of a normal tablet.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: We purchased the reMarkable Starter Bundle, and we are loving it! The reMarkable 2 tablet is truly a revolutionary tool for anyone who enjoys writing or drawing.Pros:Paper-Like Experience: The 10.3” display feels just like writing on paper, which is fantastic for our note-taking and sketching.Marker Plus Pen: The included pen with a built-in eraser is a huge bonus. It glides smoothly across the surface, and the eraser function is super convenient.Lightweight and Portable: The tablet is slim and easy to carry, making it perfect for on-the-go use.Free Connect Trial: The trial period allows me to explore the cloud features without commitment, which is a nice touch.Cons:Limited App Integration: While it excels at note-taking, we wish it had more app options for enhanced functionality.Overall, we highly recommend the reMarkable Starter Bundle for anyone looking to combine the digital and analog worlds. It’s an excellent investment!

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: The Remarkable 2 tablet is truly exceptional. Its sleek design, combined with its paper-like display, provides a uniquely satisfying writing experience. The battery life is impressive, lasting for weeks on a single charge. The interface is intuitive and user-friendly, making it easy to organize notes and documents. Whether you’re a student, professional, or creative, the Remarkable 2 tablet is a game-changer for digital note-taking and sketching. Highly recommended.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: I am a non-gadget person. So, this was a gamble. I love it! I use this basically as an electronic notebook at work. I take notes about everything. I no longer have to drag around paper notebooks. I do not use many of the features, like convert to typed text or write on presentations. Only downloaded the notebooks a couple of times. But the ease of having different notebooks for projects all in one place is wonderful. And the feel of the writing is great. I have replaced the tips on the pen every 2 months. Use the eraser a ton. And move text in the notebook. The battery lasts 3-4 days, depending on use. Love this gadget!It does not have ways to mark items as “to do” within the notebooks. That would be ideal.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: This device is so lightweight and portable you won't believe it. There is a small learning curve and that was for me to write a bit bigger to allow for better accuracy when using the OCR function. When they say it is like writing on paper, they mean it! No slipping around like writing on other tablets. The battery life is exceptional! I've used it for a week now and the battery is still going strong. There are easy on screen prompts to make it easy to use as well as emails with tips to improve functionality. One of the templates puts automatic lines on the page so that things are more legible. The pen/pencil/stylus (not sure what to really call it) attaches magnetically to the tablet and unlike other devices, it stays in place even when putting it into a work bag or taking it out. I have yet to see it fall off. It is a bit pricy but I am thrilled with my purchase! This is the only device I will be handwriting on in the future.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: I hesitated because of price but this product has changed my work-life for the better. As an HR representative, I struggled with organizing notes, and I take notes on EVERYTHING. The tagging feature I absolutely revolutionary for me. I can keep all of my notes in one place, in a portable, light device that I can also link to my computer. I love porting over documents to take notes on.The pen options are perfect for a wide range of uses. It stays charged for a decent amount of time considering I am using it all day every day. I didn’t bother buying an expensive ReMarkable brand cover for it, so I got an inexpensive off brand one that works perfectly. The magnet feature on the pen has helps keep it from being misplaced. The eraser feature on the pen is amazing, too. It can be very precise, which is awesome.There are a couple of features that aren’t ideal for my uses. The first is the tip on the pen. The package includes extra tips, which is great but even when I’m consciously trying to write lightly, they wear out very quickly. There are off brand pen tips on the market but haven’t tried them yet.  Another feature I wish the device had was being able to move typed text around on a page. It’s more feasible in the app than on the actual device, but you can’t in real time move text to different spots in the page, which is not the end of the world but definitely frustrating.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: I got the e-pad for my daughter who is wanting to get organized and also likes to doodle. It took a couple minutes to set up, suggest pairing with an iPhone as that was much easier. Great choice and considering getting one for myself now.

product_name: Remarkable Essentials Bundle – Gray | Remarkable 2 Paper Tablet | Includes 10.3” Remarkable Tablet, Marker Plus Pen with Eraser, Book Folio Cover in Gray Weave, and 1-Year Free Connect Trial
description: I am very happy with my reMarkable2 note taking tablet. I manage a busy Real Estate office and this helps me take notes on meetings and when I am interviewing new agents. Everything has it's own folder and it's super easy to find what I'm looking for when I need to review something or add to it. I also have it sinced with my desktop computer and my mobile phone. So where ever I may be, I can access the information that I need. I bought the case too and the screen saver. I highly recommend it.

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: The screen turns on if the chassis is squeezed, and the screen will sometimes turn on in the middle of the night.  If you toss and turn, you will inadvertently put pressure on the chassis an activate the screen which is quite bright in a dark room.  There is no way to disable this, but after putting it on my ankle, this issue goes away.  Sleep tracking works on the ankle (if you are NOT using clip-on body mode).  I worry that this Fitbit wasn't tuned for the ankle.  That is, I move my ankles less than my wrists when lying in bed.This tracker does not work well when using with a treadmill desk.  In order to get an accurate step count, you need to wear on your ankle but tell the app you are wearing it in "clip-on body" mode.  This mode unfortunately disables heart tracking.  I would love to see a "worn on ankle" mode that addresses these issues.  This Fitbit does not track any treadmill steps if my pace is on my treadmill's lowest setting.  I hope they adjust the min speed threshold because I walk for hours per day on this setting as I work.The screen is small which is great, but why can't we have all those on-screen controls available in the app too?  If I want to toggle clip-on body mode, and it's a tedious to swipe and click on that tiny screen--especially if worn on ankle.  My phone, on the other hand, has a large screen.Automatic sleep detection is wildly inaccurate in terms of when sleep begins.  This could be a result of wearing it on my ankle.  One night it said I went to sleep at 7:20pm and was restless until 11:20pm.  In reality, I went to sleep at 11:20pm.  There's a way to manually edit the start time which I did, but then later my manual edit was overwritten, and I had to do it a second time.  This bug happens routinely.  There is an option to tell the device explicitly when you start sleeping and stop in real-time, but if I use this feature, it shows an error code 0x and most of my sleep stats are missing.  In general, the software has lots of little bugs like this: the premium feature called "Meet your sleep animal" ignores my manual edits of my sleep start and end times.  I know this because it says on average it takes me one hour to fall asleep which way off from my manual edits.Heart rate tracking seems to work perfectly when worn on the ankle.  A strategy for treadmill desks users could be to use Fitbit for heart rate tracking and sleep tracking only, and then use your iPhone for step tracking as iPhone is more accurate and convenient.  You would just need to place the iPhone in a pocket near the knee (cargo shorts) so that steps are counted.There is no way to manually turn off the device.  The only way to turn it off is to let the battery drain to zero.  As far as I know, storing a device with zero charge for long periods of time will permanently damage a battery.What I liked about my Fitbit is that I have learned my Resting Heart Rate (RHR) and Heart Rate Variability (HRV).  I learned I probably don't have sleep apnea or attrib fib.  I'm not using my Fitbit anymore.  In a year or so, I will dust it off and check these stats again.  I hope my battery still works.

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: ***** UPDATE August 15th, 2023 *****I've had my watch for 20 days now. Worn it to bed every single night. Of those 20 nights I've gotten THREE nights where it has recorded a sleep score. It's nice to see my REM and Deep Sleep cycles and to put some loose value on the quality of sleep I'm getting. I had to go to the FitBit site to try and trouble shoot why I only got 3 nights...I *think* (not 100% sure, but based on FitBit help pages this is my assumption) you have to have the watch SNUG at night to get a good reading for sleep. And when I say snug I mean I have the SMALL band so tight I only have 3 notches left to go before I'm out of notches. I'd say I have average to small wrists, so If you have REALLY small wrists you could be out of luck unless you get a 3rd party band. I will likely go that route as the firmer plastic that tight is not comfortable and leaves massive dents.The worst part of not getting but 3 days of sleep score is that the monthly sleep profile needs 14 nights of sleep score to give you a sleep profile, so that likely isn't going to happen this month unless I can get a sleep score every night for pretty much the rest of the month. And then the "Readiness Score" also needs the sleep data. So I got a score yesterday (Monday) because it gave me a sleep score for Sunday night. I can't judge that aspect of it on one score.I did wear it in the pool today and it seems fine in regards to the water resistance. My gripe there is that I was doing water aerobics and there is no quick option for that - just swimming. So I had to go back into the app and add my activity and the time frame. Not the worst thing, but if it's an exercise option within the app I wish I could set it as a quick select for my watch as it's something I may continue doing on a regular basis.Still would't upgrade the star rating at this point, nor would I pay the 10 bucks a month for premium with the data I've gotten thus far.***** Original Review *****I will admit I've not had my new FitBit for more than 24 hours yet as I start writing this -- BUT -- This is my 3rd or 4th FitBit in the last decade or so. I go between FitBit and Apple Watch. I'll pro/con this from my prior knowledge of what FitBit was prior to Google buying it. I already utilize the apps FitOn for exercise videos along with LoseIt! for food logging, so that plays into my review.Pros:The screens now are SO much better.Battery life is better than in the past.Way more information in a compact device - It's more than just tracking 10000 steps with 5 dotstsw now.Bands are more comfortable than prior models, and have plenty of 3rd party options.FitBit now has exercise videos in app. (You'll see this in cons, I'll explain.)Clock and App Gallery. (Also going to appear in cons.)Meal ideas. (Another double edged sword here too.)Cons: (Maybe grab a snack right now, it's going to take a minute.)The App... is simply atrocious. With what I'm seeing right now, I can't say paying for premium is going to be worth anything. Unless the health data and readiness score are absolutely mind blowing I really can't fathom spending 10 bucks a month on it. I've also noticed that an issue with the Inspire 3 not showing things like breathing and skin temp are all over the help pages on FitBit. I'll try and remember to update if that all shows up in the coming days like it says it should.** Groups no longer exist. You can have a group with your personal friends you add on, but you cannot find a public group if you wanted to just talk to people about something like meal prep. There is no more social aspect to to the app aside from adding friends. I can partake in groups on LoseIt! and FitOn both.** Clock and App Gallery - there's limited clock faces for the Inspire 3. The stock one it comes loaded with is the one I like the best, and you have THREE whole color theme options (green, orange, purple). There are apps I cannot load onto my Inspire like FitOn, which REALLY irks me off as that's my primary exercise video app (more on that below). My Apple Watch had an app too that synced my heart rate to FitOn.** Speaking of things the FitBit won't work with... It won't sync any data with Apple Health - I will have to see if my FitBit syncing with the LoseIt! app will do so.** Exercise videos: There seems to be a good bit to choose from, some are for Premium subscribers only like most apps, which isn't a huge deal. My dislike on this is there is precious little to sort the videos by. My FitOn app I can go by time, equipment needed, body part I want to focus on, and even the trainer. There are 6 filter options on the FitBit app. They have groups such as "no equipment needed" or "weights only" but then there's also ones I came across that require a treadmill or push-up bar, but you don't know that until you click on the video itself.** Meal ideas are awesome, but on the FitBit app they are all in video format. I don't want to watch a video to get the recipe. I want an ingredients list and directions I can *read*. Looking at a few videos they are short, like 36 seconds, and at no point do they tell you how much to use in the ones I looked at as they are backed by music. Again, I can find recipes in a clear format on my other two apps.My conclusion:I already gave my Apple Watch to my kid, or I'd be very tempted to send this back. Is it worth a Benjamin Franklin? Not really, and especially not when the potentially useful features require me to continue paying a monthly fee. I'd say this is worth perhaps 60 bucks tops, so if you see at that price point, then maybe go for it.TL;DR:If you use other apps already for fitness and food tracking, or are looking for the old school social aspect of FitBit, then you likely should look elsewhere because Google is running the lower end trackers and the app into the ground in hopes that you will price up to the smart watch options. I had hoped that those articles saying as much were being a little dramatic... they're not. Sad day.

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: To begin with, all I really wanted was a step counter and sleep tracker. I don't need to monitor heart rate, stress, or any of the other features the Inspire touts. I got this only because Google, now corporate masters of FitBit, no longer support the FitBit One which was working perfectly fine as a product and doing exactly what it said on the tin, right up to where they decided to let it wither on the vine and the software stopped syncing steps with my iPhone. By comparison, the Inspire 3 has its pros: automatic sleep logging (no more fumbling in a daze for the sleep start/stop button!) and more accurate step counting... so long as you wear it on your ankle. (Who the hell thought you could accurately track steps by arm movement?) Cons: it's a real pain in the ass that most of the functions are only accessible through the touch screen of the device itself and not through the iPhone app. Like setting the alarm, which is kind of critical to my working life. Ultimately, that didn't matter because the alarm DOES. NOT. WORK. AT. ALL. I am grateful to my cats, who woke me up in time to go to work on the first three days I wore the thing to bed. Fortunately, the One will still sync alarm settings from my phone, so now I wear the One at night for only that reason and use the Inspire as a step-counting anklet during the day. It's less work than trying to return the thing and find an alternative. (And yes, I looked hard at Garmin and other brands in hopes of being able to give Google the old heave-ho, but ultimately the price point on the Inspire had them beat.)

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: I mainly wanted a device to track my sleep as I’d been having severe fatigue. I was between the Inspire 2 and 3. I ended up going with the 3 because of the newer features, especially the nighttime oxygen saturation tracking. About a month after getting the Inspire 3 and using it 24/7 besides showering, I did a sleep study…I went into the sleep study confident that I did not have sleep apnea because the Inspire 3 said that my nighttime oxygen saturation was fine at an average of 96% with low variation. However, I ended up being diagnosed with moderate sleep apnea after my sleep study detected an average of 16 apnea/hypopnea events (SpO2 <89%) per hour. Unfortunately I learned this just after the return period for my Inspire 3 had ended, otherwise I would’ve returned it.I understand that this device is not intended to diagnose any medical condition etc etc, but I feel like I wasted my money getting the Inspire 3 instead of the lower cost Inspire 2 that would’ve been just as useful to me.As far as features that it shares with the 2, this is a great device and did help me track my sleep duration and phases. The sleep tracking and heart rate monitoring seem to be pretty accurate. The battery life is also fantastic. I charged it once a week when I was using it consistently, and it would still be at about 40% at that point. Keep in mind, I did not enable phone notifications on my device, which is supposed to significantly impact the battery life.Assuming those features are consistent between devices, I’d recommend the Inspire 2 but not the 3.

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: I am on my second or third Inspire 3 and probably have had at least six Fitbits.  I like it when it works.  It is small (I have a small wrist so the Apple watch is too large), counts steps and mostly gives you your messages and calendar alerts.  I say mostly because it is easy to turn these alerts off by accident.  And, when it is starting to fail, it does not do so.My current Fitbit began having serious issues about a month before its' warranty was up.  I called Fitfit, The "fixed it" (it was not giving notifications. It worked for a few weeks. Broke again. Fitbit "fixed" it aagin. It worked for a few weeks.  Then the Fitbit said it was not charging.  Fitbit "fixed it" (all this is phone support).  Four days later I discover the battery is not holding the charge and it takes more than three hours to charge it. In the meantime it is again dropping notifications.  I called Fitbiit. They refused to help me on the phone because my case had already been "escalated".  Two minutes after hanging up, the same representative who I spoke to wrote me an email saying my Fitbit was out of warranty and here was a 35% discount to purchase, but only from Google shop.  We had already discussed that the problems started before warranty expired.  I had already said to her that a solution that said it was out of warranty was not honorable.  After all, Fitbit support had bee dragging the watch past the warranty line with fixes that did not stick. So, if you choose to buy the Inspire 3, just know this is basically a "subscription" watch where you need to re-purchase every year.  Also know, Fitbit is only extending this discount via Google shop, not through Amazon.

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: I have used a Fitbit device to track fitness for close to 14 years. The Fitbit devices and apps that were developed by the original Fitbit team were excellent, accurate, reliable and their customer service was responsive.None of that is true of the current Fitbit experience and tech ever since Google acquired Fitbit in 2021.I bought a Google Fitbit Inspire 3 a year ago when my Fitbit One (from the original, pre-Google Fitbit team) finally gave up the ghost after twelve years of great use. It was a sad moment.The Google Fitbit Inspire 3 doesn't hold battery power well - it drains quickly. It must be worn on my wrist (unlike the Fitbit One that clipped to the waistband of my pants or a pocket) and it doesn't record steps as accurately as the Fitbit One device did. Also, because I already had a smartwatch (for things other than steps and sleep) it is ridiculous that if I want to maintain and continue my Fitbit stats I must wear two devices on my wrist. (I feel like those stereotypes of guys on the streets of New York, who open their coats to reveal slew of watches and ask passersby, "Hey, you wanna buy a watch?"In addition to the downsides of the duplicative and inaccurate step counts wrist tracker, Google has destroyed the Android app that the Inspire 3 must sync to so that counts of steps, sleep time, heart rate, etc. don't match anymore from the worn device to the mobile apps. It appears as if the Google-managed Fitbit app is just making up random numbers. That app inaccuracy renders the Fitbit devices useless if the data they are supposed to capture, record and generate detailed historical patterns with (not to mention sync with partner apps!) are not accurate. At minimum it's a two-part fitness system: device and app. If one or the other doesn't work correctly, accurately or reliably, the system is worthless. That's the state Fitbit is at now under Google's management.My recommendation: Don't adopt any Google fitness solutions (Fitbit or Pixel). They don't seem to be able to code apps correctly or accurately and their product management people are unresponsive to many many users reporting similar issues on their Fitbit discussion forums. In addition, they've dropped popular features, have discontinued the once-loved desktop Dashboard charge a lot for their "Premium" app (translate that to mean obtuse and unneeded + with all the same bugs noted above). Buyer beware!

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: I got this one as a replacement for my charge 2 which ironically isn't holding a charge very long any more. I picked this one as it was much smaller than the charge 2 which I always felt was kind of big and clunky. This is much smaller and it does have some nice features but it also has some annoying parts too. I like that I can see my phone notifications on it and I also like that you can turn it to sleep mode so it doesn't blind you  when you turn over in bed at night. The vibrate notification that you have a message seems to vary as sometimes it is very obvious and sometimes I don't even feel it. The step count accuracy seems to be similar to the charge 2 which means not terribly but probably within maybe 25 steps. There isn't a clock face that I love so I am resigned to having the time be in 2 rows of numbers. Whoever designed the band should be sentenced to sit and replace them over and over for a couple of weeks as punishment as the connector is awful. I don't know who decided this type was a good idea but it is terrible. It reminds me of the old watch bands that you had to use a small screwdriver to get off if your band broke. If you have no fingernails, you don't have a prayer of getting this on or off but if you do have fingernails, you're probably going to break one replacing the band. It is also hard to be sure that it is seated all the way in and won't fall off your arm. I ordered additional bands which I had to return as the pins wouldn't seat in the watch so replacement bands may or may not work well. I ordered the yellow original band inspire 3 as the additional bands I also ordered had a black band but I had to return them so if I had known that, I would have ordered the black band one. I am also having an issue with the swipe feature as most of the time when I swipe, it just turns itself off so I am repeatedly tapping to wake it up and then, swipe, it goes to sleep, tap tap, wake up, swipe go to sleep multiple times which is very annoying. Also the battery life icon is not for the faint of sight as it is very very tiny. So after fighting to get the screen to swipe up, I had better be wearing my glasses if I want to see how much battery is left as it is a very small icon and teeny numbers up in the top corner of the screen that also includes the date and the step count. It seems like a lot to cram onto the screen especially when the battery life is kind of useful to be able to read. I know I said I like the smaller screen but I also want to be able to see the things on it. The battery does last pretty well which is nice. So do I love it, no. But it will do, hence the 3 stars.

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: When my Charge 5 died I ordered the Inspire 3 because it had a smaller face and thinner band.  I expected the same functionality as my Charge 5, but that is not what I got.  The biggest functional issues are 1) it loses pairing with my phone at least once a day, and 2) I have a hard time getting the watch to tell me the time when it detects that I am exercising (eg running to catch a flight, on a hike…) without me going through a rigmarole.  Additionally, the traditional buckle on the strap of the Inspire 3 is harder to fasten than the style of the Charge 5.

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: I like the Fitbit but 1st of all the band that it comes with is very small! I thought it was just me but my wife even tried it on and it was tight on her as well. I can only buckle it on the second slot of the strap! But I could deal with that or get a new strap not a big deal to me!The real issue is the inaccuracy! I was driving a tow truck all day today! Tow trucks & pretty much all trucks are very bouncy! I watched the step counter go up every time we went over a bump causing my arm to move! Even while we were on the highway doing 70mph! I could understand if we were stuck in traffic doing 2-3 mph & my arm moves up & down it could mistake me for walking but at 70 mph?It's a shame because I really liked it & I'm getting more into fitness now & wanted a reliable pedometer & something that would track approximately how many calories I burned & I thought I found the solution!But don't take my word for it! Seriously! Try it out yourself! It might work perfectly for your application!

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: Fell in LOVE with this, so much smaller than an Apple Watch, didn’t irritate my wrist or get caught on things as much. Super durable, never scratched it and I scratch everything. Could go a week or more without charging it. Pay for the premium because it helps track so much more including my sleep. Easy to setup. The app is good for what it is. Now to the negatives. Sync is so so so slow. It doesn’t show my texts on my watch no matter what I do with the settings. It doesn’t track the stair master and the steps you get on it but tracks your zone min. I’ve had this for just over a year. Out of the blue about a month ago it stopped holding a charge. Now I have to charge it daily and I’m looking for another one.

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: Love my Fitbit! It’s affordable with a sleek design offering all the health benefits and steps information needed. The Fitbit is easy to link to a smartphone and charge. The battery has a long life before needing charging. The charger is sometimes challenging to attach to the device, but it charges quickly. Like the sleep monitoring.

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: Day three on the Fitbit bandwagon for me and I’m LOVING the inspire 3! I was never a fan of the bulky smart watches (or watches in general) and couldn’t justify spending hundreds on an Apple Watch. I don’t need a watch to make calls, send texts, show my pictures, etc. I had been using my iPhone to track my steps each day, but that got frustrating when I’d put my phone down on the stair climber at the gym. None of those steps were ever accounted for on my phone. I hesitated getting a fitness tracker, but decided to finally take the plunge with this one. I’m a fitness junkie anyway, so I love how it motivates you to move more, I love that it tracks my heart rate, work outs, and my sleep quality. I love the “relax” app that encourages slow, deep breathing for two minutes- I’ve been using that to help me fall asleep quicker. I love all the different bands you can buy to accessorize it to your personal style. All in all, I am very pleased with all the apps this little thing can do!

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: I wanted something inexpensive to try tracking sleep. After wearing this every night and most days for two months, here’s my thoughts:tl;dr : A great inexpensive tracker for steps, activity, alarms, but not a very accurate sleep trackerPROS- Smart Wake Alarms: this is my favorite feature by far. I love the vibrate on my wrist to wake me up before my other alarms, and I feel like it’s not as much of a struggle to get up- Long battery life: I’ve only had to charge it 3-4 times in the months I’ve had it.- Automatic workout detection is nice, since my activity is mostly outdoor walks and I forget to set the workouts- Small and comfortable, doesn’t bother me while sleeping with it on- Move reminders are helpful during my work day- Heart rate and step counts are visible right from the watch face- Mirrors iPhone notifications for texts, calls, Outlook emailsCONS- Sleep tracking is not very accurate. It has told me I was asleep when I was awake laying in bed, and some nights tells me I went to bed much later or woke up much earlier than I did.- Small watch screen makes it hard to read notifications from your phone- Doesn’t consistently vibrate for notifications from your phone- Limited watch faces and you can’t customize the colors- There are some FitBit Premium features that aren’t super obvious in the app and require some digging (recipes, etc).

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: I've been wearing the Fitbit Inspire 3 for a few months now after I lost my Inspire 2. I do not regret upgrading to the 3!As someone who doesn't need a lot of techy features, this watch has been perfect. I love the different clock face backgrounds you can install (something the Inspire 2 did not have) and the overall look of the watch. The band is slightly thinner than the Inspire 2 as well. The pixels of the display are so sharp, clean, and bright, making it way easier to read in sunlight. So far, the battery life has been great, getting about a full week/week and a half before I need to charge it (it charges pretty fast too, only takes maybe an hour).If you've had an Inspire before, it definitely took some time getting used to the different layout this watch uses. I'm not the world's biggest fan of how the notifications pop-up and look in the notification menu, but I'm not complaining either.The only thing I miss from my Inspire 2 is the Tile Tracking feature. The GPS on the watch is only for measuring exercise. I knew this before purchasing, but it's something to keep in mind if you're someone like me who lost their previous watch while hiking. Another piece to keep in mind is that the bezel size, the actual screen, is fairly small compared to the whole face of the watch; this is something I wish was bigger and actually covered the whole face.Yes, the box does come with a charger and one band. The full set-up of software installation and Fitbit app pairing took me around 15-20 minutes. Since then, I've done two updates, which take 5-10 minutes max (the watch says it can take up to 20 minutes, but it's never that long).

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: I've been having issues with my Samsung Galaxy watch/ Samsung health because it was physically DRAINING ME. I'm on a weight loss journey and now that I understand how calorie in= calorie out works, I bought a smart watch to help track my meals so that I could keep a close eye on my calorie intake vs the calories out. But holy crap it's almost like I barely moved an inch with my galaxy watch with how little it accumulated calories burned. I know it's a estimate, but how was I serving at my job for 12 hours, going to the gym after, and BARELY making above my BMR? it made absolute no sense.I decided to buy a fitbit, regardless of the whole Google conspiracy. It's affordable, it's cute, and it maaaay over compensate on calories, but doing a quick math equation with percentages, I can confidently say that this was the right fit for me.Weightloss/ fitness aside, I adore it's simplicity. I love a simple watch. It does everything it's little mind can, and ya know, that's money well spent!

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: I’m not usually a watch/bracelet type, but this thing has been fantastic. I barely notice that it is there while it keeps tabs on my health and fitness numbers. It’s nondescript & was under $100, could not ask for a better product. An added bonus is that i don’t feel tethered to my computer (work) like I did with the Apple Watch. Nice to be able to “unplug” once in a while.

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: Am pretty disappointed that Fitbit batteries don’t seem to last longer than two years.  Chose the Inspire because I cannot stand 1. Hulky, sweat inducing things on my wrist, 2. Receiving texts or phone calls on a devise too small to operate easily and 3. Paying for yet another devise on my cell phone plan.  When this devise fails, I will replace it with grumbling (for having to wade back into the decision and set-up rabbit-hole) but few qualms about the cost.I love most of the features that Fitbit offers for free on their app.  I think most of them are accurate enough - although they have major odd hiccup days about once every 9-12 months.  The devise offers a lot of tracking options that I don’t use and wish I could turn off.  I will accidentally swipe or tap my wrist wrong and end up in menus that are challenging to find your way out of.  Thank goodness for YouTube and Google answers.A good choice for me.  But HEY, let’s make these things “repairable” at least to the degree of swapping out batteries.  Earth does not have endless resources!

product_name: Fitbit Inspire 3 Health &-Fitness-Tracker with Stress Management, Workout Intensity, Sleep Tracking, 24/7 Heart Rate and more, Midnight Zen/Black One Size (S & L Bands Included)
description: GPS: I saw a review crying about needing to have phone on body in order to have GPS tracked. The features of the Inspire 3 compared to other models are CLEARLY listed in THIS product description. This model has CONNECTED GPS (means it will talk to phone), or you can choose a model with GPS built in (no need to have phone on you). ZERO surprises here.STEP COUNT: I find it accurate, leaning toward underestimation, which is fine. Never have I found it to over estimate. Seems about as accurate as all the other Fitbit products I have used over the past 10 years. If you find it over estimating for whatever reason, then raise your goal.SCREEN CLARITY: good color, clean clear presentation. I have been using their smart watches the past several years, so I wasnt sure what to expect from their "low end" basic model. Very clear. Very different (and better) than basic models of 8-10 years ago.SCREEN USE: very receptive to my touch. I can tap the screen and see the time, date, and steps, and then scroll UP to see: date, battery amount, steps, distance, floors, hourly activity progress, heart rate(actual and resting), sleep and sleep score, Sp02, menstrual info, exercise progress. Scroll DOWN, to see alarm if you have one set, or want to turn off. Along with other options. Use SIDE button and swipe left or right for other information and settings stuff.BATTERY LIFE:. Lasts forever. I have my watch set to only turn on with a tap. I didnt want to see it every time I flicked my wrist. That also takes away from batter life. There are likely other settings and such that decrease battery life, but as of right now I have been using it since July 9th, and it is the 17th at time of writing this. I have 32% battery left. 10 days is likely accurate.BONUS: although it says that it does NOT have ECG app for AFIB detection, it does. Sorta.
