product_name: SAMSUNG T9 Portable SSD 4TB, USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 External Solid State Drive, Seq. Read Speeds Up to 2,000MB/s for Gaming, Students and Professionals,MU-PG4T0B/AM, Black (Pack of 1)
description: I upgraded one of my external drives to the Samsung T9 SSD and was very happy with it so bought a second to replace my last old WD external drive.  I formatted both for mac and use one for Time Machine and the other as an external hard drive for files.  The second drive (used for files) now disconnects after a few hours of use.  Won't come back until I move the drive to a different USB port.  Will replace it with a unit from a different manufacturer.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: I do 10X more scanning than printing, but that's why I buy a all in one.  Printing seems ok, no issues.  Scanning on the other hand leaves much to be desired.  As I said in the headline, it's slow.  Worse than that it doesn't like to feed things straight.  It's like there's one drive roller on the far side and it pulls at an angle.  Software is kind of clunky, but does have one very nice feature, the ability to edit pdfs in terms of rotation, order and delete or add pages.  Very nice feature.  But overall I like the Epson I previously had much better.  Not that it was perfect either, but what do I expect for a hundred bucks, +/-.In spite of the fact that the price has nearly dropped in half since my purchase last summer, I would not buy again.  It is a good value at it's current 69.99 price however, but...Update, one more complaint.  I have this on a desk, off to my side about 2.5 feet away.  The display for errors, ink, etc, faces up.  No popup display like my last printer.  I can't see it without getting up, leaning waaaaay over and even then it sometimes takes a flashlight.  OK, this is a home machine, not an office printer with a bunch of 2'X4' overhead lights.Update, less than 2 years in.  I'm looking for a new printer.  It still works, but the document feeder drives me nuts the way it wants to feed stuff in at an angle.  Print quality is good, but they all seem to be.  Scan quality is not great, either cranked way up in resolution for photo scanning or just scanning documents to pdf.  Printers seem to have a short half life, which I'm kind of used to now, but I'd at least like they to work well while they work.An odd quirk I've run across is the heavier the printer the longer it seems to last.  This one is a feather light 12.7 pound according to the listing here.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: So I purchased this one bc it had the option to plug the printer into my laptop. I’ve read many reviews and what I didn’t want was the WiFi not working and my documents to not print. Seems like that is an issue with many of the printers.At least this one had WiFi capability as well as the direct plug in capability.First you should know that this comes with a plug but it’s the USB A and USBB, so basically if you have a MacBook you have to buy yourself another plug.I had no real big issues with my MacBook but today I tried printing something for my kiddo for her HW and she has a Microsoft surface pro and so I used the original plug it came with and it did NOT printI’m very familiar with setting up printers and I had trouble, I tried everything.20 non existing print jobs later,  I decided to change the print to 1 page at a time and what do you know it worked. Typing and deleting a page number is so annoying when you have 15 pages to print.At this point I miss my 6 year old laser printer that had paper feeding issues, I literally had to hold the paper perfectly or it wouldn’t feed correctly, anyways I thought I hated that printer this takes it to a whole new level.Not knowing if my printer will work is so aggravating. Of course I watched a tutorial on you tube and now I see many comments stating how this is the worst printer and to not buy.Wish I saw those comments earlier.Honestly if I could do it over again I would spend a few more $ and get a different printerAnyways, I threw away the box so I will have to make this work for at least a year.My HP was def better.My advice look elsewhere.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: Maybe I am being too critical for the price, but despite all the great reviews, this TR4720 will never compare to my MG5220 that recently met up with the dreaded B200 error code.  I am not high-tech or an IT person...just in need of a home printer for personal and work use.If I missed something in the description that said the paper drawer extends nearly 5" beyond the dimensions given, please inform me.  I have never had a printer where I had to take out the paper to keep it free from dust or save precious desk space.  When empty and folded up, the printer is a great size and meets the dimensions given.  If this was such an important feature, why not have at least a dust cover over the extension?  The drop-down tray for the prints is not an issue; this feature is also on an HP we have at another location (but the paper tray stores the paper horizontally, covered and is flush with the printer housing, hint hint!)Plug & Play Rating: 3 1/2.  Mostly an easy set-up, but too many choices for setting up the scanning.  Took three tries (following the instructions) to get it to work.No Icons on desktop when first installed.  Had to go to APP, right click to add shortcut.  All had the option to add to Pin to Taskbar.As for the ink, I agree with some of the others.  For the price, they don't seem to last very long.  I believe it is to encourage using the auto-ink promotion.  I will experiment with the XL cartridges to see if there is a significant improvement.  If so, I will update this review.I guess it is a sign of the times that products are not supposed to last or be made with quality products.  Again, I agree with some of the other reviews that the plastic housing is very flimsy.  Be cautious when opening, using trays, etc.Read what is included in the box.  I did, so I knew there would be no USB or phone (for fax) cables.  Fortunately, I was able to connect to my WiFi, but if yours is spotty, you will need the USB.Fax is useless without a nearby phone jack, found that information in the Canon Forum.  This model does not support wireless faxing.  My fax usage is limited and usually a low page count, so I use FaxZero.In all fairness, if I do find more positive features, I will update this review.  Hope this helps!

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: I got the TR 4720 because I just needed a budget printer, and fast.Owning this printer, is mainly dealing with constant troubleshooting until it finally gives you what you want.I dealt with weird page sizing issues when I first bought it. I continue to deal with a never-ending struggle to get the printer and my MacBook Air to connect wirelessly.Even after changing to a physical connection via usb, they will sometimes take 20 minutes to communicate the print job.The display looks like that printer you had in 2004.The ink ran out after printing maybe 40 band-style concert setlists. The black runs out fast if you’re using a printer for what people usually use printers for: black and white document printing. If you’re using it for pictures or other fun things, the ink runs out even faster because there are no dedicated cyan/magenta/yellow cartridges. They’re all condensed into one small “color” cartridge. I recommend stocking up on ink and buying a 3 pack or something.3 stars because it has printed what I needed it to… eventually. It is not fancy, and it almost functions. But it was dirt cheap so…

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: As far as printers go, this was relatively simple to set up and use. The print quality and features are not too bad for the price.My biggest complaint is the ink cartridges. We've probably printed less than 50 pages (maybe half that?) and it's already requiring replacement ink. Most prints were basic Word documents with occasional color, so it wasn't heavily used.This printer is only a good fit for someone who rarely prints, and even then, I'd recommend starting with at least one set of backup cartridges on hand or investing in a higher-end model that will have longer-lasting ink.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: This printer was relatively easy to set up, though the drivers are not easily found on the Canon webiste. Best to just Google "Prixma TR4720 drivers" and locate them that way. Also, you MUST agree to everything that Canon asks for permissions to or it makes life difficult when connecting via Wifi or mobile device. Oh and the display is not backlit- I missed this in my research and it is annoying, but for the price, I will deal.But man...this printer is loud/noisy!!!! My printer is located right next to me in my home office (I don't have any other option) and there would be no way I could take a phone call with the printer going. Probably couldn't have much conversation until it is done printing.People mentioned it is "plasticy"- It is. And cheaply made; it's no different from the last one I had to return to my previous employer. I think this is just the way it is now.Just got this today and prints look good and crisp. Color is nice. If not so noisy, I may have given it more stars.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: I only gave this a couple of tries before deciding to return, so I can't say how it holds up over time.Right away I noted that the plastic seems thinner, lighter, and more flexible than my old printer (an old hp officejet). I worried a little but hoped for the best.Another gripe about the build:  in the pictures it looked like the paper was stored in a covered tray. This is what made me choose this printer over a very similar and somewhat cheaper machine that had the paper sticking up out the back. Well, the paper tray is not fully covered. I'm not sure why there's no paper sticking out in the product images. I still think the horizontal feeder is probably less likely to get damaged by dust and humidity than the sticking up the back type, but it's not what I had in mind.Setup was easy but would it really have been so hard to include a quick start guide in the package instead of making you open it on your phone? I mean the QR code worked fine and the online instructions were fine but I could have figured it out faster with a simple illustration or two.Wifi Setup was easy peasy and other than putting in ink and paper it didn't need anything else to be ready to print.First thing I did was print a test page of basic text from a Google doc on my phone. It transmitted efficiently. Then the printer let out an awful squeal and printed a page that looked like it came from 1999. I couldn't believe it, so I gave it another try, checked the settings (maybe I should have manually selected black and white instead of keeping it on color and letting it figure out that the text was black?) Still came out grainy and grayish. Then I printed the same thing on my old ailing hp (maybe the problem was in the document?) and it was a little fuzzy and streaky (this is one reason it's getting replaced) but definitely blacker and less pixely looking.I like having a color printer for those occasional projects and kid stuff, but most of what I print is black and white, usually text, sometimes with barcodes. If it's not going to be black and reasonably sharp, then never mind.I printed a color test page on each printer just out of curiosity, and it was much better. I almost couldn't tell the difference between the two. The text in the colored image was much sharper than the black text, you had to be paying good attention to see that it was still a little grainy, and the colors were similar enough though maybe ever so slightly richer on the hp.I sure hope the noise and poor text quality are a fault of this model and not a Canon habit, because I just ordered a different Canon to replace this. Because that one is evidenced on YouTube to really have a covered paper tray, and the similarly priced hp has the paper sticking up in back. But if the print quality is still poor then I'm going with the hp and will have to risk the exposed paper feed, because in essence I need my printer to print at least well enough. And preferably quietly enough to use while people are sleeping.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: This is an average basic cheap printer. The quality of the color prints appear to be dull. It took over two hours of attempting to try to connect to the Wi-Fi in order to print remotely. The scanning capabilities are poor scanning to other devices the quality is smeared, are blemished last time. I definitely would choose to pay a little bit more money for a higher quality printer.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: I have been relatively brand-loyal to Canon for probably 20 years, now, when it comes to printers and copiers. I've put their large copies into businesses, and used their smaller inkjet devices in my home.This particularly copier just embodies "cheap plastic junk" in so many ways that make it very frustrating for someone who has loved Canon products for so long. Among the things that are really sub-par about this device are the following:* The paper tray on the bottom sticks out from the rest of the unit, which is annoying. Previous models of various Canon printers I've owned have had a wide enough body that the paper tray fit completely under the printer. I would gladly trade the extra shelf space for having the paper tray not stick out from the printer.* The fact that the paper tray sticks out from the printer, combined with the fact that it isn't even a full tray, just a flip-down tray, led to it getting cracked and breaking off when someone pushed on it too hard.* The two-line LCD display is a step backward from the LED screens that previous products have featured. Configuring the printer, checking status and settings, etc., is made much more difficult with this display.* I'm not sure that going from separate color ink tanks to a single integrated color tank is actually a good step. The ink cartridge is significantly smaller, which means more frequent changes (and thus more wasted plastic), and you then end up replacing all of the colors at the same time whether you've actually used each of them or not. This seems incredibly wasteful, particularly since my experience with the individual color cartridges is that one of the colors tends to get used disproportionately to the others.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: Hate this printer.  Did not realize there was no concealed paper storage.  Have to open front and load paper every time I want to print, even if it is only a few pages.  Then have to remove any extra paper in order to close front of printer.  Had I been aware of this I would not have ordered it on line.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: I love my printer. It is a high-quality wireless printer. I can print from any wireless device whether I am using my smartphone or laptop computer.  I can also print labels and other documents. The ink quality is superb.  It prints fast and doesn't make a lot of noise. It was easy to set up by downloading the app. I like the size of the printer. It doesn't take up a lot of space. The ink is a little pricey.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: Well, the little rascal that is my Microsoft laptop won't allow me to install updates needed to operate this printer, but my android phone can do it, no sweat.The printer initially kept dropping the wifi connection and entering a password on this keyboard is an exploitative laden task surely leading to temporary insanity. Another maddening feature is the tiny menu screen. It is nearly impossible to read in natural light.The instructions included to connect to wifi are difficult to follow, at best. At least, they were for me.  However, once I learned to send print orders via my phone, I learned to like this printer. It's fast enough. The ink is cheaper than most. The copy function works well unattended. It's fairly quiet and lightweight. For the price, it is a decent personal printer.Heed this advice. Don't buy a Microsoft laptop thinking you can get rid of S mode. I have been trying for years to get rid of it. Honestly, if Microsoft wants to control what I can download, they should have bought the computer for me. If you can't get rid of S mode, you may have problems when you add newer peripherals. My computer would support the 3500 models in this series, but a 4700 is just too modern, lol.Also, I initially thought the problem was the printer. The company I bought from gave me no problems with offering a return. It was perfectly painless. However, I really needed this the day it arrived and now I won't paet with it.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: Does not have automatic double sided printing. You have to do double sided printing manually with this printer. And the ink supply runs out pretty quickly. But it is a cheap laser printer. And most cheap laser printers have a limited ink supply. So it is pretty normal for a cheap laser printer.The photos are pretty good for a cheap laser printer. But again, do not expect to get a lot of prints off the limited ink supply.If you want a lot of printed projects that use a lot of ink, get a large capacity printer. They are more expensive than laser printers. But they can give you more printouts before you need to put in more ink. Unfortunately, with some large capacity printers you have to refill the ink yourself because they do not have easy to replace cartridges like the laser printers. And avoid recyclable or reusable ink cartridges. They can leak and ruin your printer.This printer is a good quality laser printer, despite the manual double sided printing. It will function as well as any other laser printer brand and print nice quality pictures. Just remember, is a laser printer. They will mess up your prints at times due to ink clogs, human error, and occasionally internet connection problems. It is something that they will all do. But this printer will scan and print very clear pictures and documents. Canon also sells cameras. They know good quality photos when they see them. Try out their cameras sometime too. They are wonderful once you learn about them and are not too complicated to use.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: A very very very affordable, classy and works very good. I was afraid at first while ordering, because of some of the bad reviews. We always check on the bad reviews while ignoring the good once.I will make things very clear, if you have a pc/laptop/phone, it’s really easy to connect with the printer, manual way also works.The speed is not super fast. But it’s not too bad either. I am a student , I reckon I don’t care bout them speed either. It’s all bout quality, which is hellagood. It’s not too big, not too small. But overall 100/100.Hint: if ya also got confused that you need to buy colors at first or not. You don’t. It already comes with one with the regular packaging. I reckon I didn’t read much and bought them extra colors.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: The Canon PIXMA is a versatile all-in-one printer that delivers impressive performance across the board. From the moment I unboxed it, I was pleasantly surprised by how straightforward the setup process was. The clear instructions and user-friendly interface made it a breeze to connect to my home network and start printing within minutes.Using the printer on a daily basis has been remarkably easy. The button display is intuitive, allowing quick access to all functions without any confusion. Whether printing, scanning, or copying, the controls are logical and simple to navigate.What truly stands out about the PIXMA is the quality of its prints. The results are nothing short of seamless. Text documents are crisp and clear, while color prints showcase vibrant hues and sharp details. Photos come out looking particularly impressive, with rich, true-to-life colors that rival professional prints.The printer's multi-ink system contributes to its excellent output, providing a wider color gamut that's especially noticeable in photographs and graphics. Even when printing borderless photos, the results are consistently stunning with no visible banding or color inconsistencies.Overall, the Canon PIXMA combines user-friendliness with high-quality performance, making it an excellent choice for home or small office use. Its easy setup, straightforward operation, and seamless print quality make it a standout in the all-in-one printer market.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: Really easy set up to my iPhone.  Prints seamlessly every time.  I highly recommended it  for simple at home printing.  Only issue- it wasn’t as easy to set up my Mac.  I got it but it took some time.  I had my phone set up in minutes.  Great little printer.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: My problem is with the printer that will NOT print on envelopes, jams frequently, support is a confusing nightmare. Pages have been removed for error codes, difficult to get help. Many choices  beforeyou can get any help. I ended up using both my phone and the laptop just to find the error codes. Printer is quirky. Finally getting a print job ac comprised, speed is fine, capacity is 100 pages of paper...good enough. Must unplug printer with EVERY error code which deletes all fax info and all storage.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: Great little All-in-One printer for the price. Replaced a Higher Priced All-in-One with this one. From unboxing to test page <15 minutes, also checked scanner, copy functions no problem and set up fax option. Used supplied web site address for setup and easy to follow instructions. Connected to WiFi with zero issues. Print & copied test pages looked good and okay print speed but that’s not a concern for my home printing needs, everything easy to read and replacement ink not bad price either. Does come with trial black & color cartridges.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: Feeder scanner, WiFi, Duplex printing, and it comes with ink, all for $60?  That's pretty awesome.  The only bad things about it is that it's slow if you're printing images, the initial setup is annoying, and the feeder scanner only scans one side of the page.Don't bother with the apps; Cannon wants you to download multiple pieces of software that require admin rights just to get the printer installed.  If you're running windows, connect manually from the device, then use the add printer feature.  Windows' built-in scan app even recognizes the feeder tray option (although my first multi-page scan failed with an unknown error, but my second, singe-page scan worked fine).  Full disclosure: I just got this so this review might change.  This thing even waits for the previous page to dry before printing on the second side.  You're getting a lot for your money.

product_name: Canon PIXMA TR4720 All-in-One Wireless Printer, Home Use with Auto Document Feeder, Mobile Printing and Built-in Fax, Black
description: It’s a good printer, but one must read carefully that it comes with sample ink what I mean by sample Inc. you have to buy more ink right away otherwise it’s a decent copier. I wish I would’ve added a few more dollars and sent it with some ink. You can really use instead of this cheap web selling things.

product_name: Apple AirPods Max Wireless Over-Ear Headphones, Pro-Level Active Noise Cancellation, Transparency Mode, Personalized Spatial Audio, USB-C Charging, Bluetooth Headphones for iPhone - Midnight
description: I would highly recommend them!  Excellent sound quality and incredible noise cancellation.  I love the small carrying case too…I returned the larger hard case, since it was much too big.  They are a little heavy but it has not been a problem for comfort.  They feel like high quality.

product_name: Apple AirPods Max Wireless Over-Ear Headphones, Pro-Level Active Noise Cancellation, Transparency Mode, Personalized Spatial Audio, USB-C Charging, Bluetooth Headphones for iPhone - Midnight
description: I am switching to everything USB-C headphones included, these are worth the hype.. the sound is amazing, the noise cancellation is top tier, the quality and make of these is just amazing. If you can afford these things they are worth it 100 percent. I'm obsessed.

product_name: Apple AirPods Max Wireless Over-Ear Headphones, Pro-Level Active Noise Cancellation, Transparency Mode, Personalized Spatial Audio, USB-C Charging, Bluetooth Headphones for iPhone - Midnight
description: Stupid that I got this for usb c charging. With that said…it’s pretty nice that all my devices use the same charging now. If you’re looking to save money and don’t care, get the original model. There are good deals on them right now.

product_name: Apple AirPods Max Wireless Over-Ear Headphones, Pro-Level Active Noise Cancellation, Transparency Mode, Personalized Spatial Audio, USB-C Charging, Bluetooth Headphones for iPhone - Midnight
description: Cool

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: This is definitely a CD player (and theoretically a radio, but I'm not using it for that). It's compact and looks fine. It plays audio CDs (but as far as I can tell, does not play MP3 CDs or anything). It has the worst speakers this side of the Dollar Tree. Muffled and somehow at the same time tinny. I can only describe it as "If I had to listen to music through these, I would hate music."thankfully I'm just using it to play lullabies for my kid at night and he doesn't seem to mind.I haven't tried the radio. I imagine it would have the same sound issues and the station uses a dial on the side with the number pressed into the dial so it seems kind of... difficult to tune but again, I haven't tried it since I don't need it... but if you need a radio I would recommend spending an extra three fiddy and getting something that shows the station on some kind of display... or at least a station BAR and not this dial. It has a little LED display but it only shows CD track numbers or the word "NO" when there's nothing loaded.Additionally there is no line out jack, so you can't connect it to better speakers.There IS a line-in jack if you have another device you want to play through this to punish yourself.Honestly, this is a music machine and it can only be used to listen to music poorly. Save your allowance, wait a week or two and get something better.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: I thought  would be a good brand, but I am dissapointed. The tuner is very difficult to get stations and get them to come in clearly. There are no numbers on it to tune into a station. Would not buy it again and I should have returned it and purchased another model

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: I like the look of this however; the dial for tuning into radio stations is very old fashioned. It shows approximately, not the actual station. So for this reason I'll be getting another that shows the station it's on. Otherwise, it's a nice little radio/cd player to have around in any room.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: I purchased this as a way for my young kids to be able to play CDs (rather than using the home stereo system). It serves that purpose beautifully - plays CDs, has radio function, and is lightweight and portable (and inexpensive). The sound quality is not great, but I guess I can't expect too much for this low price. It will serve our purposes until we can trust the kids with better equipment.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: This radio and CD player played well for the last two years. Now September 9, 2024, the speakers are totally dead. I really enjoyed the quality sound and operation of this radio and CD player but was hoping it would last a lot longer. :-(

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: Sound is not good. But for the price itIs ok!

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: I didn't even know they made speakers this bad anymore - sound is like that of an old transistor radio.  Tinny and no controls for quality or balance, so what you get is what you get.  Waste of money.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: I wanted to get my child a boombox for my own childhood nostalgia for their room. It's a pretty color and they love it. But the sound quality is muffled. Not very loud.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: It has a good sound. It is much smaller in size than I was expecting.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: I wanted a cheap-ish CD player that I could listen to while I work on the computer... after all, why splurge on something as antiquated as a CD player?The item arrived decently packaged. The cord is detachable, but the cord doesn't seem to match the common AC cord (like what goes into my Xbox Series S). Like others have said, the display only shows track number when in CD mode. In radio mode, all you get is a small LED that lights when the system is on.Audio quality is middling at best. Lacking in bass and treble, it sounds like... a cheap radio. Again, I'm not listening for hi-fi, so it doesn't bother me too much. Discs spin up quick and the disc drive isn't too loud. On either side of the boom box are dials: left is for volume and right is for tuning. Tuning is a bit inconvenient as the only way to approximate your frequency is by looking at a disk used to tune. Personally, I prefer having a tuning dial since I find it faster and quieter than having a digital tuner. I live in the city, near radio transmitters so reception quality is decent. The buttons used to control CD playback have their function debossed and emit a clicking sound when pressed.Overall, this purchase is just OK. I thought I wanted a cheap, barebones CD player and that's what this is. I wish I had thought more about how the radio frequency would be displayed, but it's not a dealbreaker for me. Just make sure that you are really OK with a cheap CD player before pulling the trigger; else you might be rather disappointed.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: I bought this CD player for my son who recently discovered the joy of collecting "Old" CDs. First of all, I don't know if you've noticed but CD players are hard to find these days! I was happy when I found this one on Amazon at a reasonable price. The sound is fine and I must say he uses it a lot ( as well as the built in radio.) Let's Hope his interest in CD's lasts as long as this player!

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: I have bought three of these one or myself and the others as gifts and I have been completely satisfied. It has good sound and is handy to be able to move about the house wherever I am working. It was exactly what I was looking for at a very reasonable price.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: Operates fine, but sound is rather poor. I am still giving it 4 stars, as I feel the low price justifies it overall. However, I would suggest buying something else if you want distortion free sound. But you will probably have to pay considerably more than 30 bucks. One thing I REALLY like about this unit is the small size. I had several potential cubby holes in mind for this, was not sure it would fit with still being able to open the lid, but it will go into any of the spots I had in mind.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: Easy to operate;  sound perfect.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: I purchased this as a gift for my teenage daughter because she's in her early 2000's faze at the moment and she loved it. I made sure to read some of the reviews before I purchased it, some of them weren't favorable but I decided to still give them a chance and I don't regret it. For the price, its unbeatable and the item is working perfectly fine. The plastic is a little flimsy and the sound is a little tinny but again, for the price, you can't beat it. You get what you pay for and I'm happy with my purchase.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: I gotten rid of my bigger stereo with five cd changer to make room in my bedroom for this boombox to play the radio and my cds it is a perfect size for my bedroom because a huge room. So glad it came in my favorite color purple would buy it again if necessary.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: I bought this little boombox for my 81 year old mother. It is simple enough for her to understand how to operate. It is very lightweight which is great for her to take by the handle and place on the seat of her walker to transport anywhere in the house. The sound quality is good for the price. She is very happy with it. The radio reception is not the best but she won’t be using that feature much since she’ll be using it for CD play. Overall, well worth the price paid!

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: I enjoy the clarity of the speakers. The bonus is the CD player! Small and easy to travel with.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: It is a throwback to the 90's and 2000's. CD player works. Radio picks up enough local stations (without telescopic antenna). Sound quality is definitely on the not too good side, but for the very cheap price I am happy.For a small bedroom, it's great. If you are in a loud environment, you need a Bluetooth speaker or a larger stereo.

product_name: Magnavox MD6924 Portable Top Loading CD Boombox with AM/FM Stereo Radio in Black | CD-R/CD-RW Compatible | LED Display | AUX Port Supported | Programmable CD Player |
description: Not high quality sound but good enough for my needs.  Does skip on cds if bumped in anyway.  Radio is good too.  At least it works better than a previous jenson model I bought from another retailer.  That one went in the trash.

product_name: Amazon Fire TV Cube, Hands-free streaming device with Alexa, Wi-Fi 6E, 4K Ultra HD
description: Update to below review:I hate this device with a passion that will never fade.  It'd be great if it worked, but it doesn't--at least not as advertised.I pulled the trigger and bought a receiver and speakers, so sound is resolved for my home theater, without any help from the Fire TV Cube.  But, I still have the Fire TV Cube, so I figure, OK, I'll hook it up and maybe..1) I can use Alexa voice control as a universal remote.  Nope.  After setup, it just doesn't work.  Nada.  Completely non-functional.2) OK, I've got an Apple TV and receiver to watch most of my content.  Maybe I can use this as another Alexa to stream Amazon Music, to which I have a subscription, to stream to the main level of the house.  Nope.  Crazy buggy.  The Fire TV Cube is in the "main level" room and all audio is supposed to stream on a set of devices, including an Echo Plus and a Stereo Echo Link.  But, where does the Fire TV stream to without any reason?  An Echo Flex.  You can't assign the Fire TV to the audio in the room, even though it is assigned to the room.  You can't even direct it specifically to the room.Junk! Junk! Junk!  These guys have no idea how to write reliable software.  ABSOLUTELY NO IDEA!I've had it.  I'm ripping it out because it is less than useless.  In fact, I'm heavily invested in the Amazon Echo ecosystem.  I'm out.  I will never buy another one of these devices and when I need or want something else, I'm slowly transitioning out.  Who?  I don't know, probably Apple.  More expensive? Yes.  However, their stuff mostly works and you can get decent support. Try to contact Amazon and you'll spend hours on the phone with a runaround.So, for the home theater I have Apple TV, a Denon receiver, Klipsch speakers, a PS3, and a Nintendo Switch.  Almost all my content is available through Apple TV.  If I need to use the Nintendo or PS3, I'll just pick up another remote.  I can turn on the entire system, turn off the entire system, and control volume through the Apple TV remote.  Most of the time, that's all I need, once everything is set up.  Do yourself a favor and just do what I did and get an Apple TV.  If you're happy with your TV audio you can even dispense with the receiver and speakers, or maybe get a sound bar.  Save yourself the money and the endless grief.Hate it.  Hate it.  Hate it.--------------------I suppose if you're going to use this as your main streaming device with external audio (TV or Receiver)  it'll probably work OK, although the UI is absolutely horrible and the system is buggy.  But, for my use, it just didn't cut it.I wanted to hook this up with the Alexa Home Theater mode with 2 x Echo Studio and an Echo Sub, connecting other devices (including Apple TV, which has a far superior interface and better integration with the Apple ecosystem) to my LG OLED using ARC to return audio.  The point was to roll-in Alexa Music into better sound for the TV.  But, it just doesn't work that well.  Here are some of the problems I ran into:1) When I use the Echos to play music, the Fire TV Cube will lose audio on TV content.  When it comes back seems random.  I get a lot better results if I go to the Fire TV Cube and try to play some content there first, but even that doesn't always work.  I wound up turning off audio input on this system to try to manage this better, but it only helped marginally.2) Automation is terrible through voice.  It just stopped working.  At first it seemed to work fine, so I got another one for the main home theater system in another room.  When I told this one to turn on the TV, nothing appeared to happen...until I discovered that this system was turning on the OTHER TV connected to the other Fire TV Cube.3) ARC from the TV mysteriously stopped working.4) Setup is inconsistent.  I probably tried going through the set up 2 dozen time to try to fix some of this.  Sometimes it recognizes the other devices.  Sometimes it doesn't.  Sometimes it'll allow you to configure the inputs on the TV.  Sometimes it doesn't.5) Always trying to upsell you.  You think you used the generic screen saver, which is important to prevent burn-in on plasma and OLED TVs and it'll often revert to try to get you to try new content.6) A lot of stupid annoying random bugs.After sinking a bunch of dough (AND TIME) into this, I'm throwing in the towel.  Bought a Yamaha receiver and speakers and just sticking with that.  I wish I hadn't spent so much time on this and was in the timeframe to return the two Echo Studios, Echo Sub, and Fire TV Cube.  One of the most annoying devices I ever had the displeasure to wrangle with.Unless you're seriously anti-Apple for some reason.  Save yourself the trouble.  Get an Apple TV, a receiver (I like Yamaha), and some speakers.  True, the ATV doesn't have the pseudo universal remote capability, but it just doesn't work that well with the Fire TV in any case, so you'll save yourself some grief if you get something that just works, even if it doesn't do everything you want.

product_name: Amazon Fire TV Cube, Hands-free streaming device with Alexa, Wi-Fi 6E, 4K Ultra HD
description: After several months of use, I thought this review needed an update. If it was possible to change my 1 star rating to zero stars, I would definitely do it. I keep hoping for software upgrades that would address some of the issues, but none have been forthcoming. I can't even get the upgrade that I know is currently out as the Cube says it is up to date. It isn't.Audio issues have gotten worse over time. When Surround is set to "Best Available", it is always Dolby MAT and only recognizes Atmos for Amazon content. Sound output on Dolby MAT is so low it is essentially unusable. The hype on the screen says it will provide the best format up to Dolby Mat, but that is just a lie. It provides Dolby MAT period. Similarly when set to Dolby Digital Plus it is always Dolby Digital Plus, and there is considerable delay before it recognizes Atmos, and often it doesn't recognize it at all unless I reboot the Cube. The issue with the HBO MAX app appears to have been resolved as I no longer have to restart the Cube every time I want sound on that app from the Cube. This really is a terrible product if audio matters to you at all. And audio does matter to me.And I still don't understand why Amazon won't at least give me the latest system software for the Cube. I know there are serious security issues with the version I am running (7.6.1.3) and I know 7.6.2.5 is out, but the Cube says it is up to date. Totally unacceptable service from Amazon.On top of that, the Alexa volume from the Cube's internal speaker is so low now that it is undetectable  if my ear is more than a foot away from the device, though it's medium OK through the TV. Volume on the Cube is set to maximum. The microphone isn't sensitive enough to pick up a shout from more than 6 feet away, and a shout is required at any distance from the unit.External USB storage devices are pretty much limited to thumb drives. Have tried several hard drives (formatted correctly) and none are recognized by the Cube, and it takes a significant amount of time for it to recognize a thumb drive, but it eventually does.Though it would be a huge hassle to untangle all of my Amazon stuff, I'm seriously considering switching to Apple, because this product is just terrible and Amazon doesn't seem interested in fixing it. Pretty much all of the issues are audio related. Video is pretty much OK.Previous revue:Well, I've only had it two days and lots of issues. Not ready for prime time, but when it works, it's excellent. First, it was supposed to come linked to my Amazon account. Nope that didn't happen. Shuts down at random for no reason. Takes it quite a while to recognize a change in audio format leaving me with several seconds of moving lips with no sound at all. Alexa's volume is too low even at max when running through the built in speaker. Fine running through the TV. Audio outputs are also way low. Soundbar goes up to 100, but the cube needs 20 points more than the Firestick 4K it replaces. Still usable, but strange. Hard to say at this point if it's a hardware or software issue. HBO Max app is especially problematic as far as audio is concerned. Many settings are inadequately explained. Setup asked if I wanted to import from a previous version. I've had 4 Firestick Versions before this, but my only option was to import from my very first Firestick rather than my 4K. Only had it 2 days, and maybe software updates will fix it. I'll give it a couple more days to see if it settles down, but right now it's pretty wonky. This stuff should have been worked out before they shipped.RevisedReduced the star rating to 1 because the problems are inexcusable.After 3 days of troubleshooting, I think I may have resolved the issues. The issue of the cube randomly shutting down seems to have been resolved by unplugging the cube and plugging it back in.Other issues all involved my setting the audio to "Best Available". Changing to Dolby Digital Plus appears to have resolved the issues.In my case, the "Best Available" was Dolby MAT/Dolby Atmos Mat. The problems were several and intermittent.1) Sometimes when adjusting the volume using the cube's remote cause the audio to go away altogether. Made no sense and was very difficult to receiver as it wasn't simply a matter of it muting the sound system, the cube wasn't actually putting out sound to the system at all. Randoom buttoon pushing was the only resolution.2) With the audio set t "Best Available" the cube frequently did not recoognize when a Dolby Atmos prgram had started. This was intermittent. Sometimes it switched from Dolby MAT, to Dolby Atmos MAT and sometimes it didn't. A woork around was to start the program go to Settings, chose Display & Sounds Settings, Go down to the Audio & Video Diagnostics and click "Play Dolby Atmos and HDR Content." Then hit the back button repeatedly until you get back to the program and hit play. I am not making this up.3) Once I got Dolby Atmos MAT enabled, it didn't go away when playing non-Atmos content. It did seem to play 5.1 OK while Atmos was enabled, but eventually it would bounce back to Dolby MAT, but this was also often problematic. When switching back, it went smooothly some of the time. Other times, it killed the audio altogether leaving me with the same issues as above. The other transition was even worse. The picture began flashing with the audio going on and off. The oonly work around I could find was really weird. I opened HULU and played any episode of Letterkenny. No other program oon any service including HULU worked reliably. I cannot explain this, but it is what happened.3) the low volume issue was completely resolved with the switch to Dolby Digital+ as opposed to Best Available.Solution was indeed the change in Audio Settings from "Best Available" to "Dolby Digital+". With this setting so far, Dolby Atmos was recognized on all three of the services to which I subscribe that support it, and it dropped back to 5.1 or whatever other format was appropriate to the content. As I just foound this solution this morning I can't claim that all issues are permanently resolved, but at least the seem to be for the time being. The Alexa thing is still useless when it uses it's own speaker, but fine when it uses the sound system.But it appears I wasted 3 days of challenging troubleshoooting t fid a solution and I ain't happy. Amazon doesn't document much of anything, and the on screen info is limited and often confusing. It's inexcusable that  Amazon would release a product that requires that much time and effort on the part of a user to unravel. Should have been caught and fixed in testing before it was released on unsuspecting consumers. I am seriously angry at having to do their job for them without the nice compensation they pay their engineers for.

product_name: Amazon Fire TV Cube, Hands-free streaming device with Alexa, Wi-Fi 6E, 4K Ultra HD
description: Be sure to watch my video review in the review section above!Amazon released their third generation Fire TV Cube the other day. Whenever Amazon announces a refresh of their high end TV streamer enthusiasts get excited, and every time they’re left disappointed. This time is no exception but it does remain a great choice for general consumers who are invested in the Amazon Alexa eco system.That’s not to say the new Cube is a bad product. It in fact combines two Amazon products – an Amazon Echo voice assistant and a Fire TV – into a single product. The Cube has a powerful speaker built in that works when the television is off for voice commands. Like other Alexa devices it can control any compatible smart home device.The Cube can also be instructed to turn on specific devices hooked up to the television and select the proper inputs for those devices. So for example you could ask Alexa for the Xbox and it will properly power everything on and switch the television and/or audio receiver to the right input without picking up a remote control. While some of the Fire TV Sticks can accomplish the same tasks it does require picking up a voice remote to do it.The Cube does have an HDMI input that’s designed to be used as a cable box passthrough. This is for simplicity for those challenged by having multiple devices connected to their television, allowing for the Cube and the cable box to work through a single input on the television.It’ll also upconvert other sources plugged into that HDMI port to a 4k output resolution but my preference is to set things at their native resolutions and have my television’s built in scaler handle the job. Note that the Cube's HDMI input is not ideal for upscaling game consoles as the video processing does introduce some latency.Amazon added Wifi 6E support to the Cube which performs well but not all that much better than what we experienced recently on the Fire TV Stick 4k Max. You will of course need a WiFi 6E access point or router to take full advantage of the enhanced networking performance. But it is of course backwards compatible with older WiFi standards.Beyond that the Cube largely does what other TV boxes and sticks do: stream video from streaming services. It supports 4k HDR modes including HDR10, 10+, HLG and Dolby Vision. It also supports Dolby Atmos audio from supported providers. You’ll find most if not all of the popular streaming apps available on the cube. At least for now.So the bottom line for most consumers is that if you’re heavily invested in the Amazon smarthome ecosystem the Cube will give you both Echo and Fire TV functionality in a single box with app performance that justifies its price point.But why are enthusiasts disappointed? It’s because it doesn’t have quite enough built in.The first involves its networking. Enthusiasts like to plug their devices directly into Ethernet for the best performance. The Cube has an ethernet port but it maxes out at 100 megabits per second. Most boxes that are in the Cube’s price range like the Apple TV and Nvidia Shield have gigabit ethernet. While most streaming services max out at around 40 megabits per second even with 4k broadcasts, many enthusiasts stream higher bit rate video with their home servers that require more than 100 megabits per second of bandwidth. Amazon also went with a slow USB 2.0 port that powers itself off when the box is switched off vs. the faster USB 3 ports we see on most boxes.Audio support is also a bit flaky on this. The box converts most audio to PCM and does not pass it through directly. This means that movies stored on a personal server that play lossless Atmos or DTS audio will likely have the audio quality degraded by the player and not all surround channels will be activated.Unlike some Android boxes out there the Cube does have an option for “frame rate switching” where it will switch the frame rate of the television to match the content. Most movies and many streaming shows are shot at 24 frames per second and televisions have special modes to play back that content properly. While it’s nice that it has the option most of the apps I ran on the Cube didn’t support the feature and played back 24p content at 60p. The Cube did do proper framerate switching in Plex, however.The Cube does not support 64 bit applications just 32 bit ones. While this doesn’t matter much for streaming apps it is a bigger deal for gamers looking to emulate game consoles on the box. Some of the more modern emulators are only available as a 64 bit download. And when Android apps are “sideloaded” on to the Cube they often appear with blank icons. There’s a fairly lengthy process involved with getting those icons to appear properly.So in many areas the Cube falls short of being an ideal experience. Although the same can be said for most competing boxes too. Which is why we all keep multiples attached depending on the task at hand. We all just want the box that does everything.But for now my top pick for enthusiasts remains the Nvidia Shield. While it has its own shortfalls what’s amazing is how much Nvidia got right with that box seven years ago. To this day it remains the most graphically powerful Android box on the market.

product_name: Amazon Fire TV Cube, Hands-free streaming device with Alexa, Wi-Fi 6E, 4K Ultra HD
description: Cliff notes version of my review is “For me, this Fire TV Cube did not work too well controlling my Cable box”. Of course, your results may vary… Details below:I recently purchased the Amazon Fire TV Cube. I have wanted to try this with my old TV since the New Fire TV Cube came out, and the sale this weekend pushed me over the edge. Unfortunately for me, it did not meet my expectations for what I wanted to use it for. I have a Panasonic Plasma TV that I won’t give up just yet since it still has a very nice picture, but the problem with it is it has only 1 HDMI input. I have tried several HDMI switches to add more devices, but I have not found one that switches properly. I was hoping I could use the Fire TV Cube with my cable box so I could primarily watch cable, and still have access to Amazon’s streaming services. In the end, it did not work out so well.To start, I used 2 new High Speed HDMI cables to run from my Spectrum cable box to the Fire TV Cube input and I then connected the Fire TV Cube output to my Panasonic Plasma TV. I used an IR Extender placed in front of my TV and cable box. If you don’t have one of these, you will need some Long HDMI cables, since the TV and cable box need a clear view of the front of your Fire TV Cube. I then started the programming process to get the Fire TV Cube to control my TV. It took 3 runs through the setup before it would operate the power and sound on my TV. I then started the setup for my Spectrum cable box. That seemed easy, until I tried to watch cable. The Fire TV Cube would turn on the TV, and the cable box was on, but there was no picture or sound. I discovered the Fire TV Cube was switching the inputs on my TV to something other than HDMI, so I had to go through the TV setup a couple more times until it stopped switching the TV’s inputs. I didn’t change anything, it just started to stay on the HDMI input. There was still no picture though. The picture and sound on the Amazon home page was great, just nothing on the cable. After some reboots and moving cables around, the cable came on. That was enough setup for one day, after having spent about 5 hours trying to figure this out. I finally had cable working with my Fire TV Cube. I came back to the TV after dinner to watch cable, hit the power button on the remote, and nothing! No power on the TV, I hit the button several times, and still nothing. Then it came on with no prompt or button pushing. Quite the turn on delay here! I was able to switch to cable, but no other functions on the remote would control the cable box. Enough! I unplugged the Fire TV Cube and hooked my cable box up directly to watch some shows.The next day is here, and I am ready to conquer this adventure! I hooked up the Fire TV Cube again to see how Alexa would work. This time it came on right away and I was able to turn on my cable box with the programmed shortcut key. Oh Boy! It works! My enthusiasm was short lived, as I then asked Alexa to tune to the weather channel. Alexa switched back to the Amazon home page and tried to install the Weather Channel app. No, I wanted to watch the weather channel on cable… I switched back to cable and asked Alexa to go to the HGTV channel. Alexa replied something like” You don’t have an input labeled HGTV”. I then tried to get her to go to a channel by number, and Alexa said “I’m sorry, I don’t understand”, OK, I will try this. I said go to the Science channel. I watched the blue light bar on the Fire TV Cube scan back and forth, and 20 seconds later Alexa switched to the Science Channel. I tried several channels, and yes I timed it. 20 Seconds to switch channels by voice! A bit slow, but finally something worked. I also noticed it takes about a second per push to navigate through the cable box channel guide. I also had an issue with the channel guide advancing to the second menu, like I had pushed the button twice. I tried adjusting the IR timing in the Fire TV Cube settings section, but this did not seem to help. Another issue came up also, where when I said Alex to the remote to issue a channel change command, my TV would mute. I could see the Mute label come up on my TV screen, but hitting the mute button on the remote did not unmute. I had to use the volume up or down button to hear the sound again.I had more issues with this device trying to get it to operate my cable box correctly, but I have said too much already. To sum it up, If you want a good Fire TV streaming box, this is a good option. It is quick when you are using the apps and gives you a nice looking Alexa device in your TV viewing area. For me, wanting this as a cable controller first and streaming device second, this one did not work out. The Fire TV Cube and Alexa Voice Remote Pro have been returned to Amazon.

product_name: Amazon Fire TV Cube, Hands-free streaming device with Alexa, Wi-Fi 6E, 4K Ultra HD
description: Update TwoGuess I got my answer to the review below with the following anouncement:"Prime Go ad free $2.99/month Prime movies and TV shows will have limited ads starting January 29. Pre-order ad free to watch without ads."Guess the $9,000 I spent with Amazon in 2023 alone was just not enough.  If I want fewer ads, pay more.  My request for fewer ads was monitized.  Guess enough is not enough...---------------------------------------------------I’m a staunch supporter of Amazon and will continue to be as I have found the company to be a reasonable and reliable partner in my commerce related endeavors.  My two Amazon Fire TV Cubes work great, however, they are going to the back of a closet shelf until someone at Amazon, whether that be AI or human, corrects the following problems;Because I choose to not watch advertising, I’ve kicked broadcast television to the ditch as it has become a 50/50 mix of poor content versus an equal amount of inane advertisements, many of which are simply blatant false claims.  Just can’t bear to waste so much time, and so no broadcast tv for me or mine.Yes, I choose to limit myself and family’s exposure to commercials/advertising - that is why I pay for my entertainment services.  Amazon however will not let me remove the Freevee channel (advertisement driven) and several other apps from their tv box.The top leader portion of the intro screen is often a listing of items that have to be purchased, as well as in the listings below the top leader, having channels I am not subscribed to and movies also requiring purchases beyond my monthly subscription fees.There needs to be a setting whereby unsubscribed channels and pay movies (and advertisement driven offerings), are automatically removed.  Takes too long to filter through all these items to find something to watch that has no cost attached.And I absolutely refuse to pay to watch advertising.  Yet when I use my Amazon Fire Tv Box, I am inundated by a slew of personalized directives meant to maximize my purchase of channels and movies – these directives apparently created just for me by AI driven algorithms.  These are nothing but indirect, even covert advertisements.I know I cannot win against such an adversary.  Heaven forbid I select favorites, rate movies, or select for wish lists, as I will undoubtably find them offered up on a channel I am not subscribed to or a movie listing that requires payment.Neither do I wish to see previews of other movies before a movie I have selected to watch begins.  When my family sits down to watch tv I want to be completely in control of what is shown on the screen.  Amazon cannot select the previews I let my family watch.  As a result of Amazon doing just that, my family has been exposed to vile blood and guts movie scenes and more.I have no intention of paying more than my budgeted monthly cost for the three channel maximum I choose to subscribe to – and those channels best not base their success on additional earning from me over that monthly base cost.  Amazon is wasting both of our time with constant strategies to increase earnings.This is why one channel in particularly is such a success – its services are just what it states they are, with no added attempts at additional ‘added value’ earnings, and allows watching of offerings in binge mode as opposed to doling out episodes one week at a time, which just another inconvenient strategy tied to earnings.So I purchased  and set up in my home two Amazon Fire  TV set boxes and several Alexa devices and make purchases consistently of your Amazon Marketplace web site. I paid for the hardware, I pay to use the hardware through my Prime fee -  how much  additional advertisement to you think I should allow into my home?  Is there an advertising overflow relief valve?  When will enough be enough.  Is there a brake pedal on your AI?  When will Amazon and Amazon AI understand that at times LESS truly IS MORE….I'll check back in 6 months and see if anything has changed.  I know Amazon has been responsive in the past.  For now, I will go back to an older tv box of another brand and if that’s not satisfactory....  will just turn the darn tv off.------------------------------UPDATE - Amazon did in fact contact me about this review stating the points made have been passed up the ladder for consideration.The support person did point out that on the Amazon Video apps initial screen there is a discrete listing called 'Amazon Originals and Exclusives' where all listings are viewable at no additional cost, if you are an Amazon Prime member.  That was helpful as it is not obvious.I value the fact that Amazon even choose to list such a critical review.  I continue to be impressed that such a large company as Amazon can still be responsive to individual customer needs.

product_name: Amazon Fire TV Cube, Hands-free streaming device with Alexa, Wi-Fi 6E, 4K Ultra HD
description: I purchased 2 of these one for my living room and on for my master bedroom.  I will be returning the MB one and keeping the LR one.For years I've been using the Harmony Hub with Alexa to turn on and off my Samsung TV, Sony soundbar, and DirecTV HS17 -100 Genie2.  But it stopped working. Then the Cube 3 was released and the reviews were impressive.  The one feature that was different from all the other devices out there was the HDMI pass-thru.  Being able to control all my devices and streaming through one product was what I was looking for.  I was so very wrong.Setup was pretty easy, it discovered my TV but had some issues with my sound bar, but eventually figured it out after cycling through about 10 different frequencies.  The Cube detected my DTV box, but couldn't talk to or control it, even after doing so during the setup process.  Yes, I have gone through and connected the Cube to Alexa and enabled all the skills and created routines.  But no matter what, the Cube cannot switch the input to it's own internal HDMI input that has DTV.  It also cannot turn it on, off or change the channel.The picture through the HDMI IN on the Cube looked terrible.  It was washed out and not crisp and clear.  I tried all the Cube display settings, but couldn't get a decent picture.  I even tried multiple HDMI cables but no matter what, I could not get a decent picture from the Cube HDMI IN.  I used to go through a Sony AV receiver and the picture was just as good as connecting directly to my TV.  So, this should not be happening.  I tried it on my TV upstairs with the same results.  The HDMI IN on my two Cubes does not work.I removed DTV from the Cube HDMI IN and plugged it directly into my TV and went through the Cube setup again.  I went through the Add Devices setup and it found the DTV box on my TV connected to my TV HDMI input, it could switch input on the TV and change the channel on the DTV box through the setup  process.  But once setup is complete, Alexa can only turn on DTV and switch the TV input.  it cannot change the channel or do anything else.Another issue is that no matter what the Cube starts on it's home page.  Even when you select the option to have the TV decide what Input to select when it powers on or to start an App.  The TV starts on the input 1, then switches to input 2 that the Cube is on.  The Cube does not open the App I've selected it to default to in the settings, all you will get is the Home page.  I had to setup a routine that turns everything on then switches the input back to input 1 so I can watch DTV.I got the second Cube to put in my MB as an alternative to getting a new TV.  I have an older Sony TV that  is very slow when it comes to streaming and doesn't have Bluetooth.  I have an external BT transmitter connected that works about 50% of the time.  Again one device to control everything and take over streaming and add BT seemed like exactly what I was looking for.  Nope, wrong again.The HDMI cables needed a bit of force to be inserted.  Pulling them out was even worse, so no matter what this Cube was going back.  But I figured I'd test it anyway.  The HDMI IN picture looked terrible, as it did on my other TV.  So, I could not pass DTV through the Cube, which means I cannot use the BT on the cube.  I tested BT on the Cube just to try it and it worked great.  Pairing was easy and there is no lag.  But then I turned off my BT headset and the Cube shouted, "Bluetooth has been disconnected!"  Imagine this, you're laying in bed, watching TV while your partner sleeps, you decide it's time to go to bed and turn off your TV and take off your BT headset.  Only to have the Cube, even when it's turned off shout, "Bluetooth has been disconnected!" I spent hours, turning off all notifications and searching through every forum I could find to stop this from happening.  Only to find that this has been and Amazon Echo/Alexa issue for YEARS.In conclusion:- The Cube is very fast- HDMI IN has terrible picture quality- If you have DirecTV expect only the most basic of control options.- Cube will only start up to it's own Menu no matter what setting you select you will only get the Home screen- Bluetooth disconnection is a deal breaker.1 has been returned, haven't decided if I'm keeping the second one yet.  Probably return the second one as well, since I got it for the HDMI In and it's unusable.

product_name: Amazon Fire TV Cube, Hands-free streaming device with Alexa, Wi-Fi 6E, 4K Ultra HD
description: On the hardware, comparing the Gen 1 and this Gen 3, there is a noticeable improvement. Navigating around is smoother and interfaces feel like they load quicker. Having one remote for almost everything is also great; I no longer need multiple remotes to manage my setup. On the hardware side, here are my issues:1. Sadly, they chose to continue with the 2GB of RAM which puts this device to shame. The Gen 3 Cube could have been so much more and with RAM being dirt cheap, it wouldn't have costed them anything. Everyone knows that they almost always discount their devices so why not add $5 and increase the RAM? Whoever decided 2GB was sufficient, made a really really poor choice which lacked customer obsession; they clearly didn't work from customer needs or haven't been on the internet to hear customers.2. When the Pro remote is an option, why not sell the Cube with the Pro remote as an option? Why am I forced to have 2 remotes when I prefer to pay extra and have the Pro remote?On the operating system side, they have almost done the best they can. Here are my top issues with the current state:1. After having set the equipment up, the default volume control is via the remote which requires line of sight. Being the 21st century, no one points the remote at the TV anymore but this Gen 3 Cube is hoping to make that trendy again!? It is a simple change in the Advanced Settings to switch the volume control to happen by the Cube.2. You can no longer setup a Cable box like before. WHAAaaAT!? You have to connect the cable's HDMI to the input of the Cube or else you have no way of switching to it. There is an Antenna that can be configured but it doesn't recognize the cable box and simply switches the TV to its antenna input.3. When you hook the cable box directly to the Cube and switch to it, hitting the TV Guide button on the remote not only triggers the guide on the cable box, but it also triggers the guide on the Live TV feature of the Cube. So if you were watching a program on the Cable and hit the TV Guide button, you would see the Live TV Guide and would have to hit the back button twice to see the TV Guide on your cable box.4. Either the mics are bad or the Alexa software is buggy. Even though I have the Favor This Device setting on, talking to Alexa on the Cube while sitting right in front of her, the ancient Echo Show in the Kitchen responds. The outgoing Gen 1 Cube sat exactly in the same location and had no such problem.5. The Parental Controls have always been annoying; looking at the notifications requires unlocking but Alexa would happily read them to you. There are a few other places the unlocking is unnecessarily applied; at least make it configurable for people to do as they please. I would literally take 5 minutes to code this, 2 hours to write tests, and 2 hours to localize the strings.6. While some 3rd party apps have been developed properly to exit on hitting back twice from the app's main screen, there are many that don't honor this like Netflix. The operating system should have a feature to kill the foreground app on the long press of the back button. With the limited amount of RAM, having a bunch of apps still in the background, even for a minute is too much as it slows down the device.While, as a buyer, you clearly have no choice in the selecting the generation of Cube to buy on Amazon , as you get the latest one only, it is certainly less frustrating than using the Gen 1 and its primitive remote.

product_name: Amazon Fire TV Cube, Hands-free streaming device with Alexa, Wi-Fi 6E, 4K Ultra HD
description: Since I had Alexa in my house I decided to take the plunge and switch from Roku to Fire TV.  I bought this for my living room to use with my Samsung TV to replace the Roku Ultra.It's absolutely atrocious, in all aspects.First of all, the Fire TV platform is disgusting.  Everything is an ad, everywhere.  You pause your program?  Ad.  You let it go idle for more that 60 seconds?  Ad.  Your home screen?  Nothing but ads.  Your tiles for your apps are so tiny compared to all the trash on the home screen it's laughable.Second, this thing is ridiculously incompatible with most other devices and device setups.  Basically, if you're not just hooking it up to a TV and NOTHING ELSE, then you can expect to have problems.  Have a soundbar connected via ARC?  Well expect it to mute sound randomly when using other HDMI inputs, and it sometimes won't fix itself until you restart the Fire Cube.  Trying to use a game console on one of your other HDMI inputs?  Expect the Fire Cube to aggressively switch back to itself in the middle of your games.  Trying to adjust settings on your TV?  Nope, you get 3 seconds in and Fire Cube says back to Fire TV.  Oh, but wait you can turn off CEC on your TV and it fixes some of these!  Oh wait, then your ARC soundbar doesn't work anymore.  So maybe turn off CEC on the Cube?  Now enjoy nothing switching automatically!Third, the Alexa integration to Fire TV is tolerable on a good day.  It was okay in the beginning, but now if I ask it to launch X channel on X app, it never gets it right anymore.  Which completely defeats the purpose of me switching to this platform.Fourth, Amazon's ridiculous wars with other service providers due to their unrelenting greed.  I had a Spectrum cable package that would allow me to use the Spectrum app.  This was fine on Roku, but low and behold, Fire TV doesn't have the Spectrum app.  Why?  Because Amazon doesn't want Spectrum on their platform as they are a competitor and they want to be a monopoly.  Disgusting.  And absolutely unacceptable.  Okay well fine, I guess I can just use the Spectrum app on my Smart TV.  Oh, wait the Fire TV won't LET me use anything on my Smart TV without switching back 3 seconds later.  Fixes?  See above.Fifth, and I know it's petty.  But that STUPID REMOTE.  DESIGN A REMOTE THAT I CAN TELL IF IT'S UPSIDE DOWN WITHOUT LOOKING AT IT!  It's so annoying, like a USB-A cable, it's always upside down every time I pick it up and I'm hitting channel up instead of volume down.  And please make the battery cover stay on.  I have two of these and the battery cover goes flying off every chance it gets.This product is a joke.  It's a monument to how little Amazon cares about their Alexa/Fire TV users.  Charging a premium price for something that's unusable half the time.  They don't care about your user experience, they only care about how many ads they can stuff down your throat.  They don't care about what their users want.  They don't care about making a product that's compatible with anything other than their own products.Long story short here: STICK WITH ROKUUPDATE 1:  Going to continue posting how bad things are with this awful device.  Newest issue, before I had problems with sound when using other devices, now the stupid thing will just lose sound completely when I'm just using Fire TV normally.  I have to restart this thing at least 3-4 times a day to fix this issue.  Absolutely irritating.UPDATE 2:  Got a call from Amazon about my review of my two Fire TV products.  Customer support was nice enough but they seem to be clueless just how bad their product is compared to competitors.  They seem to think having to factory reset your Fire TV every month to keep it from freezing is acceptable.  They also tried to feed me some garbage about all the CEC issues I was experiencing.  Saying I could safely turn off the CEC and everything would work because the Cube has an “IR blaster” on all sides so it doesn’t need CEC.  I don’t know if it’s true but I can tell you it doesn’t work.  I moved the cube everywhere around my entertainment center and nothing worked anymore with CEC off.  And they seemed to miss the general point of my argument being that this shouldn’t be so difficult to get working properly because for some reason their competitors don’t have ANY of these issues.I’ve finally had enough and will be dumping my Alexa devices for Google, after less than a year.  Whatever updates they’ve been feeding Alexa has made it practically unusable and it was never great to begin with.  She can’t turn on my lights anymore, can’t work my TV, can’t shut off my alarms, can barely even respond correctly half the time.  The only thing she does really well anymore is bombard me with annoying notifications I can’t turn off.I really tried the smart home setup with Alexa.  But unless Amazon shows they actually give a shit about customer experience I cannot recommend any of their Alexa products.

product_name: Amazon Fire TV Cube, Hands-free streaming device with Alexa, Wi-Fi 6E, 4K Ultra HD
description: The new features of the gen 3 Fire TV Cube are welcome. They have finally added an Ethernet port to the Cube and the new HDMI input reduces input switching previously necessary.You would think that after releasing the third generation of the Fire TV Cube that Amazon would finally correct obvious problems in the previous releases. Sadly, that does not appear to be the case. Not only are a lot of the old bugs still there, they have introduced new ones. For example, when you connect it to a home theater and set the sound to “best available” the HDMI format sent to your surround sound system is actually in PCM mode except in the case where the input was in Dolby Atmos. For some reason, it is happy to pass Dolby Atmos but converts everything else to PCM. This did not happen with the gen 2 Fire TV Cube.I bought this for use with a new TV to retain the ability to play Amazon Recast TV recordings.
